99% RNG. If you like slot machines you'll LOVE this game. I realize it's not full release yet, but boy do they need to work on balance. The first part, (pre-cruciball 10-ish) are fun and challenging, especially if you're picking the game up for the first time. However, after that short period, no amount of skill will allow you to win certain fights. Actually, you've only got a 50/50 chance of getting to the second stage since one, (of two) of the first level bosses is, effectively, unbeatable unless you've lucked into just the most perfect build. Random, unavoidable, occurrences often pop up and nuke your build. Some items are so incredibly rare they may as well not exist, while other garbage items pop up CONSTANTLY. 

I know you're probably thinking, "What do you think a roguelite is, man?". Uh huh. I thought so too. The big difference between this game and say, Binding of Isaac, or even something as simple as Vampire Survivors, is that the game WILL try to screw you over, but the decisions you make and the skill at playing the game can give you that extra little edge to win. They encourage you to "git gud" because your skill and forethought win games. This game tries for that, (and, like I said, the earlier levels largely deliver) but it just gives way, WAY too much power to RNG. Imagine working your butt off for an hour, doing everything right on one of those other games and just as you're about to win a giant hand comes on screen, flips a coin and says "Whoops! You lose! Soreeeeeeeey!". Not fun, eh? Yeah, it effectively happens on this game ALL THE TIME. It's addictive. Elements are fun. Long term? Not so much.

I think the concept of this game is great, and I find it quite fun. I'm giving this a thumbs down for now because we are heading far into feature creep territory here. There are too many new balls, relics, and effects being added, and it is hard to synergize them because there are simply too many. You can be impossibly over powered or utterly useless because of the large item pool.
Focus on improving and balancing what is already here, rather than adding new items.

There's just only like two working builds if you want to try and win - crit build and bomb build due to the health of endgame enemies, and whether you get the necessary items to complete either feels like chance. So I think I'd recommend giving this game a miss, go play slay the spire some more, it's great.

This is a grudging recommendation, as Peglin is generally enjoyable, and seems like a good modern-day successor to Peggle.  It serves as a good casual distraction for 30 or 40 minutes now and then.

But the first levels are so tedious;: you're stuck with a bunch of uninteresting orbs, all of the boards are super-boring and irritating, and the music is just ear-bleedingly annoying.  Especially the bass solo part with that terrible smarmy pretentious dry-sounding bass - I just hate it so much, It's somehow the musical equivalent of having MoistCr1TiKaL's voice whispering "M'lady" in your ear over and over.  Set the Music Volume slider to 0% as soon as you can.

Fun for the first couple runs. Once you've mastered the slightly janky physics, skill no longer has any bearing on whether a run is winnable. A handful of items are game-winning by themselves, while far more require very specific synergies to function or do so little they might as well not even exist. Weapon selection barely matters and is also RNG based, so once you start climbing the difficulty ladder you'll see many more frustrating messes than satisfying and interesting runs.

This game is cute and fun but far to random.
About 3 hours in I figured out the strat/a build I liked and then it was just a matter of the stars aligning for me to get something similar to what I wanted to win the game.

Because the combat doesn't have much of a skill element, random bad luck can often lead to an unwinnable state. 
In many other rogue likes, if you get bad luck you can actually out skill it and still win. Not here.

There's this boss that's a literal actual brick wall with a turn limit. Its just a massive damage check and if your build doesn't just happen to be stupid high damage consistently then you insta lose.

I enjoyed my time with this game but I'm never touching it again and don't recommend people buy it unless they add a way to make it slightly less RNG dependant.

Peglin combines the addictive dopamine hits of Peggle with the best elements of a number of Rogue-likes to create something far greater than the sum of its parts. As I'm writing this it hasn't even hit 1.0 and already there's an incredible amount of content, loads of orbs, relics and enemies, and a ton of build variety. After 65 hours there are plenty of items and entire builds I've yet to try, and they're adding more all the time with regular content updates and balance patches. Multiple classes and the "Cruciball" mode that allows you to keep adding additional challenges to your runs means there's plenty of replayability. It's a great value for the price. If you like Peggle and Rogue-likes, it's a no-brainer.

[h1][b]Still do not recommend.[/b][/h1]
[h2]I cannot recommend addictive gameplay.[/h2]
[b]I know it's not addiction, but it's behavior compulsion, which is the same but for behavior, and not substance abuse.[/b]
I sure hope people don't recommend crack or cocaine out there. I sure ain't doing that. And I'm not doing it either with this game. This is more a word of warning than anything, really. Like, [b]BE CAREFUL, I HATE THIS GAME AND I'M STILL PLAYING IT![/b] kinda thing.

[h2]A Rogue-lite where Skill barely matters.[/h2]
Normally, Rogue-lites, and even Rogue-likes, have learning curves. The more you play, the better you get at it, the more bearable it is to NOT get good items and such.
In this game, it's all luck... mostly. If you can't synergize your items and orbs, your run is dead. There's only knowledge of what may or may not work with one or another, and technically that's a skill. Throwing the orb can also be consider a skill but, it does little effect in the general outcome. In the end, everything has to go right up to the boss fights.
The normal battles, and even the elite ones, are not dangerous most of the time. Only if you get really unlucky. The boss fights? Well, there's a reason why the worst boss is a [b]LITERAL WALL.[/b] They are basically Stats Check. If you can't get past them, you're not ready for the next area. But, as I already said, normal battles are not a problem most of the time.
If you lose to a boss, it's just unfortunate that synergy did not work, or was not developed enough... or you just got unlucky things did not go your way. It can be frustrating when you were actually enjoying the run.

[h2][b]HERE'S AN AMAZING ITEM![/b] but[/h2]
The game has to be balanced. For some reason. So here's a side-effect that is gonna backfire so bad, you'll think twice next time.
Most items available are either mediocre, or a double edge blade. I'm fine with having both, but only having both is... not very good. What about straight up good items? Like the Meteorite Shard? The Gift that Keeps on Giving? Which both can still backfire but not as much as any other items. Often it is required to focus on something to carry the run on, but it's mostly a matter of trial-and-error if it's gonna work. It really feels like the whole game is a double edge sword, where you might or not enjoy the run you have.
Maybe, less double edging and more actual bosses that doesn't die to a single good throw could be better. It's often better to reward than to punish.
Music still good. I don't know why they made the last boss battle theme so... uh, epic? But, sure. Some battle layouts were fixed, some still lacking and some still causes me physical pain. They are these gimmick ones, like the ones that looks like trees, or something else. The Minotaur one is actually fine now. It was terrible before.

[h2]What about the Shops?[/h2]
Useless! Or close to that. I never have money for anything when I go into it, and I have to pay to remove an orb. Now that's some great business practice. You ask FOR MONEY to remove and orb that you WILL SELL LATER to someone else, because I cannot throw it at your face. [b]STONKS.[/b]
And yes, I know it has to be balance, so abusing removing orbs just so you can use the cheese and shield combo for the win might be too broken and that's why you have to pay money, but why the price increase? It barely makes sense. Or maybe I'm only getting shops in the first area, when I have no money because I'm constantly upgrading the orbs to be able to keep up with the bullshit coming up.
[b]Also I refuse saying "peg" with the amount of "PEGGING" going around the internet.[/b]

Always loved the game Peggle, and now I get to enjoy it over and over and over again whilst dealing damage to all sorts of creatures.
As with any rogue-lite, prepare to die. A lot. Sometimes in really annoying ways, especially when on a really successful run then you suddenly come across one event scenario that completely screws you over.

I love the different characters you can unlock, each with their own unique trait, and how unlocking each of these also unlocks their specialised orbs and relics.
The variety of different relics and orbs in the game, and the different ways to obtain them means that no two runs are ever the same.

Already spent so much time in this game (just to get to Cruciball level 8 from 7 took well over 50 runs!), but still got a long way to go if I want to 100% this one!
Should we start taking bets how many hours that will take?!

TL;DR: Peggle Rogue-lite. Good variety and unique playthroughs for endless fun!

I think the game balance has gotten better, or I have gotten enough better to get past some issues, so I am flipping my recommendation to "recommended." It may still be close? There is still a good chunk of randomness, but you perhaps expected that in "Peggle meets Slay the Spire." If you come from the more "Slay the Spire" side, the randomness of the bouncing balls plus upgrade randomness might be wearing. The plinko aspect itself is pretty random, and then the orb & relic RNG is unusually high for a rogue-lite.

It's fun. The basic concept is good. The execution is increasingly competent. I am having fun playing it, which is all I can really ask of a game. The Cruciball difficulties are still a bit of a balance mess, but the base game is fun enough.

Very fun and smart concept. The execution is a bit lacking, but having looked over the reviews from a year or two ago, it's clear this game has gone pretty far in the correct direction since then, so I'll give it a weak thumbs up in hopes that this game gets even stronger with time.

Despite what a lot of other players seem to think, I don't really have an issue with this game's balancing. I think you can make a lot of different builds work, and it's a lot of fun to play around with different set-ups! This is especially true on low cruciball runs, where the game feels much more fair and rewarding to play. The issue, especially in high cruciball runs, is that you need to really rely on RNG. Most builds seem to be viable, yes, but you have to really commit to those builds and get most/all relics and orbs that lean into that play style, which is a massive ask. The game just doesn't give you enough options, especially not for relics. There doesn't really feel like there's enough time to pivot either - once you pick a build, it feels like you must stick with it, and if it doesn't pan out, then GG, start again. Peglin can be really frustrating and anticlimactic to this end.

However, when things align well (or you're playing lower difficulties and having a more relaxed run), this game is super satisfying. Designing some maps to looks like the enemies you're facing is really creative. Others move about in really fun ways. The dragon fight was a personal favorite. There's just a lot of cool stuff going on. Wish there was more variety - 7 total bosses across 3 stages is pretty minimal, and each encounter's map has no variations. But I still think the gimmick is quite fun for quite awhile regardless.

It's a fun game when you don't feel like playing anything overly complicated but definitely not worth the price unless you get it on sale. It's a bit too lacking in content to warrant the $20 price tag but highly recommend if it's on sale.

It can be incredibly fun or insanely frustrating depending on RNG. You could get a devastating combination of balls and relics and still get wiped depending on how the pegs are oriented or you could have a godly combination of balls but get them in the worst possible order of use. But that's just how RNG goes, so yeah. The castle REALLY needs some balancing though since if you don't have any balls that hit any or all enemies in the lineup you'll get rinsed by archers and mages that can attack you each turn from any distance, and they're very frequent no matter the RNG so you'll run out of money to heal very quickly if you're don't have a relic or ball to help with gathering money. In fact the more money you're able to collect the easier the time you'll have...just like IRL! How immersive! 

Overall yeah I'd recommend the game when it's on sale. Just remember that it's got some balancing issues but it's cute and a lot of fun when you just need a time killer.

After my initial review, I could not bring myself to recommend this game. It had some serious flaws, poorly designed pegboards, and levels of RNG that just took away a lot of the fun.

After another 85 hours since, I can say that the game has improved by a good margin. At least a few of the pegboards have been changed, but there's still some that are groan inducing when you see them, including the dragon boss fight's board being absolutely the worst. It can render your entire build through the whole game useless because of it's poor design.

Overall, the game is much better, but the same issues, while improved, still linger. But seeing the improvements gives me high hopes for the game. Maybe not now, but totally keep an eye on it for the future.
Highly addicting

If you're the kind of gamer who:

- Has primate brain and loves to see balls bounce and numbers go up
- Loves the roguelike genre and wants a fun game to kill ~<40 min
- Needs fun classes, specialized builds and different ways to reach the end
- Enjoys being challenged the further you go on

And can deal with:

- Some losses feeling unfair, getting screwed over a few times just to crawl towards death in a dead run
- It still being developed (very sparingly)
- A limited OST (make no mistake these songs go hard. But there's like five of them)

Then you'll be smashing slimes with pebbles, daggers, swords, boulders, lasers, obelisks and whatever else you can stuff in a ball in no time.

This is a weird one for me. I like it, and I definitely recommend it, but there's definitely some drawbacks.

Some of the good stuff first: As far as a Peggle-type game goes, this is probably the best you're getting on PC. There's a simplistic, but charming art style to it. The music is pretty good. Definitely has some catchy tunes, which is a good thing since you'll be hearing a select few CONSTANTLY for large chunks of each playthrough.

The classes have tremendous variety, each allowing for a very different way to try and build your run. Certain orbs and items are limited to one or two classes, and some can just use them better than another class can due to their starting perks. You can also make custom runs out of any combination of orbs/items you've ever taken with any class.

The difficulty curve, though, is where things get a little...off. The base game's difficulty is reasonable, and if you're decent at this type of game, you'll get the hang of and beat it pretty quick. When you start going up in Cruciball levels (This game's version of Slay the Spire's Ascensions), It's not so much a difficulty curve anymore as a difficulty CLIFF. There's 15 levels in the current version as of when I wrote this, intending for 20 in the full release. 5 is what I'd call the best balance of difficulty since the negatives it puts on you there actually make some new builds possible. 8 is a good challenge. Above 10, each level has a NASTY debuff, and winning on 14-15 requires an absurd amount of skill to get to where you even have a CHANCE of winning (if RNG lets you).

Overall though, I'd still say a good game and worth buying if you're into this.

This game is fun.  It has very interesting concepts, but it is 110% RNG.  The items you get are pure RNG, the enemies you fight are RNG, and about 95% of the time, the path of your throw is RNG.  The amount of times my throw has gone the actual proper direction can still be counted on a single hand.  

The only real way to actually win is to beg the gods that your shots go the right way and that you get decent item RNG

The game is fun, but if you're a fan of roguelites and building around randomness, this one may not be for you. Like I said, it's fun, but just in a neat novelty way. The luck needed to overcome the RNG is a bit too much. For the average player, Peggle may feel very random, so there's that portion. But when coupled with roguelite elements like random encounters, second and third stage bosses you can't know about, and random upgrades, it feels very out of your control whether you will win or not.

I'd say the demo is still worth trying, and the concept is amazing, but with limited characters, huge difficulty due to luck, and difficult paths to unlock characters, it just doesn't feel worth it.

Very fun and satisfying.  It is a really good peggle deck-builder rouge-like.

In the game your goal is to defeat enemies by racking up damage by hitting pegs.  You build a deck of orbs, which are your attacks.  Each has a different damage per peg hit, and often have a special effect.  They work sort of like a deck of cards, but you can see what's coming up for a long while.  Just like deckbuilders, an important part of the game is deciding what orbs to add to your deck, considering synergies, and limiting your deck to get to your powerful orbs faster.  There are also relics, which are usually small powerups you get to keep.  Though the boss relics are special, as they are often double edge swords.  Sure one might increase the damage of all shots, but it could also remove a refresh peg, limit your aim, or prevent you from picking up more gold.

Extra Positives:
*There's a freeplay mode where you can just go crazy with random combos.
*A lot of surprise interactions with ? nodes.  They thought of what happens if you lose all your orbs.
*Save scumming is possible.  If just one bad move goes horribly wrong, you can save scum with 0 consequences.
*Not very luck based with your shots.  You can aim in all directions, and it usually feels like where the ball goes is because of your aim instead of luck.
*You heal after beating the boss for an area, leading to an interesting game of surviving with just enough health to beat the boss for the full heal afterwards.
*You can build powerful decks involving avoiding hitting critical hit pegs, which is pretty interesting.

Negatives:
*There are moments when your board is almost clear, but the refresh peg is blocked by a few other pegs.  This can result in shots only doing 1 or 2 damage until you can finally reach the refresh peg.  These situations aren't fun.
*Situations where your deck isn't very powerful, but just strong enough not to get you killed.  It's unsatisfying for you to only get 20 damage done to an enemy with 700 health, multiple times in a row.
*Runs where none of the good orbs seem to show up, or they show up so late that there isn't enough time to build the rest of your deck around it.
*One of the mini-bosses in the 3rd area is just pretty annoying.  The board is build in a way it's hard to get more than 7 hits in with a shot.

Overall, Pegglin is fun to come back to and just play a satisfying run of.

This game has been so much fun, so I'm recommending it, but beware of its current purgatory-esque state. Too many underwhelming orbs and relics, and only three zones to fight through.


Biggest problem is relic and orb bloat. Poor balancing of several of the pegboards, enemy load-outs, and events means you have to hope RNG gives you the right orbs and relics at the right time. Most Orb and relic perks aren't really strong enough to be worthwhile otherwise. You can't collect them in the wrong order either, because some are completely useless at keeping you alive long enough to find the next one. The Cruciball challenge levels make the issues even more severe.  I also don't think we should ever have to consider skipping a relic after defeating the Boss at the end of a zone. There's only two boss fights that give a reward afterwards, so is guaranteeing a useful relic reward really too much to ask for? 

Several relics are great to have in the Forest, but do nothing for you in the caves. The original versions of the gardening gloves and salt shaker had this issue, but you could still find them anywhere. Both relics have been changed, but I'd argue the gloves are actually worse now. The new salt shaker sounds nice, but it is actually useless until you have enough healing orbs or relics. 

An easy way to address the orb/relic bloat and scaling issue is to overhaul the economy. Better orbs/relics should cost more, weaker ones should be cheaper, instead of everything being the same price. The same should be the case for Orb upgrades. We should also be able to sell orbs instead of having to pay to get rid of orbs. Being able to sell Relics we don't want would be even better. Gift that keeps on giving is a great example of a very powerful relic: the dragon hoard was the Only pegboard in the game that counters the Gift, (but that pegboard was horrible no matter what your deck looked like, so I was very thankful when they flattened it out a bit!). Otherwise, the Gift can turn a losing run into a winning run. I would love to spend up to 200 G if I found it in a shop! If the shops stocked a larger fraction of the available orbs/relics, that would also significantly improve the bloat issue.

All orbs also need more upgrade potential. The price of upgrades could also vary depending on level and strength of the orb being upgraded. On a lucky run, it is possible to fully upgrade all of the starting pebbles during the Forest Level; But if you don't pick up any relics that boost the pebbles, you won't stand much of a chance at surviving in the castle when there are OP shields standing between you and a line of archers and mages that hit harder than the Slime Boss!

Slime Boss pegboard has needed overhauled for a very long time. The slime Mini-boss and Minotaur mini-boss used to have horrible pegboards, but both were significantly improved and now I enjoy them even during Cruciball!! It is very frustrating that I have to consider abandoning a run when I see the slime boss on the map.

There is simply not enough depth to this game to justify the price. The challenges to unlock the other classes are so dependant upon RNG that one of them requires the use of a mechanic (slime) that I have not even encountered it in the 9 hours of play that consisted of many full completions of the run on standard and "challenge" modes. It does not compare favourably to other roguelikes. Slay the Spire is now approaching 4,000 years since release and still only has a smattering of classes, but provides considerably more viable build possibilities. This is also true of Griftlands, Roguebook, both Hand of Fate games. Peglin has potential but is currently lacking in depth.

Game was fun, originally. Cute little game, fun concept, lots of variance. Then they decided to over-promise, under-deliver, and repeatedly lie. Full release originally in 2023, now slated for 2026 at the EARLIEST unless they pare back their promises, then maybe 2025. Conveniently, Fowl Damage and their new project should be launched by end-of-year 2025. Last patches have been wild floundering, clearly without any goal to them other than "release some changes." Like nerfing a relic that was already WIDELY considered the absolute worst relic, worse than skipping and good on exactly no builds. Yeah, it's worse now. 

RNG opted to begin work on two new games. Which, for a big studio, wouldn't even be a blip. Problem is, RNG is two guys and one gal. And the gal had a new idea or two. So now Peglin's on its way to the DayZ/Star Citizen graveyard of empty promises. Don't buy this game. They have no real intent on finishing it. To quote one of the devs via a now-deleted tweet: "We know we won't get much more sales out of Peglin, so in addition to Fowl Damage, we've already begun on a new project." 

The closest thing to "complete" Peglin will ever be is when they give up on all their promises, release one big bugfix/balance patch, and call that 1.0. It won't ever be anywhere near what the devs swore up and down it was going to be by end of last year.

TL;DR: RNG is a 3-person team who are working on two projects right now. Peglin is an unfinished game. RNG has opted to work on new projects because they already sold Peglin.
All of the frustration with the RNG mechanics of roguelikes made manifest. Who thought this was a good idea?

Overall, I enjoy Peglin. It's a fun experience blending Peggle and Rougelikes which gives a lot to discover and, assuming you enjoy the genre, is great at holding your attention for the early runs - it's incredibly satisfying to discover synergies and watch as your buffs and damage numbers go crazy. However, it's a little poor in terms of replayability in one sitting - I often find myself playing one or two runs and having my fill, whereas with other rougelikes like Slay the Spire, I could do runs for hours on end. I'd recommend this game for People who enjoy strategy games. To me, the game is a 9/10 for the first few hours, then drops off to about a 7.5/10 when you've finished discovering.

The games music and art direction is endearing, and the mechanics of things like crits and bombs are very fun to play with. A particular favourite of mine is when you can get certain relics to induce a chain reaction of bombs - super satisfying to see it go off. The bosses are interesting and generally not too easy or difficult, with the notable exception of the Slime Boss in act 1 being a complete run ender at higher ascensions, and the Wall boss in act 2 being trivially easy if you've built reasonably well. I've seen some people in these reviews complain about the bosses health pools, but my experience is that with proper scaling to do enough damage this is more than manageable - none of the later bosses health pools feel unreasonable to me even at the highest Cruciballs (this game's version of ascensions). The characters all feel distinct and interesting, and how you unlock them is interesting in itself - although certain characters are noticably weaker or stronger than others and playing the weaker ones, such as Roundrel, at higher ascensions feels a little unappealing at times.

Unfortunately, the game has flaws which mostly start once the novelty of discovery wears off. Once you start reaching higher Cruciballs, runs come down more and more to luck as you start getting worn down quickly even by hallway enemies, particularly in the 2nd act. If you're not offered the right things early, including getting a tempo relic very early on, then you're kinda screwed - as in the second act you outright NEED a lot of aoe to not eat half your healthbar to certain hallway enemies - and there's RNG to get through even with a highroll, as getting unlucky with where refreshes end up can easily whittle you down fast as your pegboard depletes without a good way to refresh it. There's also a lot of frustration with the navigation, which is, like everything else in the game, decided by Pachinko gameplay. This means that bad bounces can completely screw up your planning for the act, and feel particularly unfair. While the bosses are generally good, I do feel they are slightly unbalanced in that one of the bosses is noticably harder than the other in both act 1 and 2 (and to a lesser extent even act 3). There's also a little bit of a lack of visual flare after beating enemies, but this has never really bothered me at least, and a lack of an overarching story - but that's not what I come to this type of game for.

I don't write a Review that often.. that being said, here is my take on Peglin.

This is a fun variation on peggle. the rogue-like element works super well in this game. This game has taken over every bit of my spare time for the last couple of days. i usually play peggle shot 2 days a year or so and get bored of it. not the case with peglin. the " oh one more game " effect is very real, even my girlfriend witch is not in to pegle games, played a round after the first round of she told me "Im not really in to this but ill finished the map."  she died at the second boss and got frustrated. and went on with the day. later that evening she bought the game to play by herself and as we were sitting next to each other exploring the game together on our steam deck's. 

32 hour's in i still encounter new stuff almost every-round. there is still so much stuff to do and it its still challenging to clear all the bosses that mix up every new game. trying to make certain builds and figuring out what route to take is also allot of fun. at one point i had a build that threw bombs at the enemy for about 2 minutes killing me and the boss in the process.

a multiplayer mode would be great. as simple as taking turns or a bit more complex as pvp where at a couple of points in the game you can battle each other. but that is not what this game is about its just pure mind numbing fun.

Don't buy this game in early access!!

Let me start this off with I love Peglin, its one of my favorites even but there's a flaw with it that you can't ignore. 
past cruciball ten+ it's not a roguelike anymore. 
A roguelike in the most watered down terms is a game where you have a singular run where you can't die because it resets you to the start and you have to do it all over again. thats the charm of a roguelike. 
You come out defeated but ready to get more and on the surfice peglin is just that.

But it goes wrong when you have an option that you can restart a room and the loot you get from it, and it basically becomes essential at cruciball 10+ because at that point if you get a really bad thing the run is over and you don't want to throw 30 minutes away and loose your proccess when you got so far, or not far even!

It just honestly sucks that it becomes necessary if you dont want to spent a ridicoulus amount of times throwing runs away because you got a bad option or you simply didn't get the right once at the right time.

I love this game and it might just be a skill issue, but it just looses what I love about roguelikes so much when I feel like the game wants me to do that to progress. and it kind off also destroyed the fun I had with peglin, and the fact they're going to be 5 more is so daunting to me and really makes me not to play anymore.

Thank you for reading my ramblings. Have a good day.

I do not recommend this game RIGHT NOW and here's why;
This game is a repetitive nightmare, the only thing that changes are the final bosses in each levels. The maps are the same, the encounters are the same and each run has felt the same, I have run several times back to back and it just felt like one endless run. unlocking characters are near impossible right now with the current balancing, out of 100 runs the max spinfection i have been able to stack on a boss is 20, and the max bulwark i have been able to stack has been 30 (skill issue? maybe!) but the game shouldn't make it this hard to unlock new things even in early access.
THAT BEING SAID, this game can be something and i am holding out hope that it gets better, it plays a little better on mobile than it does here, but it is much easier to see what you are doing and where you are aiming.
The soundtrack is fun to listen to when playing through the levels and lessen the repetitive feeling as you nod your head and blow up enemies. and the peglins! I MEAN JUST LOOK AT EM! they're so cute i wanna hug em, each enemy has this same art style and cuteness to it.

I originally recommended Peglin because of the cute Mascot and the rather fun pachinko shenanigans but as of late it has become more and more unfun. Every Patch nerfs good stuff but doesnt elevate the unusable to a useful level. Every Patch some useless Orbs and Artifacts get added that clutter the Loot table to an extend, where you know right after the Forest if you lost the game. Bosses are weirdly balanced, with the QR Code being a God amongst men, whilst the crystal thing barely does anything. It is a coinflip if you get absolutely mauled during your travel or if you breeze through the entire thing without issues. Some Elites and non Elite Fights are balanced so badly, that they are absolute run enders like the Person doing the Handstand in the last Area. 

It is a very short game which prizes itself on replayability, yet the Maps never change, there is never anything interesting and after 20 Hours of playing this on the Steam Deck I feel like I know absolutely every Event and Fight by heart. There is about 5 to 6 Hours of original Content, after that its just "which fight havent I seen, Which Boss havent I fought and which Orbs havent I used". 

I started off loving the game but I dont feel like its going in a good directions. Content Updates just litter the game with garbage and it is so random if you even got a shot at winning, even if you consider other pachinko games. Peglin is fun when you do well, but skill plays such little importance that you might as well blindfire.

I like Peglin, I just cant really recommend it anymore and I will give it another shot after it leaves Early Access.

I'm not a fan of rogue likes. I've bought a lot of rogue likes and none have been a big hit for me... Except for Peglin. While there are several things that a gaming casual like me cant appreciate such as the rather tough challenges to unlock new characters, i do really appreciate the amount of achievements you can obtain by simply trying new strategies. on top of that the art style of the game is very cute (which I enjoy as a pixel artist myself) and the writing has given me several good laughs. Of course lastly the game is very fun because it has the tried and true peggle as your attacking method. I'm a big fan of games that give you minigames as your method of attack and this game got that down to a science. all that to say i recommend this game. you might not play it for a long while in one sitting but you will rack up playtime over all while playing.

Until then, buy on sale.

This game is fun enough for a while, I suppose. Unfortunately it gets really old after a while.

So this is basically Slay the Spire meet Peggle. Instead of a deck of cards, you have special balls that behave in unique ways. Neat conceptually, unfortunately there's really almost no variance. A few of the orbs and relics can really influence the way you play, but most of them really don't. You're supposed to be able to unlock other characters with unique abilities, but the unlock requirements seem virtually impossible to achieve through anything but sheer dumb luck.

Speaking of luck? There are so many luck factors to this game that you basically can't plan for anything. Just pray that RNGesus is kind to you... in your map layout, the orbs you're offered, the relics you're offered, the enemies you face, the bosses you get, the order your orbs are dealt, the way your orbs bounce...

It gets just straight up frustrating at times, especially when you have a really good run, right up until the last boss and you're even doing good on that boss which you've never beaten before... then the game just decides that... you're done.

On top of that, I don't feel there's enough content to warrant the price tag. At full price the game feels incomplete. I say wait for at least 50% off.

*edit to add:
I finally managed to complete the objectives to unlock the other 3 playable characters, two of whom don't really seem any different than the base one except you're more restricted. The third, I can't tell you because the game decided not to register me winning a battle with over 100 Ballwark, which took me forever to achieve because of how many times the game was just like "LOL, no Ballwark generation for you."

At this point, I've uninstalled the game, and have no intention of ever going back to it. I'd rather just roll a d6 and declare that I win if I roll 3 6s in a row. Less frustrating use of my time.

This game is ok, it just never got any better, and arguably has gotten worse over time. The main problems are gameplay related, but for starters, the presentation just isn't there. This is a peg/pachinko game. It needs to have a good celebration when you win. It doesn't have to be fireworks and choruses when you finish a level, like peggle, but you need some kind of worthwhile celebration. That's just a staple of the gametype. 

Things get really repetitive after a while. You may say "this is a peg/pachinko game, of course it gets repetitive", but I'm speaking more to level progression. The worlds are always in the same order, and always have the same levels in the same locations, and there is always the same progression through the worlds. There are a few different paths to choose from on each map, but it gets tedious following the same progression and the same routes and seeing the same levels over and over. This is a peg game; it shouldn't be super complicated to program procedural levels and layouts and map progression. It wold be nice to see things changed up and not have to be stuck on the same few tracks again and again.

Poor balancing plagues the moment-to-moment gameplay. You'll cruise through levels as you crush enemies and mini-bosses, but world bosses starting with the castle have huge health boosts and make you feel pathetic. There's nothing fun about mowing through common enemies, and then watching a 10k HP boss receive 48 damage per shot for multiple shots in a row. It's like watching a train wreck, because you know there's no way you will beat the boss with the tools you have. Maybe I'm missing a key gameplay element in boss fights, but they have stupid high difficulty spikes that feel like cheap shots. I don't remember bosses being this bad when I first picked up the game, but it just feels stupid now.

Too man garbage orbs and relics clutter the game. The devs have continued adding new orbs, but too many are crap. Some of them will absolutely destroy enemies while others waste your time. It's the same with relics. Some are such garbage that you'll end up rejecting the relics offered to you instead of taking one, while others are basically a win button. Players should enjoy building their bag of orbs and experimenting, not spending their time wading through garbage in hopes of finding something useful.

There's also been a fair amount of nerfing of useful items. If your solution to poor balancing is nerfing the useful items then your design is poor. You are taking the useful items and making them garbage, which ends up making everything garbage. You should be lifting up your crap and making it better, instead of taking your good things and making them crap. As an example, lightning orbs especially have been turned into garbage. It could be argued they were OP originally, but they are absolutely useless now.

As this game is still in early access, the devs have been continually adding content to the game. But so far their additions have not positively improved the gameplay experience. Currently it seems they are shoving content into the game without taking the time to iterate on making it fun, meaningful, or interesting, while also negatively impacting what was good in their game.

Also, this line on the store page description, "Explore a new map every time, with different orbs, enemies, and surprises along the way.", is false. It is NOT a new map every time. It is not a new map anytime EVER. Unless there is a feature that I am unaware of, the game always progresses in the same order, and while you have the option to choose different paths on each map, they always end up in the same place.

I doubt I will play this much more. I may check in again if it ever leaves early access, but as it is now, the game gets tedious after a while and often makes you feel like you've either been cheated or like you received a win button. Neither experience is fulfilling.

One last note: you cannot change the keybindings. Why? That's a basic thing to do. Weird oversight.

I was expecting to like this as I really like pachinko as a genre and roguelikes but this game fell flat for me. The price of this game ( normally $20) of over $5 is way too high for the gameplay of this game and eventually why I did a refund after playing for a short period.

It's kinda boring in which it doesn't feel like a good pachinko game. The idea of the game is really cool- but the actual gameplay is very one-note. The ball types you get don't really change the overall feel of the game with their effects/impacts on the round. I don't feel any growth or progression outside of a variety of ball-types and leveling these balls effects.

I feel like the "pachinko" aspect isn't really the highlight as it tries to adapt a pinball-like physics when interacting with the pegs/stages. The RNG of physics doesn't feel heavy. Everything is a bit too bouncy imo and there's no real weight behind the ball you shoot- maybe for the best player-wise to get more pegs but it doesn't feel like pachinko outside of the way the game is framed.

I'm sure this hits for a certain audience as this game is generally well reviewed- but I really didn't care for this as a pachinko game nor as a roguelike. Maybe it's the graphic style or overall physics- but nothing hit despite being on my wishlist for a long time thinking that this game looked interesting.

If you want to play for fun and throw random balls, watch how number grows and then hits enemy, this game will be great for you. 

If you want to play on higher levels (Cruciballs) or you're a completionist who wants to max out the game, around Cruciball 8 it will start to be harder. After Cruciball 12 the fun will end, as game take more and more of your tools to deal with enemies. On two final Cruciball levels the suffering will start, there will be no place for fun or experimental builds, you will feel every missed shot, every awkwardly placed refresh will make you rage and you will have a list of boards which you hate. You will abandon runs, you will alt+F4 the game, you will throw hands when you die in most dominant run, just because you run into unfavorable encounter.

In general game if fun to pick up and start playing, concept is pretty nice. Unfortunately, the base of it is the reason why this game can be so frustrating on higher levels. You throw balls onto the peg board, you cannot fully control how or where it will go. You cannot control the layout of the board or where specials pegs appear. Problems with this are very apparent on higher levels where enemies have more hp, your deck is worse, your board is worse, and a single mistake can cost you even 40hp in some encounters. Two runs in a row you can see same first enemy, one time you will beat it without losing any health, and other time you will lose 20 - just because RNG hated you. 

To sum it up, a wise man once said "I am ready to get hurt again". And this is the best approach you can have towards this game.

I generally like this game but I'm leaving this as a rage review to complain about the state of boss relics. For the last patch or two the boss relic pool has been saturated by total garbage where I either am compelled to skip my pick or I take a bait relic and die as a result. A few 'powerful drawback but niche strength' relics are cool, but [url=https://peglin.fandom.com/wiki/Category:Boss_Relics] look at this pool. [/url] It's nearly every single one. Stuff like 'take a crit off the board' or 'take a refresh off the board' might not be too harsh drawbacks for some decks, or even benefits for others, but too often for the last several months (Imo the addition of Leaf the Rest for Later, which is ONLY SEMI-DECENT IN REFRESH ABUSE DECKS, THE ARCHETYPE IT IS EXPLICITLY DESIGNED FOR, YES I HAVE TRIED IT was the breaking point) it has felt like I go through the whole first two acts only to get fucked by one of my boss relics in act 3. 

Bosses don't feel good to beat anymore and haven't for a while. I shouldn't be compelled to skip the majority of my boss relics, but considering they range in quality from 'accidentally trigger a crit with a multiball in your muscircle deck and nerf your damage by >30%" to "kill yourself," it seems I have no choice. This will stay here until boss relics get some adjustment because right now the pool is far too saturated with these annoying monkey's paw relics.

It's very fun, but after Cruciball 7 it really gets frustrating. You constantly have to pause and return to the main menu to get the right relics, and there are no benefits for having a higher Cruciball level, only hindrances. It doesn't feel rewarding to level your Cruciball up. Plus, only one boss from each stage is fun to fight against. However, the game isn't a complete slog, I still really enjoy playing it. The physics are really solid, and seeing the little ball rack up the damage is very satisfying. With some tweaks to the Cruciball levels and changes to some annoying boards, this game could be a lot more fun. But currently, I can't quite recommend it. But I really want to.

I picked up this game on launch day thinking it was a cute and quirky little experience that I wanted to try out and support. It is that but it's also become a very solid and consistent game that I come back to for one quick run here and there, more so than almost any of it's contemporaries.

I highly recommend this game as an investment more than anything, you may not buy it and sit down with it spending 20+ hours slinging pebballs for your entire weekend but I can guarantee it's one you come back to a lot because it really does something in this space that I don't know any other games are doing, or are doing as well as this.

If you're going to play a video game, play one where you have some agency. 99% of this comes down to luck. What trinkets are offered, what balls, and as the difficulty level increases the game brazenly cheats, causing your orbs to bounce in ways completely contradictory to any known laws of physics. Indeed, playing on a higher difficulty and then going to a newer character on a lower difficulty setting makes this blindingly apparent, as you can rather easily predict the path the ball will take from a given bounce as it approaches the peg.
On the higher difficulties this becomes impossible, as the ball will sometimes lose all momentum upon striking the peg, despite it not being a slime peg, or bounce in the same direction as it was going when it hit, when it should very obviously have rebounded.
The first few difficulties are quite entertaining, but as the cheating becomes more and more apparent the higher you climb, the game loses all appeal as your input means less and less.

The game turned into a 'pray to RNGesus,' 'find the perfect build to progress,' and 'endlessly restart the game to get a decent starting item'[spoiler](yeah, even worse then in TBoI)[/spoiler] ordeal.

In short[spoiler], as a player who has obtained [i]Dead God in The Binding of Isaac[/i] and [i]The One Perfect Book in Library of Ruina[/i],[/spoiler] this game is [b]excessively reliant on pure randomness[/b] from start to finish: from the trajectory of the ball to the items you get

I... *really really* want to recommend this game. I got it when it was in much earlier access than it is now, and loved it.

The problem is physics updates.

I don't know why, but around the time they added classes the devs changed the way ball physics worked, and what had been a solid, predictable Peggle experience changed into something more akin to a pachinko machine, with much of the skill involved in ball placement and trajectory targetting being lost.

This, IMO, harms the roguelike nature of the game, since it renders the skill side of the equation more or less moot, often as early as the initial launch of your ball. This is disappointing, because a LOT of what this game does -- from the ball abilities to the visuals to the music -- is great, but without that element of control in your play, it stops being a roguelike puzzle game and, instead, turns into an experience where all you can *really* do is pick abilities and hope they work out.

Before the changes I got multiple completed runs in the game. Since the changes, my completion amount has dropped to zero.

Genuinely a 10

TLDR: I recommend this game with the caveat that you should probably wait for the full release or a sale. I think it's fun and offers a fun unique spin on the rogue-like genre. Granted I haven't played many rogue-likes (which may be where some of my frustration stems from) but I've seen gameplay of enough to know that this is fairly unique. I also really love the simplistic art design and un-intrusive sound effects. I've experienced some frustrating parts of the game which are even more frustrating because they really dont have to be.

The game is fun and can be addicting. Some of the boards are oddly frustrating (oddly for the reason that... they shouldn't be). I'm reviewing this in early access so I understand that the overall quality has room for improvement and that the game length can be considered pretty short. I think a full run through at normal speed can be completed in around 25-30 mins depending on your build. Currently I'm okay with it because I usually play while watching a movie/youtube so I don't care. I like the possibility of potential variety of combining orbs and artifacts to customize your builds but some of the artifacts are a bit perplexing in that their negative effects do not outweigh their positives, especially considering there are artifacts only with positives which you will most likely hunt down and pick no matter what every run.

I understand that in early access there is still a lot of work that should be done to make this experience truly great and fun and I purchased after playing the free demo to support the devs in hopefully, someday, releasing the full product.

I like the challenging enemies and bosses, but it's annoying that your success essentially hinges on very specific items and sometimes nearly killing yourself to burrow through to a damn refresh peg. Currently I don't see a ton of build variety.

My suggestions for the devs off the top of my head:

- Please rework some of the boards or the physics as they can become incredibly frustrating, like beating your head against a wall smashing 1 peg per turn to get to a refresh peg that too often end up in some of the goofiest and trickiest places. It especially sucks when I've got 1 or 2 good orbs and 5 lvl-1 pebballs (the game's version of a basic bitch orb).

- Add more maps and board variety for certain encounters. 

- Rework some of the negative artifact effects.

My suggestions for the customer:

- PLAY THE DEMO to see if you like the game

- Buy the game if you feel like this game adds enough of a unique spin on roguelikes and support the devs to see this game to its full potential.

[h1] Introduction [/h1]

I've sit and contemplated on whether or not I actually recommend this game to people and have given it a few updates to see if anything really changed with my opinion and I think at this point I have to just give up and go with a no on the recommendation, at least overall. There's some caveats I'll get into, however. I will also be using Slay the Spire as a reference point since this game takes a lot of it's structure and underlying mechanics from that game.

Been playing this ever since there was just one class to play as, and now after all the updates and everything I feel like I have a lot to say about where I stand on the game:

For the first few maybe 10-20 hours of runs, experimenting with the different classes and climbing up to around Cruciball 5-6, you'll generally have a good time, it can be a bit more RNG heavy than your usual rogue-like/lite, but for those first few hours it's not too egregious. I cannot say it stays that way, unfortunately.

At around the Cruciball 7-ish area the game goes from "Fun experimenting with different builds and making the most of what you've got with each class" to "If you don't have a very hyper-specific build going for your class, your chance of winning is 0%" and it's like the flip of a switch. Then you hit Cruciball 10+ and it becomes "If you don't get an even more hyper-specific build going IMMEDIATELY, you're not even going to make it through Act 1, or even halfway through it"

There's no real difficulty curve, it just does a vertical spike every 4-5 difficulty levels. Compared to something like Slay The Spire, where it does the same sort of thing with it's difficulty, but each character has much more viable build varieties and is overall just much better balanced in that game.

[h1] Issues With The Game [/h1]

To get into more specifics about the problems with this game, I'll break them down here:

[h3] Orb Rewards [/h3]

In STS each class has their own set of starting cards, with a few generic cards shared by everyone and 2 unique cards to them that [b] will not appear in any rewards [/b] outside of one specific random event that can happen. This is important because in Peglin, each character has the exact same number of starting orbs, and 1 orb that is different for each class (except Peglin and Roundrel have the exact same loadout), every one of these orbs can still be found again as a reward for beating a fight.

This creates a problem of just adding more bloat to the item pool that is already too bloated. No one is realistically ever going to take these items as a reward either, so they're literally just there to make getting a viable build harder. Add this on top of the fact that 2 Cruciball levels add even more useless junk to your starting loadout, and it's just not fun to see yet another stone or daggorb in your rewards when you desperately need something to get a run going.

[h3] Build Variety [/h3]

This is most likely the biggest issue with the game, or tied with another issue I have. As stated before, from Cruciball 0-5/6 you can get away with actually experimenting with new things and have a lot of builds work and this is where the game is at it's best. Anything past that though, you need very specific builds to even have a chance of winning.

This wouldn't be as big of a problem if not for one thing: reward bloat. Way too often will you get entirely useless rewards, or orbs/relics for builds that just straight up have no chance of actually winning, and as cruciball gets higher, less and less become viable and everything in general becomes harder to actually obtain. 

As it is at the time of this review, each class has 1, MAYBE 2 viable builds to go for in Cruciball 7+, except for default Peglin because he has access to nearly everything, which creates the bigger issue of the item pool being so bloated you'll almost never get any kind of actual build going.

[h3] Level Variety/Quality [/h3]

This is the other biggest issue with the game, there's just not enough variety in board layouts and the game becomes far too same-y much too fast. On top of that, a lot of board layouts are just really badly designed. You can very often find boards that can have your refresh option be near impossible to reach, meaning you'll be wasting shots just to dig it out of some corner. 

The game has one and ONLY one relic that can cause the refresh pegs to move, and you can add more of them through other relics, but this is still an issue that can occur unless you have, again, a very specific build to curb this issue.

[h3] Navigation [/h3]

Another issue I have with the game is the way navigation is done. After you beat a level, you have to shoot a ball into the area that goes the direction you want to go. Sometimes there are fire-pits that do damage to you for misnavigating. As an idea, I like it, however, a lot of board setups and other various issues very, VERY often cause you to go a direction you don't want to go.

This kind of navigation works for something like STS as you can plan out a route, weigh risks vs rewards and decide on last minute branches on what you want to do depending on how well a particular floor went. In Peglin, you can very desperately need to go one direction and either the board is set up in a way that makes that impossible/entirely random, or you could shoot your ball and it just so happened to shoot a bit harder than usual this time and bounce off a peg so hard it bounces in the other direction with no real control, and every time you misnavigate it almost never feels good or like you could have prevented it.

[h1] Conclusion [/h1]

Overall with all of these issues, I can't in good faith recommend the game. It is fun for those first few hours, but once you start digging into the harder difficulties and challenges the game offers (which is the only real extra content waiting for you after beating it the first few times), things become just entirely unfun and frustrating and just gets exponentially worse in that regard the further you go.

I do hope the devs fix a lot of these issues the best they can because the game does have a lot of potential and can be fun under the right circumstances. I wouldn't have put 93 hours into this game if there wasn't something there hooking me, after all. But to anyone looking to get into it, be warned, either wait and play something like Slay The Spire instead, or if you do choose to get this game, just be prepared for the frustration that will eventually happen.

If things change in the future i'll update my review and recommendation, but as of now this is where I stand with the game for anyone looking to get into it.

It doesn't matter that this is in early access at time of writing, It's well worth the money already. It's not just that it's roguelike Peggle. It's the massive pile of relics and balls to acquire and level through your run. It's each enemy encounter getting its own board layout customized to that particular encounter. It's the polish added in every update, the fun random events, the goblin charm oozing off everything. At time of writing I have over 50 hours, and just finished the last difficulty level (15) as the starting character, getting the last (as of now) achievement. I was still using a new build, unlocked a new relic.

Peglin's an amazing game to boot up for an hour for a run, or a few minutes for just a board or two, or get lost for the whole afternoon. highly recommend!

Hopefully I can make the review positive in the future, but as of now, there is way too little content in the game to recommend as a roguelike. It's fun enough for a run here & there, but even just in 3 runs, I would be incredibly surprised not to have several relics that the game gives you in each, because the loot pools are so small. Room & enemy variety also is lacking. If you have 15 dollars & aren't expecting much, it's a lot of fun, just not something I can sink nearly as much time into as I'd like

I want to love this game but the RNG is so dog sh*t and there are way too many forced debuffs/game ending mechanics. like 1% of your runs end with a solid deck. every aspect of the game is rng to the point the house always wins. fix your sh*t, its not nearly this hard to get a good deck in FTL by end game. when you get far enough in the game, skill is irrelevant and its pure RNG / reloading saves over and over.

I purchased this game a while back around the time when you only had one class and certain things felt kind of unbalanced. I ended up taking a break after beating my first run since certain items/orbs were either completely useless or insanely broken. Coming back after a few months, the game feels easier in the best ways possible. Encounters feel challenging, yet possible, encounters like the ballista encounter is far easier with amount of piercing orbs or orbs that get around hitting the enemy in front, and frankly, I love the new gameplay options.

As an example of a glowup, the Gambler's Chip used to be significantly worse, since two of the zones were 0x. So if you were running orbs with multiball and a single one hit a 0x, your entire damage shot didn't actually matter anymore. Now, since the 0x was changed to 0,5x, you still get punished for taking it and not getting the shot lined up so it hits the 2x, but now multiball actually works in a way that doesn't completely invalidate your Gambler's Chip. 

Builds feel easier to craft, the orbs feel powerful and honestly, I really like where the game is at in terms of balance. Highly recommend, and honestly at this point, I can't wait to see any new orbs that come out

[b] This game is good and honest fun, but, especially once you reach the higher difficulties, it is far too random and inconsistent for my tastes. [/b]

Many runs will fail based purely on unpredictable and uncontrollable factors. Again, at lower difficulties this problem is not a problem, but this is not because the difficulty modifiers introduce it, simply because the lack thereof grants a sizeable buffer to random punishment that makes it manageable. Most of the game's problems are built right into its core. It would benefit greatly from a minor reduction to the difficulty of the modifiers and a serious overhaul of many of its random attributes to be more reliable.

I will amend, however, that the game is still in beta so my concerns may be addressed, and, for some, they may just be an aspect of the rogue like experience. My specific complaints may come from a dissonance of how much control I wish to have in a style of game that hinges inherently on random factors. I believe it could be much better, but perhaps that is just me. All in all, the game is probably worth checking out, but at the higher difficulties its randomness can make it exceptionally frustrating.

Peglin is a really fun rogue lite game that combines pachinko, strategy, and dungeon crawling. Although there is luck involved, there is enough strategy to keep one playing again and again. As you progress, you unlock various characters and debuffs which can make the game more challenging. Some bosses can be really difficult depending upon the build you've set up! Unlike some rogue lite games, it is random enough to not feel repetitive, and the ability to make the game harder ensures that one won't get bored if they find the early game too easy. Highly recommend!

Updated review:
Coming back to this game after several updates I find it a lot more annoying and tedious to play. Sadly it is the kind of roguelite that gets more difficult as you unlock more things. The amount of stages you go through doesn't change but there are more stuffs in the item pool so the game become a lot more RNG heavy as it keeps getting more difficult to find synergy in your builds. It's really frustrating when every run ends up having a half-build that doesn't work because the game refuses to give you anything that works well together and every wins felt like you got the better roll instead of having a better build.

Initial review:
Surprisingly fun and addictive roguelite. The balancing could use some more work and due to the nature of the game I feel like the balance will never be perfect and you can't really get rid of RNG ruining runs because of it. 

As of the time of this review the game currently has 3 maps with 2 bosses each (6 bosses in total). The bosses all have their own gimmick but none of them really play upon on peggle gameplay and more of a test to your build. There is also the usual ascension system from other roguelike in the form of Cruciball in this game, but they felt more tedious than challenging. With all that said it is still a really enjoyable experience with more updates to come.

Sick play on deckbuilding/peggle. Game got redundant after beating the new bosses though. They added a bunch of different orbs and a bunch of different ways to build your orb deck, but I feel like it's very linear. Cool combos don't help you in the end. It's just about how strong and OP you can get. Which forces me to not like the game. I want to like it, but no.

I said in my review that they would eventually add enough content for it to be worth the price, and at this point, I think that has probably happened.  I would still like a little more depth, but the breadth is now there.

[strike]As of the time of this writing, the price for content just isn't there.  It's a great concept and a fun game, and I have no doubt that one day it will be worth $20 if the developers add content, but in Early Access, this should have been a $10 until they did that.  I understand the game is not complete, and purchases are being used to pay for development to a certain extent, but this is Early Access ãƒ¼ not Kickstarter.

For the first few weeks after I purchased the game, it had become pretty unbalanced and, to an extent, what I would call "artificially difficult".  The developers addressed this, but that artificial difficulty had been helping to mask the lack of content by gating the last 5% of the game behind difficult RNG, without making it obvious that it was only the last 5% of the game.  Right after the re-balance patch, I realized the spot I kept getting stuck on was the game's final boss fight.

You will no doubt have fun if you purchase this game, and I certainly have, but I also suspect you'll be wishing you had at least some of your money back as well.[/strike]

Its great fun, don't get me wrong. But the game state is closer to a demo than a game, and the price tag is higher than even a full game would deserve (unless they add way way more). 

The game is 3 stages, no endless mode to enjoy your crazy builds. 
Some builds are nearly impossible to get going, for a mediocre result (Healing -> dmg build), and other builds are basically a free win blindfolded.
The enemies are super limited, and even with different sprites, their attacks are limited to 4-6 mechanics.
Some relics are build defining, some relics are top tier for every build, some relics are generally strong, and some are...... OK.
The orbs are very varied, and all of them have some fun mechanics.


EDIT: 
The first review was more than a year ago. A lot of changes got pushed out, and new content added. The big negatives have been fixed, enemies and boards are now way more interesting and varied. Relics are still unbalanced, but now in a more fun way, and the worst relics have been remade.

Sometimes you will face a random encounter that perfectly blocks your build and causes you to suffer a crippling defeat at the last second.

Despite that itâ€™s still an amazing experience almost every time you play, especially if you focus on going with the flow and try to make new, funny, or outright strange builds as opposed to just trying to win using an â€œoptimalâ€ strategy.
Donâ€™t like that? Try the cruciball [sic] instead. It may not be the hardest thing out there, but it can certainly give you a few hours of a challenging deck building experience where youâ€™re forced to improvise and use your knowledge of game mechanics to scrape by with what you have.

Although it may not seem like it on paper- I believe that this pixelated pachinko-playing goblin simulator is an amazing standalone game that is well worth its price (plus thereâ€™s a free demo you can try).

This game is AWESOME! I have over 250 games in my library, and this game is already on my top 20 of most played games, soon to be on the top 10. And it's probably among the cheapest games I have. It combines the adictive fun and randomness of Peggle with a strategic gameplay that makes this game way deeper than the old Peggle games. 

The game in its core is a roguelike, and you'll lose and start over a million times, but if you manage to beat the game (3 worlds with around 10-13 "levels" each), you can start your new round with a twist, that keeps adding. So after you beat the game the first time, maybe enemies will be a bit stronger. And if you manage to beat it that way, then you also start with less gold. And if you beat it like that, then next time you'll also have less special pegs on each level. And such, and such. This means you always have a new challenge to beat. After 80 hours, I'm at Cruciball level 9 and there seems to be at least 15. And you can also change the character at some point, which brings new game modes into the table.

Really, it's worth every penny. Try it, it won't dissapoint you.

-------------REVIEW BELOW IS FROM TWO BIG UPDATES AGO, THE PROBLEMS ARE GONE. --------------------------

I'll be blunt, this game is (can be) pretty fun, but ultimately badly designed. There's way too much rng; the worst kind of rng.

I'm talking about the higher cruciball levels (the game's difficulty modifiers; 15 lvls). which the game is not at all designed around. Why? It's because a single bad thing can ruin an entire run. This includes even a single bad shot (though this is an extreme example, it happens, and enough times that its a problem). 
Much more common is a terribly placed refresh/bomb/crit, which happens too often.

Even if everything is and is going perfectly a single rng based bit of unluckiness can screw everything up, this remains the case the entire run. 
And since you need a good setup to have a shot at winning, you're probably going to have to rely on the random events. That adds even more rng. As normal fights are often not really worth the cost/risk.
I should also mention this is with constantly going in and out of the run so i can constantly be, resetting fights, rerolling artifacts, pegs, orbs and other things obsessively, which probably isn't intended.

While the rng, which governs every espect, the map, enemies, loot, peg placement, cycle of orbs you'll be firing, etc., is a problem, what makes it unbearable is all the 'checks'. 
In other words, 'you don't have the counter/solution to a problem you're extremely likely or just garenteed to face, you're dead.' These include: can you deal with shields and/or multiple enemies (multi target and pierce), red bombs (requires great healing or a lot of hp), multiple sources of dps checks (the Wall bossfight, the castle mage elite, in the castle killing enemies fast enough to get to the archers and mages before they deplete your health, 4 boxes final bosses).
The games expects you to have everything while giving nothing.

And there's a few more rare checks, like the third floors invisible enemies or how you can deal with your orbs being funneled into a single hole (looking at you dragon).

Since it's a turn based roguelike theres's no getting around bad rng with skill like, taking a populair roguelike(lite) as an example, hades or something.

The central problem revolves around not having enough resources (gold, dmg and hp) and having to constantly deplete them. This leads to constant early deaths (and deaths in general) even with good setups and thus a LOT of frustration, because of something completely out of your control. That's why i call it badly designed.
A bonus/free chooseable or in the beginning of a run, much like the free relic you get would go a long way to make it more doable. That or along with a reroll button (that can even reroll random events and what you're fighting, 'cept the bosses).

Put alot of hours into the game, still some quality of life upgrades needed and updates slow.  More peg patterns, an ability to end an attack when ready (upgrades and certain ball types have had me stuck on doing 10-20k of damage and just constantly cycling over and over the board before the turn ends).  I've beaten it over and over but no more cruciball mods to make it harder.

That said, 30 hours in and I still play it.  Fun game, just needs to offer more for folks who have gotten this far into it.

I normally don't care for Early Access games but this developer has followed through on their promises thus far and the game is already incredibly fun. If you ever played Peggle and loved it then you will enjoy this game even more. I didn't think it would be possible to combine pachinko with an RPG but here we are! You select a character, each with their own perks. Next, you'll choose an artifact which allows you to modify the balls, board, or navigation to start and then jump right in. The first few times you play through will be fun in their own right but the true fun comes after you understand what each of the balls and artifacts do. Once you have this understanding you will be able to come up with some absolutely insane combinations of powers that allow you to just obliterate your enemies. New players alike will be able to pull this off (even if by accident) as evidenced by GF giving the game a try at my request and doing better than me! I strongly recommend giving this game a shot if you want something fun and relaxing; you'll have a BALL (couldn't resist).

I want to like this game, I loved Peggle, I think the idea of combining a roguelike 'card' game and branching path game with peggle is great, but there are just too many issues.  First thing I noticed that drove me nuts is my cursor doesn't actually line up with my shot trajectory.  Got used to that, kept playing for a couple hours. Only my first run was not frustrating at every turn. Most of the relics are garbage that requires you to take a debuff to get a buff that may or may not be useful, bad enough when you're picking one (assuming you can even get one that doesn't just straight debuff you given the rest of your build), but really bad when it is just straight given to you from a ? tile.  (FYI - the coin that makes the bottom slots do 0.5x / 1x / 2x damage, and makes one of the 0.5x slots do damage to you, is just straight terrible)  The explanations of the orbs are bad. Some of them aren't too hard to figure out, but others just have an icon for what it does, and some tell you it applies some condition but doesn't tell you what that condition does. The game doesn't even tell you how your damage works to start with, you just have to click stuff and figure it out. (not that it's complicated - just cumulative based on how many pegs hit / whether you have crit active - but it's hard to be confident whether I understand the implications of various orbs' special abilities since it doesn't really explain anything)  

Shops seem like a complete waste of time since I generally get enough gold per level to buy one orb and upgrade one orb, or upgrade and heal. If I'm lucky and don't just miss all the coins while trying to just hit that dang bomb to deal with the swarm of enemies....  I never have any gold to save. 

This could be a really fun game with a little more polish and less bad RNG consequences, but as it is now it isn't, it's just frustrating. One of the discussions mentioned the game felt like it was built around a microtransaction framework without microtransactions. Given I first saw and demoed the game on my phone, seems likely this is actually accurate.

I'm not a fan of killing slimes, I'm sure nobody is but it's the only bad part of the game. Plus it's canonically self defence! (Referring to the Good Slime relic) 
So if you like Peggle, Goblins, A complete monopoly on all forms of purchases in their Peglin society, or goofy little guys you'll like this game.
TLDR: The game is good and unique.
The gameplay's good, it's pretty much a Peggle rogue-like with deck building.
It has an entirely controllable level of difficulty so no matter if you chose "I'm too young to die" on DOOM (The wrong choice) or master mode on Terraria (The wrong choice) or even if you're a normal person, it'll have something for you.
It has 3 unlockable characters not counting Isa-Peglin, the Balladin, Roundrell and Spinventor.
The base Peglin is a Jack of all trades, you can get most orbs and relics making for the most diversity.
The Balladin is centred around Ballwark aka shield, a Magdalene or tank of the Peglin world.
The Roundrell is like the rogue class, based around debuffs and generally being a nuisance to whatever he's fighting.
The Spinventor is a way to almost force diversity, the orbs you have get stronger if they are one of a kind, but can be not-but useless if you have many of them.
In conclusion: If you have $20, like balls and rouge-likes. Tf you waiting for? Peglin is peak rogue-like design, it can be enjoyed by literally anybody on the face of the Earth. If you want to use strategy use strategy, if you don't want to use strategy, pick up 8 bouldorbs I'm sure it'll work out for you.

where this game really fails is how hard it is to bounce back from failure. weak early games almost never lead to strong end games, and several times it feels like certain enemies/situations are entirely unwinnable based on your orbs/relics you received. additionally, it's incredibly hard to build "dedicated" builds (e.g. balladin/spinfection) since they can be easily stonewalled. your best bet is to just to make something strong across the board so you don't experience any death spirals. ironically, the devs tie unlock progression of new characters to forcing your way through these builds. that part of the game is miserable.

it's a shame because the highs of this game are incredible: pegs being hit in satisfying trickshots, monstrous destruction of enemies on god runs, even after just 6 hours there's always a desire to try another run, and early runs that aren't working can be quickly aborted. it feels like a casino every time i start up a run. the difference is that casinos don't stomp you down and draw it out over an uncomfortably long time.

peglin is a peggle roguelike, and it only succeeds at half of its' genre. it is an unabashed failure of everything that makes roguelikes great (which, with some tuning, i think it can overcome), but reinvents the peggle formula in a way that enticed me enough to buy it after seeing enough god runs on YT, but not to make me happy with my purchase.

EDIT:

forgive me. i was skill issuing hard. the new Spinventor update seems to generally make death spirals less common with a general power increase across the board. unlocking the characters is still kinda miserable but it sorta just happens as you make a very strong build. the only one i had to force was shields and that was done with Fiery Furnace + the orb that makes the shield. poison worked for me by making a bomb build with the bomb poison relic, and the slime one just happened naturally with a few slime upgrades.

game sucks if you're trying to do a dedicated orb build. just pick the powerful stuff in general and go nuts. the classes have a different enough playstyle that's satisfying enough for me. i still think this game is kind of a mess of RNG but at least now it's an enjoyable mess. don't take this game too seriously, just let things happen and it'll probably be fun/lag the hell out of your computer.
