Update:  The game is still in early access, and unfinished, but the devs have added more content. Mostly in the form of new balls and a couple new characters, that add a little bit of diversity. Could still use more. It doesn't quite scratch that gameplay loop itch that makes me want to keep hitting "Play Again" at the end of a rogue like. In time this could be a really fun game, but in its current early access state there is not enough content to justify the cost, even at sale price. I bought the game in a bundle on sale, and 11 hours in I feel like I've seen everything the game has to offer. 

I've won three or four runs now. I feel pretty sure I've seen all of the bosses and combat encounters, and there isn't much variety in them. There is a NG+ mode similar to STS ascensions, as most roguelikes have these days. It's fine, but nothing you haven't seen before. I also feel like I end up in the same builds every run. Attempts at experimenting with synergies or weak balls and items in hopes of hitting "dream" synergies just haven't felt worthwhile. 

Hopefully this will all be more fleshed out later in development, but for now this has the content of a free demo for a $10 game that is being sold for nearly double that.

There is a phrase I saw in another review that I feel sums up the biggest downside of this game:

DEATHS DO NOT FEEL EARNED.

You can get a nearly perfect combination of orbs and relics, yet a few unlucky throws during a battle can make that synergy evaporate in an instant. It doesn't help that the balance of the game is way off, some builds simply suck and others are unbelievably overpowered. The rewards for finding synergies are dubious. You can spend an entire game searching for a combo and never get it, or if you do, it just sucks, and even if it doesn't suck, the aforementioned unearned death could occur. This game design discourages trying new things.

A few pegboards are simply awful, which funnel your thrown orbs into death traps where they do little damage. This is made worse when your refreshes are trapped in difficult-to-reach places where the best you can do is chip away at each individual peg in the way to get to it, all the while doing tiny amounts of damage to enemies who relentlessly chip away at your health. I'm looking at you, Slime boss, Dragon boss, slime+bat fight, etc.

A few specific relics and orbs have hard counters which are impossible to predict. This issue is somewhat limited, but the worst example of this is the Gift That Keeps Giving, a BOSS RELIC, which makes it virtually impossible to defeat the dragon boss on the final stage (whose appearance is up to chance).

ALL of these issues are exacerbated when you play on Cruciball, where the game takes away the little saving grace it has. Some of the time, gaining a Cruciball level will simply increase the overall game difficulty, such as increasing enemy health and damage, which is a good way to amp up the challenge. The rest of the time, however, it severely cripples you by taking away vital game mechanics, such as refreshes, crits, gold, etc. You either get lucky and find an orb or relic to compensate, which has an opportunity cost, or you die miserably. I like that the game has progression and a goal to reach, but Cruciball makes the experience far too unforgiving and unfair. And without progression, the game gets quite stale. The best description for Cruciball is a series of compounding roadblocks that you must spend money (and luck) to remove before you can focus in on building your deck. It's a giant middle finger to people who want to have fun with the game still being replayable.

If you like heavily luck-based games, then Peglin is for you. However, if you've seen the popular YouTube videos of extremely fun or overpowered builds/synergies and want to replicate them on your own, prepare to have your patience tested. Of course, you can always relegate yourself to the custom run sandbox mode, but, in my opinion, where's the accomplishment in that?

I love balls
If someone has told me the solution to improving upon the greatest game of all time, Peggle, was to turn it into a rouglike dungeon crawler, I would have laughed in their face. Yet here we are.

this game has no right being as fun and addicting as it is. the concept sounds so insanely stupid at first, like how could you mix a roguelike dungeon crawler with peggle and make it fun? well they managed to figure it out and god damn do i adore it. 

i was honestly kinda skeptical on whether i was gonna enjoy this game or not considering the fact that i have a hard time coming back to roguelikes, but seeing all the balls bounce around and seeing the attack damage go up and up, then quickly shooting onto the enemies is just so satisfying and it keeps me coming back for more. 

the map is also formatted in a good way, where every time you kill an enemy, get a relic and etc, you have to shoot a ball into the area you wanna go to, which sounds simple enough right? well there are still pegs on the board sometimes that can push you to a different route, and while that sounds inherently negative, i kinda like it because it adds spice to the game. and even if you do fail most of the paths just diverge to themselves anyway.

the actual balls themselves are designed to be fun and used in unique ways which i love. my personal favorite are anything with multiball, which adds multiple balls on the screen, the lightning ball, which destroys multiple pegs at once, and the summoning circle, which puts 3 of whatever ball is up next in your ball ring. 

and finally, there are also upgrades in the game called relics. relics are where the game starts to get good because there are some really overpowered/fun upgrade in here. one of them will give every ball in your deck multiball at the cost of a couple attack, theres one that spawns a squirrel (which is just another ball) after every 40 pegs you hit, and so many more. 

this game is a ton of fun, and i think that the main problem is that there isnt too much content in the game yet. there is absolutely still enough to play and enjoy the game for well over 50 hours, but there is still a lot to be desired here, which is fine because its in early access anyways. 8.5/10

I want to preface this by saying that I have played this game mostly on mobile and have hit Cruciball 8+ (its challenge modifiers, about halfway through) on each of the four characters. 
I enjoy Peglin, I think the game has a great fundamental concept with some interesting mechanics, but I would not recommend this game on PC taking its price into consideration. 

You will be purchasing a heavily unbalanced and frustrating yet cute and sometimes satisfying roguelite. If you enjoy roguelites, you will enjoy Peglin. If you are looking for a polished game that feels fair with every loss/victory, constantly encourages you for trying new strategies, and makes you feel like you're improving your game skill, Peglin is not a game for you. If you feel like trying Peglin's full version, purchase it on a mobile device. It is not worth the price here. 

The Good:
- I like the core concept quite a bit. A Peggle roguelite is just neat, and how its implemented here is also that - it's neat. The physics are consistent enough and many in-game boards are interesting. This is not perfect by any means and certain boards/enemy combinations are downright terrible (Spiders, Dark Encounters, certain Shielded Knights, Slime Elite, and more). But for the majority of boards, they feel interesting.
- Good runs are very satisfying. The rare times where you make things work feel fantastic. There's many intentionally designed synergies between orbs and relics in this game that feel great to use when pulled off. 
- The presentation is very cute. The pixel art is simple but enemies are stylistic and interesting, visual effects are fun and flashy, and all the little sound effects that play with each attack feel great as you build up power. 

The Bad:
- The early game is quite awful. Every single character has a nearly identical starting set of orbs (and two have completely identical sets? I don't understand that one bit) making every early game run equally boring with every character. This is a game where you have to heavily lean into the relics you get if you want a chance to win. But even with this, in the early game, many encounters are complete slogs of you shooting your orb at a refresh peg or bomb over and over while being forced to listen to the damage sound effect constantly. All while the game is at 3x speed. There's no interesting deviation and this 15 minute part of the game feels like you just waiting to start playing. 
- The in-game economy is counter-intuitive. After winning a battle, you have a couple orbs you can purchase, the option to upgrade orbs, or the option to heal. Nearly every run where you feel forced to heal, you've already lost. That option feels like you're being laughed at. Spending money here also stinks, since if you run into a shop, prices are so bloated that you feel unable to influence your run there in any way, shape, or form. Early prices are so steep that you cannot influence your run in any massive way early on. Lategame leaves you with so much money that you just look for a shop, buy every relic, shrug, and move on. It's not fun having to ignore orb after orb, upgrade after upgrade, and then losing to some unfortunate refresh peg spawn.
- Character unlocks take way too long. The unlock prerequisites are downright confusing. I've unlocked every character, and to do so, I had to do specific runs for them over and over to hope I hit some... big "50" number the game wanted me to land at. I didn't win a single one of those runs. This wouldn't really be a big issue to me if the rest of the game was as fun and balanced as I'd hope. 

Peglin struggles from an overall lack of player influence. For many reasons listed above, you dive into a run hoping to get out of the first act so you can start playing. The game makes most decisions for you, although it doesn't feel like that at first. In a sense, the entire game is like a pegboard, shooting your little orb down and hoping for some sense of success. And hey, sometimes it hits. But other times, you're running through "?" rooms denying events that have nothing to do with your run, mashing the fire button hoping for the board to change, or doing the same exact strategy that you won the past 8 times with because, hey, why try anything else if they're all worse?

I do not recommend this game in its current state. However, if the development team focuses mostly on rebalance and absolutely overhauls most of the early game, this could absolutely be a gem. I'm not too stoked there, seeing the developers sell plushes of characters and push out more content on top of deeply flawed systems. The game is in early access and I see its potential, but either play it on mobile or hold off on your purchase for now.

This game is poorly balanced. 

1. New runs take a long time before they start being fun. Early pegboards and orb options make the gameplay slow and unfun and it kills my desire to play again.
2. The RNG on enemy encounters is a little too random. Some runs you'll cruise from chest to chest and stroll up to the boss. Other runs you'll get several encounters with a ton of enemies each. In the case of the latter, it will often end a run before you can really even get going (which means back to the slow, boring first area.)
3. There is no sense of progression. It feels very difficult (and up to chance) to achieve any of the character unlocks, and otherwise there's no way to start with better starting orbs, fast-track through the boring first area, or get some other kind of consistent character improvement.
4. Bosses that spawn in the same area are not as weak/strong as others meaning sometimes you'll get the boss you can actually hope to beat, and other times you're facing something with way too much health and way too much damage or that can only occasionally be damaged.
5. I strongly dislike the "lanes" mechanic where you can only attack the enemy closest to you and everything else is protected by the meat shields up front. Especially the tree enemies that turn into logs and block attacks after they die. It is not a tricky mechanic to play around--it just means your next couple of turns will ultimately be pointless (unless you are lucky enough to draw the right orb at the right time.)
6. Many of the orbs in the game are nearly useless unless you happen to get the perfect combo of orbs over  your playthrough. It feels less like the game is pushing you to step outside of your comfort zone and try fun new playstyles, and more like you are constantly just doing the best you can with a combination of orbs that don't complement each other.
7. I am ALWAYS out of gold when I get to a shop. Shop tiles should be removed, and you should be able to visit the shop between each encounter. Instead of just 3 meager orb options, upgrading, and healing, you could get more orb and relic variety to be able to actually have some slight control over your playthrough. 
8. The appeal of these games (to me) is the satisfaction of seeing the ball go on some crazy never-ending combo down the pegboard. It seems like most of the pegboards in this game are designed to inhibit players from hitting the perfect angle to get a crazy combo, or they'll just be schockingly empty. I understand designing them to be challenging, but a lot of the design philosophy at play seems to be "funnel(s) for the ball to get sucked into."

This game needs to give more ability to the player to make you feel capable and let you actually have fun. It's like a rhythm game where you only have to play one note a second and if you try to go crazy and do something cool, you'll just be penalized. You are too limited in what you can and can't do when you're already relying on some unrealistic and unpredictable plinko physics to try and fight battles. The player's resources are spread far too thin between how little gold is received through the course of normal play and how much gold you must funnel into new orbs and upgrading orbs in order to have any hope of facing a boss, not to mention any gold you might find yourself having to pay to heal since there are so few other ways to meaningfully regain health. 

My experience with the game so far is that even on my best runs, I feel like there was nothing I could have done to avoid dying at the end. It doesn't feel like something I can get better at and learn to have an edge to counter poor RNG luck, it just feels like I get really invested in runs only to lose because the game decided it was time, which is very frustrating.

This game is fun until you get to the end game levels of difficulty. I feel like you get to a point where it doesn't matter how much skill you have. You just win or lose on pure RNG. Did I get a relic/ orb that can actually beat a boss in the first couple levels? No? Oh well. Hey you wanted to go on the obviously good path that has a bunch of treasure? Nah, have fun misnavigating 10 times in a row. Gee I can only get 1 relic no matter what path I take. I hope it's good. NOPE. Hey, got a good build going on and there's an elite you wanna kill? Lets have the refresh peg spawn in the worst spot humanly possible so that you have to throw 4 orbs doing 3 damage just so you can refresh a board to actually do damage. Oh you're actually starting to figure out the game and get further up the cruciball ladder (levels of difficulty are called cruciballs)? Welp here's 5 more cruciball debuffs to your game that make it absolutely brutal even with a good build.  OH you got a fun bomb build going? WELL super sapper is your last boss so have fun dying because you exist. Don't have any orbs or relics that let you take out a bunch of pegs in one shot? Here comes the Dragon where you helplessly bounce off the side of the mountain and do 50 damage to a 15k health pool. The refresh you need? Yea that's in the bottom of the middle of the mountain that you'll never hit without special abilities or orbs that never showed up in your run because of RNG. NGL, I bought this game once, got pissed off by the RNG and refunded it, but watching other people play it I gave it another chance. And yea, if you don't care about losing 10 times in a row to things that aren't your fault at all, this game is a 10/10. But holy nutballs batman will this game make you want to gouge your eyes out with a rusty melon baller if you want any modicum of control over what happens after you click fire. It's already super RNG in the fact that it's a pachinko rogue like; Why do I have to get d!cked by map travel, crap peg spawns (crits, refresh, etc), orb selection, relic selection, end bosses that completely counter certain builds that you could never know they're coming until it's too late, and super brutal difficulty modifiers? They've added so many different orbs and relics alone into the game that just getting a build that does one thing going before act 2 is pretty hard. Especially when you have 4-5 orbs that are useless (unless you decide to keep all the stones and get god like RNG)(ASSUMING YOU EVEN GET THE OPTION TO REMOVE ANY OF THEM BECAUSE RNG). All in all, it just feels really bad the more you play this game. If you want fun, never go past like cruciball 3 or pray to RNGesus for a good run. Hopefully they change the game up in some ways with some serious quality of life changes. Two play-hours. First, this isn't a game. This is Pinball. Pinball is not a game.
 I bought this game based on the name. I assumed it was a clone of Peggle, which I enjoyed. It is such a clone. But it doesn't have whatever "X" factor Peggle had that got me to spend a couple hundred hours of playtime on it. 
The vast majority of my time was watching my ball bounce around on the screen. You fire your ball once, then it will be doing it's thing for 5-10 minutes. Then you fire again. It does a good job of providing a catalog of balls with interesting effects, and relics that change the way the game works. 
It's not terrible, but you have to already be into pinball. If you go to the casino for the slots, this might be a good choice for you. It's very passive. Just watch the pretty flashing lights.

They brought back peggle, and this time it has a kind of RPG meets roguelite theme. It's very cute and fun but short.

Gameplay is basically peggle but each orb has different mechanics for how it interacts with the pegs, and you accumulate new orbs as you play or level up existing orbs to become more powerful. At the same time enemies will constantly be approaching along the top of the screen, you deal damage with each peg hit based on the strength / features of the orb and you take damage if the enemies reach you.

It's a clever and simple design that's very easy to pick up and addicting to play. The only downside is that there's so little content. More is slowly getting added but because of how the game is built it's easy to experience everything quickly. A good idea with slightly too little substance at the moment, but a great starting point.

Camera shake is used heavily and there is no way to turn it off.

If you are hoping for a roguelike Peggle, this isn't it. The physics on the balls makes for very lackluster shots. Every bounce the ball gets extremely heavier to make sure more bounces are less likely. The levels are sometimes okay, but most of the themed levels are just designed to look like something and are not well thought out level designs for a Peggle-like experience. Peggle has various mechanics that make the game feel better to play and makes it more exciting to hit a lot of pegs in one shot.

Choosing where to go on the map requires shooting a ball into a hole with pegs blocking them in various ways, but that will often mean you don't get a choice in where you go. On top of that, there is often a fire pit hole where you will just take damage if the ball goes into it. Both of these mechanics are just anti-fun.

Random encounters will often have "take damage" on all possible choices. If you have too low of health, choosing any of said options will just straight up kill you and end the run.

Ranged enemies shoot you every shot and is incredibly unfair.

There's a small number of ball types that are fun, but the rest are not.

After every fight you can choose to get a new ball, upgrade a ball, or heal. All of these options cost money though. If you have no money, you get nothing for beating a level and it feels terrible. There is a shop you can visit on the map that lets you buy balls or remove a ball, but the cost of everything is expensive, so you will rarely be able to buy anything. You are likely to buy a ball or upgrade a ball every time you are able to after a fight, so you rarely will have money for the shop. Healing and upgrading could stay as a cost after fights, but the balls should be free. The shop could also offer healing and upgrading at a reduced price.

Overall, the many, many games I've tried of this have not even remotely come close to reaching the level of fun I have had in Peggle games. The game is just designed to not be fun.

Short version: Yes, this game is fun and worth playing if you are a fan of deckbuilders. It's unusual in the genre because of it's Peggle setting, but that adds some charm to the game, and frankly makes it less RNG and more execution-dependent than most deckbuilders, which in my eyes gives it more longevity. It's simple, polished, has a surprising amount of run variety, and will give you your money's worth.

Long version: Peggle is a very simple and straightforward game in almost every sense. It's easy to pick up and understand, it has simple rules and mechanics that are quickly understood, the artstyle is simple and low-demand (good.) It offers little beyond what it says on the cover: a deckbuilder roguelike crossed with Peggle. Weird idea, but it honestly works surprisingly well. Your 'deck' is the orbs you use to pop pegs, and they come in a wide variety of effects and even shapes. This variety is what differentiates your runs, for the most part; there's only so many different stage layouts per level, so eventually you will have seen every enemy combination, elite, and boss, and figured out more or less how to play the board itself. But adapting it to the orbs you have in question? That's where the game's longevity lies, because depending on what orbs you are offered and which ones you choose, you can have radically different playstyles. It's not always about clearing as much of the board as possible, and some orbs interact directly with the board in strange and novel ways.

So how is all of this executed? Frankly Peglin is very polished. For the most part, the mechanics are well-thought out, well-rounded, and clearly a lot of care has been put into making a large amount of playstyles both fun and viable. Bugs are very few and far between, and the devs have been good about quickly addressing them. Aesthetically, the game is really simple but that works out in it's favor; the visual style is consistent and fun, a lot of creativity has been put into the details of making almost every orb have wordplay of some sort, and the soundtrack is hardly amazing or memorable, but it's never annoying or disruptive, easily above average.

The devs are very responsive; early in the development cycle, I sent a letter detailing some findings about the game, and was more than pleased to get an answer that was clearly not a canned HR letter about appreciating support; instead the developer addressed several points of the feedback and hinted at how they might be resolved in future patches (and they were indeed.) That's a rare gem. Since then, updates have not been frequent but they have been of consistently high quality and added quite a lot of content to the game.

So are there any downsides? Yes, two major ones to my taste. Firstly, some encounters are in my opinion poorly thought out and cause unnecessary frustration. The most egregious example of this is the third level featuring some stages with portals on the board that cause your shots to gravitate towards them. Now, at times this allows for some clever play with curveballs, but most of the time, it takes away one of the core components of the game, which is controlling your shots and trying to make sure they hit what you want to hit, when you want it hit, and instead add a heavy dose of randomness to your shots (technically, portals are not random, and in theory you could perfectly calculate every impact of four portals on your shot at any point, but if you seriously try to claim that you could do just that, I'm calling you a liar.) Taking control away from the player when in all other cases it's heavily rewarded, does not feel good.

The second, and much more damning in my eyes, is the difficulty scaling. Like any roguelike and especially deckbuilder, this game has NG+ levels, the equivalent of say Ascension levels in Slay the Spire. In this game they're called Cruciball levels. And I have to admit, they embody the worst of difficulty design in deckbuilders in my eyes, particularly egregious in this game. At first it is simply a challenge, but rather quickly the Cruciball levels start taking so much power away from the player that they make certain builds and playstyles simply mathematically unfeasible. It gets to the point where each playthrough feels less like a test of skill and decision-making and more an RNG grind fest of resetting chests and elite fights until you get the relics that would make up for how terrible your starting deck, health, and gold have become. Now, take this with at least some salt, I am hardly amazing at the game by any stretch of the imagination. But I did give all of this a fair shot, I got up to Cruciball 15 (the maximum currently available,) but frankly about 5 of those Cruciball levels were forced. I did not particularly enjoy getting through them because every game felt like I was fishing for very specific things, otherwise I was at the mercy of a single piece of RNG going wrong on any given stage for 30+ stages (the crit only spawned in places you can't reach? Too bad, it's mathematically impossible to kill this elite before he removes 80% of your health.) On early levels, it takes a serious streak of bad luck to end your run. With the limitations each new Cruciball level after around 7 or 8 imposes, it could just take a single instance of bad luck which makes the game so RNG-dependent that it is no longer fun. More importantly, the game starts removing a lot of the mechanics that so much thought went into. You just get to play around and enjoy the variety the game has to offer a lot less, because you get so much less resources and so much less leeway. This all to me adds up to tedium and frustration, not difficulty. It's a shame because this game format offers a lot of ways of creatively adding difficulty, such as making individual encounters more intricate with different enemy types, debuffs, etc, but instead the chosen path is letting the player do a lot less.

I am probably being unfair to the game by dedicating so much text to the very few negative points. I truly think the game is a lot of fun despite the difficulties being flawed. Even if you only do a few playthroughs of each character's different builds, and go up the first few Cruciball levels, which feel challenging but not crippling, the game still offers a lot of hours. The core loop is really satisfying, the variety is fun and engaging, and player ability matters much more than RNG. Peglin is definitely worth the price IF you are already a fan of deckbuilders. Even if you aren't, it's quite a good place to start, and I would strongly recommend this game's base difficulty and the first few levels to anyone looking for a good, light game to pass the time with. My own playtime will very likely increase, especially with new updates, and I hope that the development team continues to be as creative and polished into the future.

I played the demo, wasn't totally sure, but picked up the full game when it dropped. Really glad I did - the game is fairly extensive, full of charm, and has a ton of fun relics and balls to get. What I really like is how responsive the devs have been, regularly patching to help improve balance, clarify descriptions, and add new items and characters. Peglin has a few oddities - the way the map pans when you start in particular is just kind of awkward - but it's a fun game with almost always something new to discover or try.

In terms of gameplay it mixes plinko/pachinko/bagatelle with Break Out mechanics, all set in a roguelike setting. In a lot of ways it reminds me a bit of Slay the Spire, especially the way the map is set up. The devs really seem to understand what they're doing here, even when things aren't perfectly smooth there's a clear synergy in gameplay mechanics. It's even possible to get different core mechanics to work with you, if you know what you're doing, so you can hedge more if you like. Anyways, ton of fun, really good game.

OK, well, it's pretty boring.  There is not a very meaningful sense of being able to do anything strategic turn-to-turn, other than discarding a crappy orb and aiming for your first peg, or first+second if you get a unicorn horn.  Beyond that, it's just chaos - you're basically rolling dice every turn.  Which means you should pick 'value' orbs like multiballs and magnet balls that do well in most situations.  There's not a big sense of speccing into a specialized build each run like you might have with StS or similar.  It also bugs me that a lot of the orbs are basically just pebbles that do something extra on fire, like apply poison or shield, which leans away from the concept of having cool interactions with the peg board rather than towards it.  The music is pretty stale, encounter variety sucks, and metaprogression is limited to a few character unlocks and arbitrary challenge upgrades.  And the puns are cringe, sorry.

But really the big thing is the passivity on the part of the player during fights, I think something needs to change fundamentally with how the player interacts with/modifies/influences the peg board while balls are in motion to make the game feel more participatory and less like an autobattler.

[h1]Positives:[/h1]
- Peglin is very fun, and (to my knowledge) a very original concept too
- Peglin is also a very re-playable game
- The game also has very little to no bugs

[h1]Negatives:[/h1]
- Although very re-playable, there lacks something to reward the player after a run, in some games this can be as simple as a high score being saved while in others it's something more like cosmetic, there doesn't seem to be anything like this in Peglin, making the hours spent a little less rewarding to the player.

[h1]The Negatives No Longer Apply Much[/h1]
The Cruciball mode now gives something to work towards, in addition to the newly added classes, (although the classes don't take very long to get)

[h1]==============[/h1]
Overall though, I definitely would recommend this game and it's clear that a lot of effort is being put into it.

The peg layout on nearly every map is piss poor. It's so easy to not get any value in a turn just because there's such a lack of pegs and/or the pegs are placed in a way where your ball will just fall between the cracks. The game requires you get mega value from every shot, and it's simply impossible 90% of the time

Updates have been nice, adding much needed variety to the game, but the replay-ability just isn't there. The classes are hidden behind an unfair unlock requirement, and even when you do get then they dont change the way the game plays in any meaningful way.

you'd also expect the pegs to be circular, this is false. They are the shape portrayed, outlined exactly as such. you will notice that means they are more like squares with flat ends and a wavy jagged bit on the sides. This makes planning a shot impossible, your balls will take a life of their own and jet off into the abyss constantly.

Fun roguelike game. The gameplay is pachinko / peggle (the trailer is pretty accurate for the gameplay), so if this sounds fun to you you'll probably love the game, and if this sounds boring you'll probably find the game boring and/or pointless.

One major distinction between Peglin and other roguelikes is that there are very few unlocks: whereas in most games you have to unlock the vast majority of your items, in Peglin you start with every orb and passive item unlocked. The only unlocks are the other characters and higher difficulty levels for each character. For some people this is a turn-off, but I like that there is no pressure to play characters I do not like in the game.

There's also the issue of the balls you'll be firing. A lot of them are just meh. Overall, I think I'd rather be playing Peggle.

A very fun game with loads of potential and heavy replayability. As of the time of writing the game only has 3 main characters to use (two of which have to be unlocked), a cruciball mode which is unlocked after your first successful run which just makes the game slightly harder, and only 3 areas to play through. There are quite a few different items and powered pinballs to find and use each run, however the drop pools are fairly consistent and there isn't a whole lot of variation between runs and I found that i kept coming back to the same few pinballs every run as some of them are useless if you don't have the right item/setup. Overall runs last about 30ish minutes if you're going slow or trying to get as many fights/encounters as possible, good for casual play and streamers who want to keep things light. 

Overall, the game is great and if you love Peggle you'll really enjoy this game, maybe wait for a few updates (or a sale) before buying though as I don't think there is enough content in the game to justify the price, especially since the demo gives you a 3rd of the game for free.

Spicy black bean Tacos

if you're looking for review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding Tacos recipe you've come to the right place,

ingredients

1 tbsp vegetable oil
3 garlic cloves, chopped
3 x 400g cans black beans, drained and rinsed
3 tbsp cider vinegar
1 Â½ tbsp honey
1 Â½ tbsp smoked paprika
1 Â½ tbsp ground cumin

For the guacamole

1 small garlic clove
2 tbsp roughly chopped coriander
1 green chilli, sliced
2 avocados, halved and stoned
juice 1 lime

For the salsa

110g pack pomegranate seeds
1 green chilli, finely diced
1small white onion, finely diced
small handful fresh coriander, chopped


To serve

8-12 corn or flour tortillas
chipotle or other hot sauce
soured cream or coconut yogurt


Directions

STEP 1
In a large frying pan, heat the oil and add the garlic. Fry until golden, then add the beans. Pour in the cider vinegar, honey and spices along with 1 tsp or more of salt, to taste. Cook until warmed through, crushing gently with the back of your wooden spoon, then set aside.

STEP 2
The best way to make the guacamole is with a large stone pestle and mortar, but you can use a medium bowl and a flat-ended rolling pin instead. Crush the garlic, coriander and chilli into a rough paste. Scoop in the avocado with a little salt and crush roughly â€“ you want it chunky, not smooth. Squeeze in the lime juice and set aside.

STEP 3
Mix the salsa ingredients in a small bowl. Heat a griddle pan or steamer and quickly griddle the tortillas or steam a stack of them to warm up. Reheat the bean mixture.

STEP 4
To serve, put 1-2 heaped tbsp of beans on a tortilla. Top with a big spoonful of guacamole and some salsa, hot sauce and a dollop of soured cream or yogurt

Peglin is a very addicting rougelike pachinko game that combines Peggle, Deckbuilding games, and Puzzles & Dragons all in one. Not every seed is meant to be winnable, but it is still extremely addicting nonetheless.

There's a few builds that you can set up throughout the playthrough. There's builds centering around: poisoning the enemy, dealing crit damage, utilizing a very overpowered orb to deal extreme amounts of damage, building defense, stacking buffs, and lots of double edged sword relics that can spice up the run. I would love to say that all of these builds are pretty fairly balanced, but I've ran into a few of the builds where even if I had the build pretty dialed in, I still found the game way too difficult and unfair. 

The two biggest examples of the games sheer lack of balance is the defensive builds and the crit builds. The defensive build in particular suffers from not having any reliable way of building up defense. The best orb is only 1 per every 4 pegs hit, which is pitiful on a lot of stages where you're getting hit multiple times per turn. It is made much worse that the tank builds give you no way of dealing strong damage; which is understandable, but you can't tank very well so it's a pain. The crit builds just suffer from not having a super reliable way of getting crits. You have to get way luckier with this build compared to others to take advantage of this build. It's kind of frustrating.

I feel like they could just introduce more orbs dealing with crit damage and then buff all the defensive orbs; then it'd be more balanced. The class that is centered around defense is so hard to unlock. You have to get 100 defense to get it, and the most I've gotten is around 50. It's really annoying.

Despite all this; I am very addicted to this game. It's extremely fun, and the builds that are actually good, are super fun to play with. I just hope they balance this game out more, and we maybe expand on certain builds that deal with buffs.

**Update---June 17, 2023**
I've gone back and played the game again after the latest update. I do believe we have received quite a bit in the way of even more peg upgrades, status effects, and RNG in some of the levels. I'm changing my review to a slight positive for the time being, but I'd really like to make this a strong positive. What we need now is more variation in enemy types, new enemies, a bigger lineup of potential end-level bosses (think maybe 5 would be good enough for each level,) and some variation in each enemy's HP.  Also, more achievements would be nice, if we can come up with some clever ones that aren't the run-of-the-mill "checkmark" type achievements.

P.S.--I've read some notes in previous reviews that you guys weren't going to add any new areas. Are you sure that's the right move? I would think four areas, perhaps even five, would seem more well-rounded and about the right amount of time to get through the game. Three areas may be a couple too few for the price point, and again, replayability is a HUGE factor in a roguelike's potential and popularity. Thanks for listening.

Thanks for all your hard work devs, we're going in the right direction.
(Original Review Below)

This is my first negative review. That being said, this is not a hard negative, but more like a slight thumbs-down.

Peglin has many positives to point towards---wonderful artwork, a catchy soundtrack, and an overall spirit of lighthearted fun.

However, there are several things related to the gameplay itself that leave more to be desired at this point in time. While the game is still in early access, I do leave Peglin open to changing the rating to a recommended status after more polish and content have gone into the game.

Currently, I really enjoy the Peggle-esque nature of the games rules and content. Peglin also adds roguelike elements into gameplay during every run, so you can start off with performance-boosting perks like adding bonus damage to pegs you hit, adding Overflow damage to your arsenal, (overflow means damage doesn't just affect one enemy at a time, but additional ones in the lineup) among many other relics that make each of your runs through the forest and castle unique.

The feeling I'm left with after ending a run in Peglin is one of not wanting to go back and try again, and I'm not quite sure why that is. The game does not have an addicting gameplay loop for me, and it could come down to several factors: one, there is not enough enemy variation and board layout variation in the levels to create a sense of RNG. I would think having maybe three different potential board layouts for each enemy encounter should be something to add. As it stands right now, when you get a specific loadout of enemies, they are exactly the same each time. Enemies also always have the same amount of HP, so you know what you're getting into. I feel this is too predictable, and feel like there should be a percentage range variation on each enemy you come across. For example, if a typical slime has an HP of 50, perhaps there should be a reasonable variation in those enemies HP, anywhere from 25 HP to 75 HP. Sometimes adding this variation can make the game slightly easier or slightly more difficult. It also adds to the RNG feeling of the game, and slight unpredictability which would give me a feeling of "oh well maybe I'll get lucky this run."  The way the game plays right now, you just don't feel that.

There's a few unrealistic animations in the game, but one that bothers me the most is the bomb mechanic. You can literally hit two bombs on a board in the same turn, but the bombs always land in the same place on the battlefield and they always do the same amount of damage. At least make the bombs centered around the enemies in the lineup so it looks a bit more realistic. This is a very minor nitpick from a gameplay perspective, but it is a glaring issue.

The Slime boss in the game is unnecessarily overpowered and is almost completely a surefire way to end a run. These types of issues crop up and can cause balancing issues for the player. A well-polished RNG roguelike game should have a feeling of incremental progression, where the difficulty ramps up gradually, with a few unknowns to keep you on your toes. But instead of being excited or a bit apprehensive about a boss battle, your immediate thought is, "well, here's the Slime boss. Guess this run is over."  This is something that should never happen in a roguelike.

I would also appreciate more enemy variation. We have a lot of orbs (attack weapons) in the game right now and I feel like we're doing a good job there. However, new status effects, new enemies, new attack patterns, and overall just a bit more randomization in the way the enemies behave would make this feel a lot more polished.

As it stands right now, I cannot recommend the game for anyone who is looking to get a bunch of playtime out of it, as quite frankly, it's just not addictive enough--and an addicting gameplay loop is a hallmark of this genre.

Keep up the hard work, devs. I'll be watching the game as it progresses, and if satisfied with such progression, I shall change my recommendation.

-GameJudgeJames-

I really wanted to write a joke review of this game but I can't because it needs to be said that this game is actually the  most RNG based roguelike i think i have ever seen. Not in a good way.

You can't try to get a certain build as well as you can in other roguelikes eg Slay The Spire, and it's not like you can work with what you have as well as in other roguelikes eg BoI, Gungeon. Each of the orbs you are offered do fun and unique things, sure, but they are severly unbalanced in terms of power. Same goes for the relics you pick up. You can pick up a relic at the start of the game that  genuinely causes your run to be lost on the first turn of the last fight. 

Plus, the game has 2 unlockable characters. This would be good, if it didnt take hours of specifically trying to get them. The conditions you have to meet to unlock them arent things you would just end up doing in a normal run, you have to go out of your way to do a build that probably wont win the run, and hope along the way you dont get killed and get the right relics or orbs to complete them. The fact that less than 10% of players have one and about 5% have the other is just poor game design. There isnt even a real reward for unlocking them either, the character choice barely change how the run plays out. There are no real unique mechanics for each character, no unique orbs, no unique relics. 

The game isnt inherently awful by any means, it's fun and cute and its definitely unique, and has huge potential to be really fun, but it just falls flat and feels really empty after playing over 2 hours. Hopefully once it's out of early access it gets improved and is rebalanced with more content, otherwise it just wont be worth it. 

TL;DR : Fun enough game for a few hours. Peggle and Slay the Spire combined, except anything StS did this does worse.

(Edit 6/17/2023):
After coming back to Peglin, I can safely say that the developers have completely fumbled the bag on this game. There is a lot of new content in the form of new balls, boards, items, and a couple new bosses, but very few actually improve the game's replayability and fun. Spinfection is a pretty cool mechanic, but aside from that, none of the items in this game synergize well with eachother other than the bomb upgrades. Most runs boil down to hoping that you get the bomb upgrades, and hoping that the bosses you get have a lot of bombs on their boards. This game is not fun, and especially not worth the price that the developers charge. Just get peggle deluxe

This game feels like it is developed by someone who doesn't play it.

1. You almost have to use cheat engine or something to speed up the game because otherwise you'll die of boredom while waiting for the ball to bounce between pegs and waiting for the damage animations to hit the enemies. 2x speed is what normal should be at, normal feels like the game speed was actually cut in half. 3x speed doesn't feel normal, but definitely makes the game fun if you already know how to play. 5x or 6x speed is useful for trying out builds.

2. The maps in the forest area are drastically different than the other areas in two horrible ways. A: they have barely any pegs which makes them really boring and if RNG hates you, you spend most of your turns hitting one or two pegs trying to get to the reset peg and sometimes depending on your progress, its better to just restart the run. Anything where the best way to play the game even casually you have just restart runs so often is bad (might as well just make a game where you infinitely go between menus if that is the goal). B: they have barely any pegs and if you get a bad setup when starting the game, might as well just restart because if you can't do something like clear bombs on command, you'll just die anyways.

3. More applies to the castle and beyond. Navigation is an illusion of choice. Unless you've cleared most of the pegs by the end of the round and never refreshed the board, you'll have a better chance flipping a coin than you will being able to choose your path. If you have a bomb build and by the end of the battles always have a lot of bombs on the board, don't even try to decide where you're going, you'll only be disappointed.

These are the 3 most common complaints I've had while playing but there are plenty more that I'd likely be reminded of after just a few games.

Playing with mods adds a ton of fun, but I'm left confused and frustrated about why the game seems to work against the player for no reason other than to be annoying. I played to the end a few times without mods before trying the game with mods and I wish I played with mods from the beginning. The problems weren't even "early access" problems, they were game design problems. The mods were the only thing making this game playable without getting unnecessarily frustrated at bad game design choices and if that's the case, I wish the mod developers were developing the game instead.

It's fun until you make the mistake of believing you need to challenge yourself with Cruciball ranks. 

Made it to Cruciball 11 before realizing I was only winning 1/20 games because of bomb build (I really wanted to believe this game was going somewhere).

I'm trying to like this game but it's yet another rougelike where the developer misunderstand what people like about rougelikes. People like them because they are hard and also have replayability due to the randomness. Rougelikes where you literally can't win without lucking into what feels like an OP build are stupid. If you got a run once in awhile that was impossible to win, that's one thing but if it's literally impossible to win most runs through no fault of your own, it's a bad game. Isaac is one of the most popular roguelikes for a reason, you can win in that game no matter how bad your run is if you're skilled enough. I don't want a game where I feel like I have my best build ever and it's somehow mathmatically not doing enough damage to beat the boss before I die.

When I first started playing Peglin, there were about 2 viable strategies. One and a half, really, since if you didn't use bombs, you were shooting yourself in the foot.

I remember hearing some news from the devs pretty early on in its life cycle, where they outlined their desire to turn it into a high-skill Spirelike game, where they kept careful track of balance. I was disappointed to hear that at the time, since the Pachinko mechanic that the entire system is built around is not nearly as manipulable as something like a deck of cards, and I was worried that they were going to miss out on the inherent fun of Peggle's mechanics for the sake of some nebulous "balance" that was never going to be terribly possible to achieve.

Whether it was a change of artistic direction, or me misunderstanding the quote, I'm overjoyed to say that that is NOT what this game has become. I'm incredibly impressed at the amount of content Peglin has these days, from new characters to new bosses, to dozens upon dozens of orbs, each offering unique playstyles that you can mix and match. The core mechanic remains fun, and important, but has become more manipulable than it used to be, thanks to the addition of things the like electropegnet, morbid, or the concentrication. The game has fully retained its charm though the incessant use of spherical puns, cutesy art, and has an added challenge system for those brave enough to face down Cruciball 15. Personally, I'm still working on the Roundrel and Balladin's ascensions, and their identities are JUST distinct enough to keep it interesting, particularly the Roundrel.

I truly love this game, but it's not perfect. I think my biggest gripe would be how short it remains. Despite all they've added to the game, it still rigidly clings to the three-act structure popularized by Slay the Spire. As with all rogue-likes, I think the best fun you can have in this game is exploring combos and finding ways to break the game, which, while possible, usually only comes online maybe halfway through Act III. The most prevalent thought I tend to have after playing a game of Peglin is "I wish I could keep going with this." The announcement of the dragon boss excited me, since I thought it heralded the addition of an Act IV, but sadly, it was just an additional third act boss. Say what you will about the mechanics of Backpack Hero, but its loop system is incredible, using old locations and enemies, but ramping up the challenge SIGNIFICANTLY. I'd love to see something like that Peglin. As it stands, it's still an excellent game.

I really enjoy this game as you can see from my playtime, but I can't recommend it. The game has alot going for it on the surface but in reality that's just not the case.

The game's severally suffers from being in early access. It's a rougelike with little replay-ability which in my opinion is its biggest sin, and the base game can be beat in less than an hour, and you can probably experience all the enemies and bosses in 2.

Another gripe is the gameplay itself. They have a whole lot fancy effects with the orbs and the relics that seem to be unique and cool but they all end up doing very similar things and leads to no real build crafting and without that you're left with peggle with extra vfx. I will admit some of the orbs are pretty fun to use but they are a very small few in a sea of dull unoriginal power ups you would see in a similar game. In the end you'll probably end up going into every run looking for the same orbs and relics as only a few are fun to use.

The game updates very slow as to be expected from a small team so there's no ill will there, but the amount of content added with each update tends to be able to be experienced all in a fresh run, so you are looking at a good 20 minutes of new content on every release. I thought this wouldn't be the case with the huge update that just happened, but sadly it didn't live up to the hype they were giving off.
 
My last gripe is the price. As the game currently is I'd say it isn't worth it and I feel it'll never be worth the $20 dollar price, as the dev has said they won't be adding any new areas so the game will have a total of 3 areas and the content they add to the game is very minuscule compared to other games out there with similar price ranges. 

In conclusion the game has a solid core and some good ideas behind it, but sadly they don't live up to what they could be and end up being dull and frustrating due to the fact you know they could do better. Maybe one day the game will be fully released and I can come back and change my review, and I'll gladly do it if the game becomes the game I know it can be. Until that day I can't recommend this game as someone who's been playing since the beta.

Pros:
Goblin Protag
Adorable character design and art
Cool sound effects.

Cons:
Bad gameplay. Like a lot of roguelikes, RNG is super important. Almost too important, as unlike other roughlikes, you cannot get any bonuses to swing it more in your favor. Your Peglin run will easily be decided for you within your first few rooms. The adding of new orbs and events does not help if you want to 'progress'. Progress in this case is The Crciball which only makes the game harder, not easier. Playing with it will result in your deck be just made entirely of stones, and with the changes to shops, removing them will not be easy. Some encounters upon starting the game can result in death, no matter what you do, depending entirely on rng. It's just very punishing. If you find being hit with a club entertaining, then you'll love the current game a ton of fun.

Low Replay-Value. You will get bored fast. If you plan on collecting all the things, unlocking the classes, and maxing the Crciball, you won't be experiencing anything unique. You'll come across the same boards all the time. The enemies only do a handful of things. Some are unique but that's only in the last stage. Otherwise, there's just three types. "Melee" which walk towards you one block at a time, "Ranged" which will stand still and just shoot you every turn (or every other turn), and "Flyers" which move two spaces towards you, and have the ability to fly over their slower counter parts. The bosses for each zone are always the same. There's only 4 zones. There's like 3 miniboss encounters per zone, one of which is unique/interesting, the other two are just melee or ranged enemies that do more damage. There's no surprises, no draw to keep playing.

Wait for this game to go on sale. It's quite fun for a while, but the content is limited and each update seems to make the game more overpowered. The requirements to unlock other characters is totally unreasonable unless you're lucky enough to exploit the game.

Peglin is currently my go-to "mindlessly waiting on other stuff" or "on a conference call for work" game (kind of like how the Peggle WoW addon was back in the day while you were waiting on.. being able to do something fun). What you see is what you get. As with all Steam games, catch it on a good sale while you neglect everything else in your library (that you haven't completed because you get caught up in side quests before losing interest/burning out or just don't feel like playing at the moment).

Once you get into the higher levels of Cruciball (I'm "casually" currently on 13) it feels like it takes an absolute miracle to get through it (i.e. you just can't possibly do enough damage to bosses and sometimes mid-bosses to kill them), so I'm not sure how well everything scales in what I suppose is the end-game; while it shouldn't be easy, I wish you had more control over the direction your run-through is going beyond just reloading the save to cheese your Shop and Chest drops while you pray for an Orboros ? node early on. I also wish the other recently released classes were available to play on Cruciball, but I understand the tuning and balance might not be quite there yet.

I've certainly gotten my money's worth, so this is positive - and my kids like doing runs every now and then when they are also waiting on something better to come around - but that probably just ages me a little bit more than it reflects on the simple pleasure this game provides when things go right.

I'm so glad I took a chance on this game.  It doesn't go on sale for much off but I wanted to try it out so bad I caved in, and it's awesome!  I can't stop playing this game.  I play it several times a day.  I hear the music in my head all day.

This is a game that you replay many times, not one of those games you only play once.  So if you don't like playing the same thing only randomized so it's different each time you play, then this game might not be your cup of tea.  But for fans of games with high replayability factor it's a no brainer.

So what's this game about?  Well, have you ever played Peggle by Pogo Games?  This is kinda the same thing only the amount of pegs you hit determines how much damage you deal out to the enemies above.  First, there's no real story though I imagine a little Peglin on an adventure and he starts in the Forest.  There is a layout of pathways between 3 different icons: pirate-looking skull & crossbones which means a battle, Question Mark which means some kind of random scenario like "You come upon a large tree with something in a hole in the tree.  Do you reach your hand in? (take 8 damage) or Shake the tree, or Leave? " and you choose one of those options, the third icon is a large G enclosed in a circle which stands for the Store, where you can purchase randomized selection of balls and relics.  Stores can sometimes make or break your game.  I plan my route and try to get to the stores, if I have money that is.

Battles consist of a special arrangement of pegs (not randomized but always the same for certain enemies) that you aim your balls at and hope it bounces around and hits lots of pegs before dropping down into the abyss.  Each ball has different attack numbers.  There's regular attack and then crit. attack.  Most balls also do something else, like attacks all enemies or can attack any enemy (choose before loosing the ball) instead of the default: the one that's closest to you.

There are 3 areas: The Forest, The Castle, and ...I think it's called the Mines.  There's about 20 or so places (I'm guesstimating, I should really count one of these days) to move to in each one.  At the end of each area there is a boss.  In the Castle there are two bosses that it chooses from and 3 different bosses to choose from in the Mines.   Some of the bosses are harder than others (the Dragon!).  

Once you beat the game you go into game+ where you have unlocked the Cruciball Lv. 1, and Custom Game where you can choose which relics and balls you start with, though you don't get any achievements when playing a custom game, nor can you unlock the two extra characters.  Yes, there are two unlockable characters!  And who knows what the Devs will add to the game next.  They just did an update and added new balls, relics, and enemies.

Music is great.  There are different tunes for each area and battles have their own music.  It's got a lot of variety to it so it's not boring and it's a long repeat too.

There are Achievements.  I have not looked at them yet to see if there are any super hard ones or not.

Overall I am super happy with my purchase.  I think it's worth full price but you can also wait for a sale to save a bit if you want.  So far 20% off is the highest discount I've seen.  If your'e a fan of Peggle or Pachinko like games and also like replaying over and over then this is the game for you, just buy it!

When taking this game a bit more seriously, you notice how limiting and unreliable building your deck is, which is what makes this game fun. 
There's not a lot of quality of life features you would expect from a roguelike (such as seeing item % chances and random ecounter %s , a library of all relics and balls, or even detailed summary of your own stats in game).
There isn't also a lot of progression other than cruciball and the only "unlocks" there are in this game are two mediocre characters and the ability to use additional relics in custom mode, which is like a "godmode sandbox godmode".
There genuinely isn't another game in the sub-genre like this, so it makes me frustrated that it just isn't fun to play.

Balance isn't there, and each update makes it worse. 60% of the picks are underwhelming, some builds hard fold to some bosses and encounters, and are just boring to play, and the ascension climbing only increases randomness, which in a peggle based game is already rampant.

Very fun game, even if somewhat flawed. There's some broken items/combos and sometimes unfair situations/annoying maps, especially on higher difficulties, but it's still very much so a work in progress receiving regular updates and again, it's just really fun.

Don't get me wrong, I like the game and it's a really fun time killer.  Throw your orbs, throw bombs, defeat enemies and don't get killed. And stay on cruciball (ascension system) 2-8 if you want the game to be enjoyable, otherwise it's just rolling the dice until you get extremely lucky to grab a few relics/orbs that synergise well. 

I actually liked the addition of money system instead of upgrading or healing for free, it makes you think and plan what to do next during a fight or where to go in the map. Somehow it added some level of control to players. And player's control is my main complaint. 

You are not in control. You may think you are and you may assume that you know just the right angle to throw your.. well, peglin (?) during navigation to get to this chain of relics, still it somehow bounces through the board to the opposite site in good 30% of the cases.  
Recent update with new classes and new orbs and relics (were they supposed to be class-specific? Cuz they're not and different classes do not fell much {if any} different since the pool is the same) only made it worse.
I'm on cruciball 12 with the default class and on cruciball 8-9 with new classes, I don't see classes to significantly influence my runs. It's the same RNG-fiesta most of the time. 

I like the game and I have over 100 hours played, yet it's rather a neutral review, 4-5/9 and I'm leaning towards 4 tbh. New content is usually good, now it only brings more chaos. And it's not that I'm not willing to adapt to new stuff, quite the contrary, it's that the new stuff made the game less fun. It's even more random but much more predictable now. Get a few ballad orbs and a few more crits on the board and you're good. Get relic/orb that gives muscircle for every 3/1 refreshes and get rid of the crit? You're set.  

No more swings: "Oh, this can be really good if I find this particular relic" or "It will be terriball if I encounter this elite", you're better off just throwing stones and skipping relics until you find what you need and then you're OP, otherwise you're just dead in a few common encounters.

Really wanted to like this. Like many of the other negative reviews, it's just hard for no reason. 

For example: One of my favorite powerups is durable, but there's a map, the Pyramid when you're fighting the dragon, that is literally impossible if you have durable, because you'll rarely break a peg so you can't actually hit the center of the pyramid. So if you don't have a good refresh build or something else, it's just a guaranteed lose.

This game got a lot of its "hype" from the fact that so many creators played it early on. And it was fun to watch, because I could speed up the video. But the play is slow. Even with 1.5x speed, let's be real with each other - it's not that great.

They tried to capture Peggle but ended up just making me miss actual Peggle and realize that this is not Peggle, even if it's heavily inspired by it.

Lastly, there are interactions which don't really make any sense. Like the ability to get bulwark but the orb deals no damage. So if I didn't get any upgrades to actually give Muscircle or Spinesse, then the run is just over. I'm tired of seeing, and sometimes playing, games where the ability to win is deterministic on specific factors. And, what's worse, you have no way to know what you might face. Sometimes it's the Wall. Sometimes it's the crossbow. Sometimes it's the dragon. How am I supposed to win when my build is really good against certain maps and not others?

TL;DR - Could have been fun, but instead just reminds you constantly that this isn't Peggle and never will be.

Editing this review from negative. This latest update with the two new characters as well as the shop and coin balances has really changed the game, before it was a real no on the game but it really seems to be heading in the right direction, the complexities of builds is back as well as the currency not having a negative impact on game play. Fun game but the update honestly kinda sucks. The dragon especially. Facing off against the dragon as the final boss literally ruins the entire run and makes gathering relics and orbs just stressful instead of fun. Like the relic that gives durable to pegs is now completely unusable because of the shape of the map wont allow any progress through the centre effectively costing you the whole game.

Remember when games used to be fun? Peglin doesn't.

They've updated this game a lot recently with added classes, balls and relics all of which is great!

Sadly they've also broken it in the process. The game is wayyy too hard to play right now and unless you're looking for Dark Souls Peggle this game ain't for you. I've just played 10 games in a row beating the first stage boss only once in that time (then died in stage 2). Before the recent updates you'd beat the first stage boss most of the time and have trouble on the later levels. The devs obviously saw this game was too easy or too relaxing so made it basically impossible to beat.

If you like Dark Souls, Peggle, punching holes in your walls and never beating the first stage all at once then this game is great for you in its current state!

I'm updating my review to reflect the current patchnotes, as my review for the game was made at a time when a lot of the quirks were very different regarding the game, however, my main conclusion is still the same. [b] Don't get the game unless you're confident you'll like what you'll get. [/b]

I made my previous review on Peglin when coins didn't exist, you could quite casually do a billion damage with the right combinations of relics and orbs, and when Cruciball was capped up to Level 7.

A lot of the points I had in the previous review still hold up with the current patch notes, but I'd like to go over some positives that the dev team have introduced first:
   â€¢ The coin system does provide a little bit of control with your runs, it's a step in the right direction.
   â€¢ Relics are now (mostly) different from eachother and actually serve a purpose. It's noted that Relics now have a rarity as well.
   â€¢ They finally added a dragon lets gooooooo there were a definitive 0 dragons even though they were mentioned

However, the main criticisms I have with the game still also hold true. Events are really punishing, with a lot of events (especially in the first act) forcing you to make really detrimental decisions for your run like forcefully adding an awful orb early, or taking unavoidable damage unless you'd like three more useless deadweights. There are a few events that do balance them out by being positive, but I find that I avoid ? spaces when I do a run because they are just that punishing.

Orbs are still weirdly balanced, while the dev team acknowledge that there were really undesirable orbs, they make them "viable" by adding a bunch of key-words to them that only make them conditionally good, rather than giving them some other form of uniqueness. (I'm looking at the Bramblorb and Infernorb in particular, with Bramblorb having a key-word that doesn't even EFFECT some enemies without any indication of not being able to do so.) Why not make infernorb instead light pegs on fire so that the next orb that hits those pegs (that are on fire) gain some extra attack while putting the fire out?

Finally, enemies are still very hit or miss, mainly because they are used as ways to blockade off specific builds. Oh, you have the Super Sapper bomb trinket? Good luck building around that and using it against the guy who gains strength every time you throw a red bomb. You're running a somewhat slow sustain/poison build? Gee golly I sure hope there's not a boss that starts rushing towards you before instantly killing you if you take too much time! Slay the Spire does have bosses like this too, but with that game, you're able to still play around bosses that go against your build if you play well. 

Peglin could be a somewhat relaxing and satisfying game, but rather than feeling good when you pull off a tough shot or being able to express yourself by making a cool build, you're instead constantly feeling like you're butting heads with the game to try and make things work. I want to see this game do well because it's a fun concept at heart and it can be really chill, but the dev team still needs to make a lot of smart balancing decisions and put in a lot of work to make this game a bit more servicable. A lot of elements feel very lacklustre, like the new classes, which just uses content that you already are able to play with and removes some aspects of it. I'll probably revisit this game in the future, but again, I don't really recommend it at its current state. Thanks for reading my review.

Do you like peg-popping and dragon-slaying games? Well, "Peglin" might just be the new ticket. It's a little game that came out on Steam recently, and it is garnering quite the attention. I have to say, it's one of the most exciting releases I've seen in a while.

The game is a fascinating synthesis of two major gaming pillars: "Peggle" and "Slay the Spire." It perfectly meshes the fun of physics-based gameplay with the intrigue of strategic deck-building. It's got an addictive loop that speaks volumes about the depth and complexity of its design, something that might not be obvious on the surface.

Take the way you can synergize orbs in "Peglin". It's a small detail, but one that I find quite intriguing. It offers the player myriad ways to engage with the game, making each playthrough a unique experience. The game also features relics, which add further layers to the strategic gameplay, a bit reminiscent Risk of Rain. It's a feature that adds a lot of replay value.

Now, let's talk about the game's aesthetics. Its visuals are bold and colorful, delivering that sweet dopamine hit every time an orb strikes a peg. And the soundtrack? It's catchy, to say the least. It's one of those tunes that just embeds itself into your subconscious, continually luring you back into the game.

Despite its many merits, "Peglin" does have a few areas that could use some polishing. The game feels a little short and left me wanting more. It desperately needs a level loop (repeat from the beginning after defeating the last boss at an increased level of difficulty) or additional levels to maintain the challenge and excitement. Plus, more unlockable characters, items, and orbs would be a significant boon, adding an additional layer of depth and personality to the game.

Also, I can't help but feel that once you master the mechanics, the runs become significantly easier. This can lead to a dip in the overall challenge, making the game feel a little less satisfying for seasoned players. This is an area where the developers could surely improve.

"Peglin" is an intriguing title that any fan of indie games should seriously consider. It's an exciting blend of strategy and action, with a few hitches that keep it from being perfect. However, the potential it holds is immense, and though I'm a master now - I still come back to it daily. I'm eagerly waiting to see what the future holds for my little green peglin.

This game has some amount of build-crafting that often snowballs into very fun (but often overpowered) builds, I especially had fun finding relics that allowed me to spam crits and super bombs which would trivialise anything that wasn't a boss.

But after beating the game on my second run, and experiencing only a small handful of new events, relics and balls on subsequent attempts, I just don't feel there is enough there to keep me playing long enough to justify the price (Â£15.49 at time of review). The game is currently far too easy and far too short, the 3 worlds fly by ESPECIALLY when you have a half decent relic or two. Part of me thinks that 6 worlds would feel like much better pacing for how much i paid.

With that, i'd also love to have a small amount of world building / story. I beat the game, blew up countless creatures/people/things ..... but i don't know why the goblin wanted to do that? I suppose he just has a bloodthirst and a need to peg.

Lots of re-balancing and updates have made the game more enjoyable. Looking forward to future updates.

In the distant Past:

I did really like this game...once upon a time. Let me take you back to the ancient past, when wild youtubers roamed free, grazing upon the green grasses of early access games. It was in those days, a rouge like, simple and yet satisfying found its way into the common diet. Ah yes, Peglin was fun, runs could get overpowered, enemies and events were interesting, and the gameplay was truly something special and unique. Not every run was a win, but more often than not you could make something work.

A creeping death this way comes:

Update after update was churned out. New mechanics and relics were added to the pool, and with this variety... everything became muddied and samey. New relics added an abundance of... weakness. Every new addition made anything decent far more difficult to find and punished the player for playing the game. Congratulations for winning that tough fight, here are a bunch of options that either do nothing for you or make your run objectively worse. While this increase in base difficulty wasn't necessarily welcome or necessary, it was tolerable... but all that changed when the coin nation attacked. Cash, Mint, Money, It hit like a sack of coins wielded by a heavy weight MMA champion. Now upgrades cost you, healing cost you, relics cost you. You would be locked into a spiral: Take damage because your run is weak -> skip upgrades and pay to heal so you don't die in the next fight -> take damage because your run is weak -> repeat. When MOST runs ended up like this and mechanical skill was left by the wayside with finnicky controls and RNG hell, the writing was firmly plastered all over the wall. 

An unfavorable comparison:

In the binding of Isaac, one's skill means that technically speaking, with no damage upgrades and a single spirit heart, you could win (extremely unlikely but possible). While not all runs could clear slay the spire, or monster train, or spelunky, or dead cells, or rouge legacy... every run made progress| maybe an unlock, maybe a skill increase, maybe just knowledge of the game that could make the next run a little bit more likely to progress further. Here though, abandon all hope ye who dare to take a boss relic. When there is only one or two relics that can facilitate a specific orb working or vice versa, taking them isn't just a risk, it often immediately acts as a penalty as they come with inhibitors. Matrobshka might just end your run on the spot if you take it after the first boss fight, or your next relic could bring everything together and almost guarantee a win... if it is one of 3 within the entire pool of items, or an orb that you might not see the entire run. If it were one or two relics, maybe a handful, it would be fine, but with more often than not ALL boss rewards being risky, if not impossible to take with the damage spiral expressed earlier, one can not experiment, especially since you'll likely lose to the next elite fight before anything has a chance to show up. (side note* Lord help you if you leaned into survival to avoid the damage spiral and you come up against the wall boss, another guaranteed loss with no potential way to use skill to win). The current state of the game is active anti-fun, even winning works against you.

A future with bleak potential:

This game wouldn't take much to re-balance (and don't think the new characters help, their unlock conditions alone are heavily anti-fun, just check the forums), a few number and RNG shifts here and there would bring this game back to its glory days. That, however, is not the direction the game is taking. Every change further limits what works and makes the game just that little bit less fun. It seems it wants to become the "dark souls" of peggle while forgetting that DS isn't an RNG hell and that if you are going to have insane difficulty you need an insane skill ceiling. It seems that the definition of "fun" here is hitting the restart button over and over again and the "skill" is learning enough to not waste your time with 50% off attempts because they are doomed just before or slightly after the first boss.

Conclusion, DO NOT BUY:

If there was an option to  roll back the game to the way it was when it was first listed, it would be an easy buy. Even with how bad the current state is, the old game, as incomplete as it was, was at least fun. This... this game is miserable now, don't torture yourself and instead buy any of the other games I mentioned above. Maybe this game will one day recapture what it had but I have gone blue holding my breath. Alas sweet peglin, I knew thee well... Rest in peggle my friend.
