I continually return to this game to try and enjoy it, but it always misses the mark.
Some boards are very fun and unique while too many boards are boring or frustrating.  
The world map allows interesting paths against navigation that is too often left up entirely to chance when it is vital to having an enjoyable (or merely playable) run.  
I like that there are a wide variety of generally interesting orbs and builds but balance is all over the place so you rarely get to experience the orbs and builds in a meaningful way. 
A total victory makes you want to play again, though losses rarely feel like they're earned.
The new unlock-able characters are behind overly chance-based conditions so by the time you get to experience what should be a new and original play-style, the system they should be introducing is used up.
The system of risks vs rewards feels unequal, for every event room you enter there's a slim chance for something great but a much higher chance of just being outright punished.
For each enjoyable aspect of Peglin, there seems to be no shortage of shortcomings to take away from them.

Peglin has all the potential to be really great and really fun, but it seems to be some way from hitting that stride for the moment.  I do look forward to a point in time where I can confidently recommend this game to others in the way I can recommend other great deck-builders.

This game is not good. Firstly, the devs allows nerf everything that is at all fun, and just make the game an annoying thing to play. Instead of there being tons of runs, at the highest difficulty it just becomes formulaic; if you want to win, pick this, then this, and so on, this makes the game dull and creative for people who like to play with a challenge. Second, the disparity in power especially for relics is palpable. for example the highest tier of relic, boss relics, contain incredibly OP abilities, like a +2/2 buff on all orbs for the cost of losing a reload, and then you also have one where all gold you get is doubled, but all upgrades are also doubled, which is practically useless in comparison. This is a rouge-like, therefore there is a large amount of RNG, you can see this good or bad, I think it's a generally good thing, however if you don't like rouge likes, the RNG will feel awful. (Duh) In conclusion, this game can be fun, but the high difficulties are just repetitive and annoying with there being a large disparity in power between items, hopefully in a while updates will come out which will improve my decision, but for now I just can't recommend.

I bought this after watching some streamers and youtubers play it. From those videos it seemed fun, but what isn't shown is how many runs it took to get the content for said videos. The highs are high but the lows are oh so low.

There is no meta progression in this game. So there is no way to get even the slightest bit of consistency. Between all the random relics and all the random orbs you will most likely get a whole load of nothing. Sure, a few of them are strong - but when everything else is so weak it feels awful. It's too dependent on the loot you get. And this is just the base game - the additional "cruciball" difficulties exacerbate this RNG issue even further.

I feel that the game does not respect your time because you have to constantly play until you get that one good run. This sort of gameplay loop does not feel meaningful or fulfilling at all. At best the base game is acceptable to kill some time but there is not enough meaningful content beyond that to justify the price tag. I would recommend to wait for more content and balance changes before buying.

Really strong concept but my grievances boil down to 1 thing:

[b]Balancing is completely off[/b]
The game has an incremental difficulty system called Cruciball. Simply put, at the higher cruciball level, it becomes clear what is viable and what isnt. Beating the 1st act of the game is harder than the 2nd and 3rd because most of the time you have bad orbs (basic boring Stones) and enemies have too much health. Setting up synergies isnt an option so you want raw damage instead of "fun" orbs. 

Most battles involve multiple enemies and you're encouraged to use Orbs that can hit seveal enemies (Bombs, Piercing...)
Most bosses however are single enemies with an oversized health pool where AoE doesn't matter at all.

As a result you end up rerolling the run until you get a decent starter relic (read: increases damage) so you can get past act 1 alone and that sucks the fun out of the game

I really want to love this game, because I love the idea and the style and it should be right my pocket. But it is just not there yet. The last upgrade was a good start, but it wasn't enough. Before the upgrade you could do one run and feel like you've seen it all. They now added a lot of stuff, which is good and the game feels a little more diverse. But as others here already said, not all the added things are great. Why is it so hard to unlock 2 more basic characters? Why do you have to go far and beyond for that? Not to mention if you just play ingame and don't read stuff, you would maybe not even know that there are 2 more characters to unlock! And the new possible builds feel more than underwhelming. Having a orb giving you ballwark that maybe helps you block 5 dmg? When there are literally tons of items who can easily heal you up for more. Why would anyone want that. Ballution might have potential, but still you need to stack 5 to do even the same amount of dmg than a bomb (which would also be aoe while ballution only targets one). And then again, after two runs you probably encountered all possible events. I hope this game will get more stuff and upgrades and versatility, because it could be really really awesome. But as it is I just can't recommend it.

Just barely a step up from an idle game with some decent roguelite elements. Gets boring a lot faster than any other roguelite game though. Tons of items that add nothing to any build, so you're regularly skipping rewards or just taking something that doesn't help. Balance feels pretty poor overall, partially because of the worthless items but also because sometimes a peg layout can be extremely disadvantageous.

Sometimes you have to take 10+ shots to get a refresh that's tucked away and lose all your health. Sometimes you get terrible orb rewards and can't dps elites or bosses. And sometimes you are too powerful and end encounter so quickly that you get no money and can no longer add power, then die at the boss.

Really leans into the gambling aspects of peggle, which makes sense. But it makes the game more of a gambling/random outcome than a skill/effort game. Will you hit 100 pegs or 2? Will you kill an enemy in 1 turn or 15? Will you go left like you wanted or get knocked to the right path?

If you're a fan of casual puzzle games, Peglin is definitely worth checking out. It's a fun and addictive game that offers a unique twist on classic peg solitaire. The graphics are colorful and cute, and the music is upbeat and catchy.
The gameplay is simple yet challenging, and it's easy to pick up but difficult to master. Each level presents a new set of obstacles to overcome, and there are plenty of power-ups and bonuses to help you along the way. The levels are well-designed and progressively get more difficult as you go, so you'll never get bored.
One of the things I love about Peglin is the sense of satisfaction you get from completing a level. It's incredibly rewarding to watch the pegs disappear and rack up points, and the game does a great job of keeping you engaged and motivated to keep playing.
Overall, I highly recommend Peglin to anyone looking for a fun and addictive puzzle game. It's a great way to pass the time and challenge your mind, and it's sure to provide hours of entertainment.

I have been a player of Peglin for a while. I even got a few of my friends playing it. When Peglin first started the game was easy to feel powerful using 3-4 strategies and it was easy to enjoy the progression of the game. Now the game feels like the balls fall faster then they should, don't bounce enough, and you now have to consider spending gold coins on life vs upgrades. The fun curve significantly reduced. The game left the casual category and went more into every turn and decision requires considered strategy. The game is still good, but i'd be lying if I said Peglin since launch has retained the "fun factor" it had when it was first launched in early access. I likely won't be playing this game as much as I had previously which is a shame. Peglin In it's current state I can't recommend.

I've played a bunch of Peglin!

I do not think I can really recommend Peglin.

The core idea is great, and they just had a big content release, which is great support to see. But while there's a greater spread of orbs and archetypes, your ability to actually control the composition of your deck hasn't scaled to match--with the base class Peglin, you'll have four orbs to choose from after a fight, but they're completely random without any kind of reroll available--if you're shooting for something specific, you can easily just have no good options available to you.

And while you do have all of those potential builds (if you get lucky enough to actually get the pieces for them)... the game doesn't really actually *reward* most of them. Ballution, the new poison build, gives you... mediocre-to-decent guaranteed damage on orbs that are otherwise hot garbage, with only one AoE option (which is admittedly good but also Quite Rare). Ballwark, the defense mechanic, comes in frankly *piddling* quantities. Your common option, at max level, gives... 1 Ballwark for every 6 pegs you hit. You are, optimistically, getting like 4 Ballwark. That is *nothing*. There's an uncommon that gives 1 for every 3 (so... 8 Ballwark)... but does zero damage no matter what. Wonderful use of a turn. And there's a rare one that actually gives you a decent-ish amount, but provides other disadvantages. And *none* of this helps you kill  the enemy because they exchange having good offense for a defensive gimmick that the game actively discourages. The later levels are so bloated in what they ask of you that you really need to have stacking offensive synergies to stand a chance.

But wait! There's classes focused on these gimmicks! Surely, they'll be better suited to making them work, with a narrower orb pool and different starting loadout. Maybe! I don't know! Because to unlock either of them, you need to do the unlock achievements--which require *50* Ballution on an enemy (a *ludicrous* number that frankly *requires* multiple of the orb that doubles Ballution, on an enemy with *high* HP, so basically specific Part 2 and 3 bosses), or *100* Ballwark, which doesn't have the benefit of a doubler, and goes away when you take damage, making it even *more* restrictive to pull off. You have to have a hyperfocused build, get the right boss, and *make* it to said boss with a build that is actively discouraged by the game. To *maybe* manage to unlock the new content. ALL WITHOUT ANY REAL ABILITY TO CONTROL YOUR BUILD. There's no rerolls, *extremely* sparse deck thinning, and in *all* of this you're at the mercy of the refresh orb RNG not hiding itself in a place that takes multiple turns of negligible damage to reach.

I want to like this, but difficulties are cranked so high for no good reason, even without going into Cruciball. The balancing just isn't there, and it's intensely frustrating.

Fun game, however the randomness of choosing navigation is frustrating to no end every time it happens. I get that the game's whole theme is Peggle, but the way it affects the navigation currently is just not great. There's no gain from this system other than the novelty of "look, where I decide to go is even Peggle-ified!", and so many times I got bounced out of an entire path that was clearly more beneficial by miles simply because i didn't calculate my shot and it's bounces all the way down to the 15th bounce with 100% accuracy. And with a game that is choosing to be a roguelike where you pick your path for different benefits, the novelty is not worth it. This problem has recently been made so much worse with the addition of shops, since it is now possible to get RNG'ed not only out of an entire path, but now into a shop when you had already recently spent your gold, meaning that you get NOTHING now, as opposed to the (still bad) choice of 3 orbs at the end of a fight, worst case scenario.

I still recommend the game, but bear in mind that this feature alone has me almost not recommending it.


Edit: after months of taking a break from this game because of how frustrating the navigation is, i decided to play it some more, since they added two new classes.

the way you unlock the classes is often pretty difficult, but only because you have to rely on having a VERY solid build specifically for getting them, and getting that build going almost kind of feels like its pointless to unlock the class, since the what you have to do is related to the class you unlock. 

For example: to get the class who's gimick is debuffs, you have to stack 50 stacks of poison on a single enemy. if you arent offered the orb that doubles current poison stacks, then your next best option is an orb that applies 6 stacks at max rank, which would take 10 hits on a single enemy (1 stack falls off each round), and the orb does some damage itself so unless its a specific boss that doesnt have many adds in the fight, its extremely difficult. Its only moderately less difficult with the poison doubling orb since it can target any enemy, but the only other orb that can hit any enemy and apply poison applies 3 stacks at a time, so its still an uphill battle. 

So you get this insane poison build going to stack 50 poison, you're enjoying the build, and then you realize that youre doing this to get a class thats advertised as some sort of debuff stacking class. But... isnt that just what youre doing now?

So you get the class, and see that it applies a random debuff with each hit. 1 stack of a random debuff. Not exactly strong, but it is nice, and you can pick up some piercing orbs. But here's the thing: to make the class worthwhile at all, you NEED pierce, and some debuff synergies. Otherwise it just isnt worth not grabbing the default class, since you will be offered one less relic everytime youre offered one. Which.. makes building around the class you chose harder..


Beyond that issue, there has also been some bugs that have cropped up but not been addressed as far as ive seen. These were not here when i last played, but i guess theyre here to stay now.

- when you break the shields that the knights hold by using bombs, the shield no longer fades away before you attack, unlike every single other enemy in the game. This results in you breaking the shield with bombs, firing a 100+ daggershot or something, and having all that damage eaten by a shield that has 0 hp and ignores any consistency in the game.

- In the mines level, the aim preview for your orbs used to properly adjust for if your orb was going to be influenced by the pull of any black holes. It still shows some sign of trying to tell you where your orb will go, but its very misleading. The worst part is that as far as ive seen, its hit or miss on if its actually an accurate prediction, meaning you cant simply be like "oh ill just adjust the aim myself to account for the bug", because it will be just as likely to not shoot how you wanted it to.



fat "Do Not Recommend" from me

I have truly no idea why this game is so highly praised - although reviews have begun to dip, they're still shockingly high. I've heard Peglin be compared to Slay the Spire - pools of relics, bosses, classes, etc wrapped in random run goodness - but despite costing about the same somehow that's about as generous a comparison I can make.

It's fine. It's a Peggle knock-off. Fair enough. I'd say, maybe about a 3 out of 5 mobile game. Which is fine! For a 3 out of 5 mobile game.

The much praised "deck"/ball building system is still as shallow and prone to crippling random chance as it was far earlier in development. The replay is near non-existent, with the pool of "random" encounters being so shallow they might as well be openly labeled. You face the exact same very few bosses in the exact same very few worlds. You pick from a surprisingly small pool of relics, few of which being worth remembering. Ultimately you work to grind out special achievements that secretly unlock alternate classes in a desperate bid to find something different even if only briefly...only to discover the much promised classes are borderline identical.

Play the demo. Do not assume further playthroughs will be particularly different if at all. If you're dying for a 3/5 mobile Peggle knock-off still at that point, well, congrats. I'd wait until it's a full mobile release.

My first run went well, I beat the first two zones and was making my way through the third when I encountered an enemy I couldn't deal enough damage per round to kill before it killed me.  Tried another run to see if it was any more fun with a different build centered around chain lightning and single-hit bombs, made it to the boss of zone 3, came relatively close to killing it, but got worn down over many turns by its constantly accurate shots.

I realized at this point that 111 minutes into this game, I hadn't had a single spark of "fun" the entire time. just following the directions and going by the numbers, making a build to progress. somehow this game makes peggle even more boring.  I requested a refund and do not recommend this game.

The more I play the more I realize how badly balanced the bosses are, and how awfully designed a lot of the pegboards are. You really aren't playing this game, its like a slot machine, everything is rng. The only way I can recommend this game is if it gets a massive, MASSIVE balance update, or the modding community blows up and transforms this into something playable.

As I got older, I realized I enjoy easy-going casual games more and this looked like one of them. I wasn't aware this was in early access and beat the game in 5.9 hours so I was kind of surprised, but it seems the devs are working on it and adding new content, so don't expect a 100 hour gameplay like some other roguelikes.

Game is fun, casual and although there is a certain level of skill involved it's mostly about luck, in terms of picking up the right combo of orbs and relics. 1 particular boss was impossible for me (4 squares constantly healing) and I'm sure if you meet it with certain orbs & relics it should be easier. 

I suggest the devs to add at least a simple FAQ or gameplay basics in the main menu as it just starts right away without telling you what is what. I still don't know what makes the balls to be activated on both sides of the map symetrically for instance. I don't know what morbid is. Somethings are not clear and makes you feel like "wtf is going on here?". This is nice when you're on a run, you're hittin insane amounts of damage and your orb is jumping all around the map but that feeling sucks when you're losing. "There is something wrong and I can't tell what". Makes you feel like the game is not fair. Don't make a player feel like this ever is all I can say to the devs. Make sure the player understands what he did caused the good and the bad, so we understand and learn. 

Anyways it's a fun little game and I recommend it, hoping the devs will continue adding content.

There's a great pachinko backbone to Peglin that I really love. It's essentially a run-based rogue-like infused with turn-based combat, with different stat and ability altering accessories that vary game to game. Your balls' abilities also vary in some really fun ways, from magnetically charged balls that will seek out special pegs on the board to behemoth boulders that smash their way through enemy ranks.

But the game falters hard in execution, particularly balancing. Experimentation in a game like this should be the fun and focus, as there are a lot of balls you'll want to try adding to your "deck," for lack of a better word. But at the moment, there's really only one viable way to play and still beat the overpowered bosses beyond the first map. Oddly enough, that way of playing not only discourages you from adding more balls to your setup - it actually hurts your chances of survival.

Want to go for a defensive run? Tough. The enemies will do so much damage that even if you max your defensive abilities, you don't stand much of a chance. Want to try for a technical build? Sorry, you're not doing enough damage to wipe the monstrously huge HP of the bosses in time to avoid their equally monstrous attacks.

There are also some glaring technical problems with using a controller, at least in my case. When it comes to artifact or ball selection, sometimes moving the left stick does nothing and the cursor won't move. Other times, pressing A seemed to do nothing. On very, very rare occasions, it's even canceled out of the thing I wanted to do, as though the cursor were aimed at "exit" as opposed to "select."

The UI is also something of a mess. Why I have to click and drag a ball into a garbage can instead of simply pressing a button to get rid of it is beyond me, especially since clicking and dragging will at times launch the ball into play. I'm also not seeing any easy way to look at my artifacts apart from their nondescript logos on the side of the screen. Little things like this add up quick.

That leaves Peglin very much a mixed bag. But with patches, maybe there will come a better sense of balancing and basic quality of life issues. I really do like this game, but it needs some serious time in the oven.

Only negative point (after only doing one complete run to the final boss) is that it seems to be a little unbalanced sometimes? Maybe I don't know how it's supposed to be, but on my first run I got some kind of relic that made the bombs do 300 dmg instead of 50 and ended up one-shotting many of the enemies. Whereas on my second run I am struggling just to make it out alive from those same enemies.

It genuinely pains me to leave a negative review, but this game feels like it is missing a major reason to keep playing after one or two tries.
Do not get me wrong, the gameplay is fun! It just misses something to strive for, something that every other roguelite has that I have played in the past. Something as easy as currencies to spend on upgrades between runs, working towards a build or anything else that keeps that desire to restart your Roguelite journey.

For now I will wait for the game to be fully released to see what it will bring, as I genuinely think it has a lot to offer if it would implement a reason to stick to it.

I almost returned this game after beating it on my 2nd attempt at about 90 minutes played mark.  Decided I didn't pay that much (on sale) and even though it was short, I'd still support them.  I did play a few more games, but also left the menu open for a few hours, so I probably have more like 4 hours of play.  

The good:  It's a fun and unique twist on a classic game (Pachinko / Peggle / Pin Board, the thing from before pinball).  Kind of reminds me of puzzle quest in that way.  

The bad:  
There's 3 zones which don't really cut it in a game like this.  Like Hades has a similar amount of zones, but the variety and content for each is far greater.
Kind of tries to have "rogue-lite" content but doesn't really succeed at it.  Plus, they give you a total cheat-mode option after you win once which really cheapens the experience. 
Super swingy on luck, which you can even save skim if you want.  But the result is you either get great things or bad things, and not a lot of agency in that.   It doesn't feel like there's much skill in building up a winning combo, as individual items are insanely good or insanely bad (and not much between).  I see evidence of combos that could exist, like stacking crit, but I doubt it's better than just picking strong individual items.  
Playing some more, I did see some new content, but overall, it didn't feel meaningful to play again.  Contrast to roguelites like Hades, FTL, or Gunfire Reborn, which tricks you into replaying the same levels hundreds of times without feeling stale.  

Suggestions to address my issues I mentioned:
Get rid of custom/cheat-mode and introduce actual rogue-lite mechanics. 
Change Cruciball from being debuffs on you to buffs on enemies. New Game+  is always going to feel better than "Beat the same game but with penalties."  Beating a boss with 10mil health is going to feel better than beating the boss with the same health but you have -1 to damage.  
Balance the orbs better, but introduce rarities where you could have a better version of the same thing to encourage you to do different strategies each game instead of making the same choices (ala Hades). 
Maybe have some kind of orb synergy or merging mechanic.  Like, perhaps an Orbelisk lvl 3 and a Orblation lvl 3 give you an ability that makes all stones and boulders be burning.  

Lengthen runs (either more zones or more content for current zones) to allow some of the "build-planning" seen in games like Slay the Spire or any of the other roguelites I already mentioned.  Again, I see "builds" that in theory exist, but with no real time or incentive to actually pursue something like relics and a bag full of Orbelisk boosting orbs, or crit boosting orbs. Allow selling things like Hades, perhaps, to create that same kind of tension about selling to try and get something better later, or keeping for its strength now. 

Make orb choices other than the big spammy ones like Chain Lightning, decent at picking up gold. Perhaps gold gain is a stat similar to damage, so some pick up like 1.1x gold and others pick up like .8x gold.  Otherwise every single run I'm picking up like 2 chain lightnings or similar, just to soak up some gold.

Peglin has a lot of charm and a ton of flaws. The game becomes very repetitive after a few runs I'm aware it's a rogue-like, but it doesn't change enough between runs to maintain replayability. This severely hurts the game because there aren't enough viable strategies to change how you progress. Cruciball doesn't change the format enough to warrant playing and the game ends up failing because of this. With alternate peg-sets for enemies the game could potentially regain this, but as of right now doesn't manage to leave a lasting impression or make me want to return for more. It's a shame because otherwise the game is very well put together. Hopefully with the addition of new classes and bosses they'll make the game more memorable, but I'm not gonna hold my breath.

Imagine a punishing strategy game (similar to Slay the Spire) except you only have marginal control over your own actions, and everything else is crammed full of unmodifiable RNG.

The concept: a casual matchy/bouncy plinko-like game meets rogue-like deckbuilding strategy
The execution: a not very fun minimally "playable" experience (there's not much play in this "game", where your decisions are very loosely associated with effects).

If the core mechanic and loop were fun this game could still be something, but it's a bizarre loggerhead of "strategy requirements, random tools" - I'm honestly baffled by the game and don't understand the designer's vision. Perhaps the design constraint the designer applied to themselves was "how to waste both their own *and* players' time"

Game also desperately needs the essential/basic QoL type of design decisions like "confirmation button" or "undo purchase" and such.

Perhaps it'll be repaired before early access ends but... I wouldn't count on it. The fundamentals of the game are wildly confused; "high accountability with low autonomy" is a phrase that more or less means "maximal unpleasantness."

Updated review: Came back to see how the patches had affected the game. Verdict: I couldn't write a damming enough review to encapsulate how terrible this game remains. Remember when everyone was furious that the original Diablo III devs clearly hadn't played their own content, and we were seething that these inexpert buffoons were weighing in on what they thought might be fun or not? This is like that, but without the budget. One star.

After a good few hours of gameplay, I can say, at the moment, this game is pretty good, with LOTS of potential. However there are a lot of different things that hold it back from being great. For me, the main one would be the balancing. So far, in all my runs, I either get dumb luck and get a few of the different item combinations that make the game trivial, or I lose because it's ridiculously hard to beat the game without a cheesy strat. Hell, it is fun to fill the board with 5 different balls at once, with each peg being able to take multiple hits, and each 50 hits spawning a bomb, but after the first few times it gets repetitive. 

I would still suggest this game, especially when on sale, it just has a lot of growing to do.

I have high hopes for the future development of this game. It combines elements of chance through Plinko with deck-building and dungeon-crawling akin to Slay the Spire, which is as refreshing as it is unique. The enemies are challenging, and the unlockable levels of the Cruciball mode add further challenges after each successful run. In addition, the option to speed up the entire game is a nice touch that helps with the grind.
Negatives are few and far-between, outside of the normal frustration of difficult battles. I may argue that more goblin classes, relics, or more orb types could add further variety to the game, but there is absolutely plenty of variety in the current state. I highly recommend this game for fun, quick entertainment if you enjoy deck builders with a touch of mindlessness.

Feels like a pre alpha game. All RNG related, zero skill required, should cost 50% of what it is currently listed as for the lack of content and frankly poor balancing. I beat the game on my very first run and everything since then has been the game stomping me into the ground with no chance of recovery. It pains me to give this a negative review as the very concept of it peaks my interest but the execution is just too sloppy. I've given it multiple chances (as reflected in hours played) but it honestly just doesn't work, at least not in it's current state. Just not enough balancing or content to be anything more than free.

I really hate this trend of nerfing everything to the ground in the name of "balance". this game used to be fun, but all the artifacts are shit now. you'll get a choice of 3 "boss artifacts" but several times I've found that I would rather have none of them because they all suck and have negative effects tacked on. The orbs you're presented with at the end of a battle are most likely gonna be shit. Both the actually good artifacts and orbs have been made so they appear less often.

Peglin is an incredibly addictive and fun game that is perfect for anyone looking for a casual yet engaging experience. The game offers a unique blend of pinball and RPG mechanics that make for a truly unique and enjoyable experience.

The highlight of Peglin is the gameplay itself. The game is incredibly easy to pick up and play, but it's also challenging enough to keep you coming back for more. The combination of pinball mechanics and RPG elements creates a gameplay loop that is both rewarding and satisfying.

Additionally, Peglin's graphics and sound design are top-notch, creating a visually stunning and immersive experience. The game's cute and colorful characters are a joy to watch, and the soundtrack perfectly complements the gameplay.

Overall, Peglin is an excellent game that is well worth playing. Whether you're a fan of pinball games, RPGs, or just looking for a fun and engaging casual game, Peglin is sure to satisfy. With addictive gameplay, charming graphics, and a fantastic soundtrack, Peglin is a must-play for any fan of the genre.

Peglin - What you need to know:

1. Somehow, this has less content then Poggle. I know, it's shocking. Yes, it is early access, but holy hell- For some reason instead of things like stages, mechanics, and items - The dev is just like "Eh, you know what? Let's just ramp the difficulty up and make that the primary focus for replayability. Oh, and that difficulty ramp should just be annoying and boring, like adding more base stones or increasing min-boss encounter rates!"

2.  What is there for the most part is good. There just isn't much of it. Maps need a variety of more nodes, some orbs/relics are straight up garbage that should just be removed from the game, but despite that, the base feel of the game is fun.

3. Peglin is cute and so are the monsters, I suppose.

Wait until it is out of early access.

i think the game is good in certain points but really lacks in other i'll go over the good points first : 
the  artstyle is quite nice . however i feel there lacks a certain continuity between them with thing like the minotaur being quite realistic and your character being a really cartoony gobling . and that's really the only thing good i can tell about the game because the rest is just really lacking . first of all the most important part about a game . it's gameplay . it is for me the main reason why i dislike this game . the gameplay is repetitive . all you do is throw a ball wich after like 3 bounce max you got no clue where it's gonna go ; there is very few skill involved . it really just feels like a point and click most of the time . but that's wouldnt be such an issue if my next point didn't exist : the game truly lacks replayability . every single ball in the game works in the same way : throw it rack , rack up damage and heal/deal dmg . sometime with an extra  thing on the side . there isn't anything that changes the gameplay fundamentally . like there isn't an object that makes the balls act differently from any other ball . at the end you trow the ball at the peg and wait for it to end . and while some object try to fix that . with thing like the pie thingy . all it does is add another layer of randomness . because when you don't have a lot of skill based gameplay rng is all you have to rely on . and i don't say that because i find rng based game bad ; they can be really good . it's just that there needs  to be something more then pure random luck . and this is only intensified with the cruciball . the only replayability this game gets . and the only reason  why it makes it replayable is because it's hard as all hell  . and that's quite shit. because  now instead of having a decent amount of different build you can pray to get and slightly influence yourself to get . you just need to rely on a few easy to get one that works consistantly . also the lack of level is a really big inderence to the game's replayability . i think instead of focusing on adding more balls and doing more collab the game should have more level and other thing that make it replayable . for example what about a daily challenge where you get a specific build and need to win with it . or even better item that fundementally change the gameplay ; like one that transforms your orbs into a beam meaning you destroy a straight line instead of bouncing . that'd fundementaly change the gameplay in a new way . or what about adding an item that makes you able to redirect your orb after each bounce with an addition of a force . it'd make it so good player can get really higt damage and make more unique runs . and i feel like i strayed a bit too far from my point so let me get back to it ; while those problem are really something that make me not like this game . there is still something to take from it . it is a unique concept ; and i'd just wish it was executed better .

This is a great game- I'm only not recommending it for a single but HUGE reason...

If you've played Peggle, you'll know what I'm talking about. The disappearing peg-delay for stuck balls.

In Peggle, when a ball get's stuck the game will make whatever it is stuck on disappear to get it unstuck. Peglin also has this mechanic, but it does so WAY TOO SOON. TO THE POINT WHERE IT IS AFFECTING THE GAMEPLAY.

90% of the time, my ball isn't even stuck, it's just going too slow for the game's liking and then the pegs disappear. This is a problem because it affects a whole slew of things like combos, drop locations, and overall damage. 

This mechanic WILL have a negative impact on EVERY. SINGLE. ROUND.

Until this is fixed, I cannot recommend this game. Yes, its' THAT annoying.

TLDR: Peglin has a fun concept, but once you start digging for depth its hard to find any. If all you're looking for is "cute peggle roguelike" then you'll be satisfied. 

Peglin follows the Slay the Spire formula, but isn't finely tuned enough to make it shine. Instead, the StS formula holds Peglin back from achieving its potential. The overall systems encourage deck building and shifting your strategy as you go, but Peglin's combat seems to actively punish going all-in on a single strategy. This is because the game has so much inherent randomness that no matter what "build" you aim toward, the best strategy will always include the same few items. 

That randomness is also applied to the map navigation, which can be incredibly frustrating at times. 

You could argue that it's not "randomness" because yes, there are ways to mitigate it. That is, get Unicorn Horn to expand your "aim line" and clear each battle stage more completely to maximize your chances of going where you want to go. There are times though, like right after a "?" stage or a chest stage, where you really are just up to The Lord's Mercy.

There's also a NG+ system similar to StS Ascension: The "Cruciball". However, the first few levels have done nothing to noticeably change the game. 

Again, I really don't know why they chose to mimic StS systems so much. StS works because you are given incredible amounts of information, and lots of agency to act on that information. Peglin gives you that information, and acts like you're supposed to use it to your advantage, but your ability to do that is restricted by RNG, and the difficulty isn't high enough to warrant the risk of specializing into a specific strategy.

Solid little game with quite a bit of promise but currently lacking a bit of variety due to only having 3 worlds and 6 primary bosses.

I have really started enjoying cruciball, game mode that stacks multiple set negative modifiers to make the game harder. It has given a lot of value to items and orbs I had considered worthless, or unimpressive on the default difficulty.

The game is at its heart a deckbuilder though, so if you don't enjoy thinking in advance and having multiple build options to account for RNG you will likely not enjoy cruciball. Which means the game will feel pretty light on content for its price.

I will update this early impression if any major patch comes out. 

p.s. I am only on cruciball 9, apparently it gets nasty after a point according to others, I haven't hit that wall yet though.

Whenever i try out a game and it keeps me entertained for so long its a win in my book

You are a little gremlin who collect orbs to throw around to do damage to enemies
the only thing you control is the direction the orb is thrown in a 360" angle
there are many different ore's with special abbillities different enemies and at this moment 3 worlds
Every playthrough is different and everytime you win a round. it gives a bigger <optional> difficulty that gets higher and higher everytime you win

The Good Stuff:
-There are many items that help you on the way, so many that every run feels different
-Good and adicting gameplay, you just wanna unlock more difficulties
-simple and easy to play

The "Bad" stuff
- For looking so simple â‚¬16,49 feels a bit expensive. in the end i found it still worth it, but it is on the pricey side
- The music really gets repetitive quick, glad there is an option to turn it of
- It's hard to stop playing, there are moments when you loose and think, "But that was unfair" and you start another round. and before you know it, you are playing this game for hours and hours

Things i would like to see in upcoming updates.
- More items, The more items are added the more different each round will become (this also includes more orbs)
- More different enemies. Elemental weaknesses, special strenght's to some, just a bit more variation to our baddies, (this includes also more bosses)
- More worlds, maybe even a pick a path, this would make the game feel 10X bigger

In short, i found this game amazing. and still play it allot. this is a good example that even simple looking games can be amazing.

A very good option if you want to play a rogue-lite but want it a bit more relaxing. There is a ton of potential to this game and the devs are still adding content every month. This game deserves a bit more popularity than it has now honestly. There are more classes being added to the future and more relics thankfully. This is still early access, so hopefully when it is fully released it will match up to the $15 price tag.

love pegs
not a bad game, but greatly overpriced, its like a 10$ game at best. should be like 5$ to get a good community going
Good game, but I wouldn't choose to play it over most other games

peglin is very fun. it is still very early access, but it has enough content right now to make it well worth the price tag in my opinion. my only real complaint is that its balance on higher cruciballs can be really rough sometimes especially in the early game, but when runs go well it has given me more satisfaction then I've gotten out of any other rogue-lite.
It's fun. Play it!
Super simple, but fun to strategize around. RNG feel fair for some reason.

God I want to like this game so much. I really, really do. The packaging and screenshots are nice, art is wonderful, gameplay is largely smooth and unencumbered. I'm just not quite sure the itch this tries to scratch and just doesn't get there somehow. This disappointment (only slight, I do plan to keep the game and keep playing) only compounded small annoyances and made them stick out to me more over time. Of course, this could easily be rectified by playing more than 2 hours of the game.

The orbs don't really affect much of the gameplay, the gameplay doesn't make sense as to how attack damage is dealt (maybe I'm just unobservant idk), the RNG is a little wonky, the paths are generally the same regardless of direction you head, and the thing that got under my skin (as pedantic and nitty gritty as it is, I'm sorry) at the end of the most recent playthrough were the imitation SquareEnix menu sounds that get way overused and have way too much echo/reverb on them for my taste. Again-- very pedantic and snobby of me, I know. But I want to hold on to this game because it's possible I've just scratched the surface as in StS near the beginning. Make no mistake that this is definitely NOT a Peggle/Pachinko version of Slay the Spire.
It's really fun and there's already a lot of promise. I know there's probably going to be more added over time but the game itself needs to be longer.
Fun roguelike with so many different possible runs

It has a strong gameplay loop and core 'pegging' experience is solid to say the least.
however, currently there isn't a lot of content and scenarios, which is to say that the replay value right now is very low,




I will update the review, as it gets more updates....
Fun

well loaded it up and played for 11 hours straight so yeah there. love peggle and will play it from time to time, like rouge likes but usually get bored pretty quick;y, that did not happen with this game!! =D

It's Peggle in roguelike form. It's works great on the Steam Deck. It's my current play-while-listening-to-podcast game and has been for over a month. There isn't a regular meta game like with most roguelikes. The main challenge in the game isn't beating it once. It's beating it 15 times with added handicaps against you added each time. I'm currently at 11 and this might be the level that breaks me. It's starting to feel like there might only be a couple viable builds at this difficulty and I have to get really lucky with the mystery locations. I don't know though. I continue to experiment.

This game is absolutely everything I would have wanted out of a modern peggle game. It's a fresh take on the pachinko format and it works extremely well. The game is a bit shorter than I was expecting, but I'm happy to play it through multiple times. Now if you'll excuse me, I need to get back to pegging
Nice game, very fun! Looking forward to what comes next and more difficult cruciball levels.
I like pegging the bosses, you would enjoy it too.
It's Peggle with Yoda
after 75 hours this is a great game to just play when im listening to a podcast. I highly recommend more level variety. after 40 hours the levels are very repetitive. other than that, no complaints
extremely satisfying
peg peg
It's good. Very, very good. There's something so addictive about crafting a perfect build in a play-through, and the newer mechanics of shops and whatnot give you more flexibility to do exactly that.

The balance of the game has been ruined by new features that work poorly with the games initial design. Crucible has become impossible due to RNG having now gone to far, navigation shouldn't be unpredictable! it defeats the point of the map and take away any need to plan. The gold economy on later crucible levels is impossible to manage and even minor health loss gets you stuck in a cycle of paying to heal and in turn not being able to get stronger to avoid future damage. The game isn't bad but it needs some serious balancing cause even when everything falls into place and all goes well one minor inconvenience ruins the entire run.

to add more info I'm on crucible lvl 12 and it took a couple hundred runs to get from 11 to 12 just to get the right combo of items and encounters. The slime boss is unbalaced as the peg layout make it way to hard to rack up enough damage especially once he reaches you. one other thing is there is to many ranged units in the first map that chip away at your health forcing you to spend money on already nerfed heals or alternatively leaving you with no health for the boss, reducing their spawn but not eliminating would be ideal as I have had 3-4 encounters in a row that add up to a lot of damage.
roguelike peggle review: it is roguelike peggle

THAT'S A GOOD GAME

There's a full review on Imalwaystired.blog
great game, with or without mods.
its a fun game you can pick up and put down has super cute little Peglins!
perfect pegging experience

Even though I don't like roguelikes in general I really enjoyed Peglin for combining Peggle with deckbuilding / drafting!
With 3 stages in total it's unfortunately a bit short for now. I finished all in 5 hours now and it was so fun I want to play more! 
But since it's still in early access I hope for lots of new content in the future. Since you start over every time it should be nice to come back from time to time if there's new content.

Questionable designs all over the places.
The game kindly explains to you how Bramble helps you slow down enemies. Guess what, it doesn't work for half of the enemies, and the game literally doesn't tell you what enemies have immunity and what not.
Then the game tells you how great thunder orb is dealing with pesky ranged enemies. Guess what, the game also introduces taunt enemies that counters your thunder orb.
Lack of enemy description and basic inspection is the biggest flaw and I don't know how it's never addressed since the launched.
It's a novel concept but it just doesn't work well as a skill based game. most of the time you can only pray for the best result due to the natural of physics simulation.

Great spin on Peggle, love the roguelike elements. Little unbalanced at times but the post-completion challenge modifiers and fun mechanics keep me coming back. Seems to show good progression as an early access game, and I can't wait for more classes to be added to give it some new flavours.

This game is very fun. It has enough to it to make you think but not so much to stress you out like a lot of rouge-likes do for me personally. It's quick to start a new run and even long runs aren't super long. Plus it has little gobos which instantly makes it 10/10.
It's an adorable and enjoyable game. In a world of FOMO, grinding and stat farming, it's nice to relax.
best game ever
Fun concept but mediocre execution. Very little control over your build, some rng is expected but this is too much. It gets boring after playing through it once.
This has less content than many 5$ games
My wife won't let me use my SteamDeck anymore because she's too busy playing Peglin.
Extremely frustrating rng. Best way to play is just not aim for anything and let the game decide if you're doing anything useful

I am absolutely fiending for that peggle gameplay and Peglin provides, but at this point of development It feels like there is very little build diversity. One character to play, and you kinda end up with the same orbs and upgrades rather than specialized builds. Fun, but not capitalizing on the rogue-like format
Peggle with roguelike elements, quite enjoyed it. Will return for future updates.
Fun
I've had an absolute blast playing this so far. It makes the brick breaking format fun and interesting again, and the roguelite elements keep it entertaining enough on replay.

Great little game, excited to see where it heads in the future. 100% worth the price it's at right now would also like to see a mod workshop if ever possible in the future!

Edit: Holy crap, I did not think I'd play almost 90 hours of this simple game but here we are. Still missing a good mod workshop, but the new updates here and there are great, I'd like more boss variety, elite events, and maybe a new stage (three stages feels a bit short for me personally) but man is this game addicting, fun, and even has some secrets! Highly recommend, all I could ask for is more. Just PLEASE Red Nexus give some modding tools to the community to elevate this game to the heavens.

Will put an Edit 2 if I find it needed to update y'all, give this developer some money, still stand by that it's worth full price!
You can Peg to your hearts content!

Great game if you liked Peggle and like games that are heavily dependent on randomness.  Game isn't exactly balanced just yet (some powerups are much better than others.)  As it's in development, I expect that this will improve over time.  It's still very fun, but I'm at the point where I've added 5 "wedges" of difficulty and I have absolutely no chance of winning unless I get insanely good luck on starting item + first few pegs.

Overall great game, and am excited to see how it develops.

I think this is good, considering it is early access.

I agree with what many others have said.

- need more balance between luck and skill, especially if you get some run winning randoms you can get to the end and win and be kind of confused how you even won without trying
- needs more length to be sure
- I did not purchase a single item from the shops because upgrade and battle wins felt easier for me to access
- try to make the map path choicing a little bit more random or varied. It's kind of like Inscryption, except with Inscryption I felt a genuine strategy and anticipation of something sort of unexpectef happening while traversing the map. Here I mainly just peeped the map and avoided all fights in favor of ?'s. I think I should be punished harder for fight dodging the whole way and still getting dope perks.

Do you like rogue-likes? Do you find Peggle to be at least somewhat fun? Then download this game!
This game is fun. Just go get it already.

A great concept but far too little content for the price tag. You can beat the game in a few hours, and that's if you don't get lucky on your first couple runs. Sure, you could do "cruciball", the prestige mode, but all it does is stack nerfs against the player without introducing any new mechanics. The formula is generally fine (how couldn't it be? It's basically Peggle with extra steps), but the variety and length of the game is really disappointing.
IT IS VERY REPLAYIBLE AND IS PREETY BALENCED
I really enjoy the game, it feels balanced, but it's too short.  I wish it was a little longer.

Needs more polish.

This game has a very neat mechanic, but at the moment it feels too much like a concept demo. The UI is too minimalistic and when you die it just immediately goes to menu, and finishing a run just gives you an overview of your gear and that's it. You're left with a sort of empty feeling. It's a game that can easily reach an 8/10 that at the moment sits at a 5/10.
You can play a relaxed Game of Peglin to End your Day, or try to unlock all the Cruciball-Levels if you hate your Life. So its a win-win for everyone.
Fun time
Roguelite meets Peggle/Pinball! Hit bricks, do damage, buy balls, get relics, beat bosses, win the game and do it all over again

Adorable Peggle-inspired rogue-like, that involves you fighting your way through three main areas to complete a run. Peglin balances skill and luck very well, there are times where you simply get unlucky, but skillful play can get you out of a lot of bad situations. For as cheap as it is, it's entertainment value and replayability are worth it.

Being a Peggle roguelike is a double edged sword. 

On one edge, its the appeal of the game - it takes the simple, casual game of Peggle, and gives it some layers to make it feel more like a fleshed out game rather than something you'd play on your phone for a few minutes. 

On the other, this means that unlike other roguelikes, there's very little mechanical skill involved, so how well you do is determined instead by a roughly 50/50 split of decision-making and luck. Once you know what items to get and how to make the most of them, you are just looping runs until you get good items. Bosses are nothing more than a check to see if you've gotten good items - if not, gg, try again. 

There's no changing this. If they made the gameplay more skill based, it loses the appeal of being a pretty brain off game with enough substance to feel worth playing. Runs will live or die based primarily on luck and either you accept that and enjoy the gameplay, or you don't and you find it frustrating.

When I'm Playing this I go back in time playing peggle and praying for the right bounce.
The game is cute. good challenges and a great combination of items that can make you overpowered (bombsx2damage)
I enjoyed this version and I'm eager for the full release.
I love pegging
perfect game to play when u r too high to play anything else

This game is so frikin good

I do like this game, and it is very fun to make some crazy builds and experiment with different strategies, such as with most roguelike games that let you become extremely overpowered, but there is a lot missing, mostly with how repetitive the game is. Aside from getting slightly more challenging every time you beat the game, there isnâ€™t much variety between runs to keep things very interesting. Most of the levels are the same, there arenâ€™t that many random events and you see the same ones over and over, and there isnâ€™t much content to unlock or discover through secrets.

Again, I do like this game and I do recommend it, especially since the developer gives it frequent updates, but I canâ€™t help but feel like itâ€™s far from a complete game.
very fun, so worth, ball bounces and its a sweet sacred dose of serotonin you didnt know u needed

Deck building Turnbased rougelite action meets Peggle. Gameplay is addictive and I always find myself headed back for just one more run. Goals, upgrades, enemy actions, and peg interactions are all full of visual clarity to help you tune into gameplay and identify deck building shortcomings in order to make an optimal run. Targeting system makes damage more strategic and of course has the beloved complexity of Peggle targeting as well as satifying combos lighting up the screen before you. Absolutely get this game while you can. For all you classic peggle fans, this scratches that itch and i only see it getting better as development continues.

I like this game, but I want to really, really love it. Its fun and easy to pick up, but it is still in early access and has some problems. After the last few patches, it feels like the balance has been changed and its near impossible to win a Cruciball run (similar to Ascension runs in StS). Especially for the final bosses on the higher Cruciball levels. You can have a near perfect run through each level, but then be taken down by the final bosses as if you had no upgraded orbs or relics. 

There are alot of different orb types and offensive, defensive, and special relics. This could be just my luck, but unlocking some of the special relics through specific events seem to never happen. I can get through part one or two of these special events, but never reach the final part. And on the next three runs, I run into the final event over and over but not get the first part.

I don't think the game is too expensive. You can get a good amount of time and enjoyment out of it (and some frustration that come hand in hand with rougelikes). I hope future updates will add more player characters, enemies, peg layouts, and a more diverse mix to the type of run that you build as you progress.

I enjoyed watching Frost play this, and I enjoyed playing it, too. 

It plays exactly what it looks like. The strategy layers (relics, orb synergy, removals) are all there, reasonably deep, and strongly reminiscent of Slay the Spire, and that's an extremely good thing.
Lots of potential here, already a great game but the places they seem to be taking this could end up being epic.
This game is a ton of fun. It strikes a good balance between fun and difficulty, and has a lot of options for creative builds. If you like Peggle or turn based Roguelites this is game for you!

Edit 2: Yet more updates have happened. The **FUNDAMENTAL** problems with this game are not being addressed. More content is being added, but it doesn't make the core game better. Whether you have any control over your situation is up to the whims of the physics RNG and the item RNG. I'm probably come back once more a long while from now (cause I forgot how infuriating it is), try it, and just hide it from my steam library.  
I literally cannot have fun with this because I see so much potential. And the devs are just letting it sit there, neglected. 

There's some promise here. But as is, the game is **WAY** too infuriating too often. There's a focus on the boards being quirky or having interesting mechanics. Sometimes it adds to the game. A lot of times, it causes you to be literally unable to hit 90% of the board without wasting 3 or 4 shots to start. Even better is when you've cleared most of the board and the SINGLE refresh peg is hidden behind 4 or 5 other pegs that can't be cleared in 2 or 3 shots, let alone 1. 

And given how imprecise the aiming controls are, and how even the smallest of differences will give you effectively random results, it doesn't *FEEL* like the game rewards skill. I expect the game will improve as it approaches release, but as is now, I cannot recommend this game. Just stick with the demo for now.

Edit: I've let 2 or 3 updates happen in about 2 months. It's not any better. The balance is non-existent, it feels like you have no control, your options are more or less all completely random.  The degree to which so many of the design choices in this game offend me makes me want a refund. The game hits the same place for me as Dicey Dungeons; the place of "this could be something I enjoy, but I don't have enough options so I just hate this".

This is a very fun concept, but it's very bare bones and poorly balanced at the moment (Feb 2023). The cruciball mode is profoundly un-fun and encourages playing in a boring way, and it has literally no rewards for completing it, so I recommend you ignore it altogether. There's a lot I would personally change:

- Shops are too expensive compared to ball upgrades and purchases, when you can upgrade balls anywhere and get relics for free from chests, especially since you won't be fully upgraded until the final zones. A lot of the time they feel like a dead space, which is a massive penalty.

- Too many relics are far too weak to be worth taking, as you need good relics to win a run.

- There are a few relics that are too strong (Electropegnant and Molten Mantle spring to mind as the two clearly gamebreaking ones)

- The game ends at what feels like it would normally be the 1/3rd mark.

Despite these flaws, I've been having a ton of fun. I hope the game can be better polished in the future so I can give it a recommendation without any strings attached next time.

So excited for new content in this game. As it stands now, it feels complete. It's so good.

Edit: I revisited Peglin and I think I may have been too hasty in my first review. Either there's been a rebalance of currency or I had particularly bad runs when I played last. It's much more flexible than I originally experienced, and the stores add an element of customization that was missing.

The new currency update is well-meaning but removes a lot of the fun of building your "deck" of balls. Having to pay coins to add new balls at the end of a level isn't an additive mechanic, it reduces choice and punishes players who aren't trying to min-max how many pegs they're hitting in a level. Adding in currency for periodic shops that allow for purchasing higher-end balls/relics is a great idea, but the current state is not nearly as fun as it used to be.

Anything after cruciball level 11 is just a hunt for the perfect combo of cheese items. The four boards boss battle is literally impossible unless you have hit the lottery. Even with perfect optimal synergy and play from start to finish, you simply can not beat the 4 boards boss. The developers seem to have skipped on some simple high school math as the 4 boards get +1 muscircle every turn. To those that don't know, whenever you scale something through the partial sums of linearly increasing terms, it scales by the quadratic. So the rate that one loses HP is by the quadratic. Healing at best is only linear so no amount of healing can get you pass 10 turns of that boss. The few cheese combos I know that allows you to beat anything pass crucible 11:

1) Bad Cheese Relic, Round Guard, getting to one orb, (Well done Steak if using Orborus)

2) Molten Mantle, Refillosopherâ€™s Stone

3) Critsomallos Fleece, Reorbanizer, Duplication Potion


I think the worst part of the game is just the awful boss relics. There are 16 boss relics and only one boss relic gives you a legitimate shot at the 4 boards boss. 5 of those boss relics are just plain awful. Like consuming chalice that removes one refresh orb for +0/+4. The rate at which the game scales makes consuming chalice the most detrimental relic I have ever seen. Cursed mask gives orbs +2/+3 while having a negative status effect. The given confusion status effect only lasts 4 turns and most battles last more than four turns. So you are just firing orbs for four turns like you are drunk and then nothing else. I could go on, but Haglinâ€™s Satchel, Constricting Chains, and Glorious SuffeRing are the last three.

If you ask me, Peglin is by far one of the most creative games I've ever played. It's something else entirely. There are a lot of unique games and concepts, and especially in the roguelite genre, variety is plenty already. Yet Peglin manages to take things to a whole other level. Obviously, pinball is nothing new. It's a classic arcade game, and even though I have never been very interested in pinball as a concept, Peglin still intrigued me...

And it doesn't disappoint. At least, not in the important aspects. Let's start with the very basics - the gameplay. Peglin takes Pinball to its extreme. It combines concepts like crits, busted balls, and different relics that help diversify your gameplay and take it to another level. As long as a run goes well, there is a chance you will be incredibly busted by the time you beat the final area. Amazingly, it feels as though you are 'cheating' the game in a way, as though you're not meant to be dealing thousands of damage by just hitting a 'Matryorbshka' enhanced by the relics you picked up along the way. It feels like 'cheating', but I feel like its designed to be that way. Power trips like these are truly beautiful.

Speaking of 'Matryorbshka', word play is literally scattered all over this game. Even after hours of playing this game, some of the names still put a smile on my face. Down from the different orbs you can collect, to the relics, all the names are pretty clever. It is clear the developers put a lot of thought into that aspect, and though it may not seem like much, I really appreciate it.

With the addition of gold, and other updates to the game, Peglin keeps getting better and better. It feels fun and fair, and though some relics are far better than others (excluding the boss relics that are meant to be even more powerful than regular relics), they all have a place in the game. Some builds can be a lot harder to properly set up - like bomb builds or morbid builds, but they're that much more rewarding once you get the ball rolling.

And if you're looking for a real challenge, the game has got you hooked up with that, too. The Cruciball difficulty settings that you unlock as you beat the game on the previous difficulty get progressively harder and make for a truly difficult gaming experience. Personally, I find the game is best enjoyed on Cruciball 4-5, that way its not too challenging but also not a ball in the park.

 I need to stop mentioning balls.

In all seriousness, Peglin is a terribly fun game that I can see myself playing more of, especially as the developers put so much effort into expanding the game and improving it. I do know that there was a time when players were generally unsatisfied with the changes being made, however I didn't own the game at the time and couldn't see it for myself. From what I see now, none of the changes or additions seem to be anti-fun. As long as this continues, I don't see a reason not to recommend the game! Hell, despite the game still being in early access, I am already incredibly satisfied with the way the game as it is right now.

Some things need fixing, like the janky physics. There is something not quite right with how the orbs roll, bounce, and react to the pegs, and this becomes much more apparent with certain power-ups. Hopefully they will fix the physics / hitboxes in the future.
Super fun though and will last you at least 10-20 hours before it gets tedious. The game is not much longer than the demo version at the moment, so I recommend playing that until they add more stages.

great game.

I really want to like Peglin. I'm a longtime fan of roguelikes, Peggle, and similar games combining the concepts such as Roundguard. There really is something addictive and enjoyable about the gameplay even as it is now. I DO believe that Peglin could be improved and refined enough for me to recommend the game at some point but as it stands currently there are a few too many issues I have with it. 

For starters, many of the item descriptions are just too vague to understand. On multiple occasions I've picked an item to try and figure out what it does because I couldn't discern that information through the description alone, only to find myself equally confused after using it. Simply put, things need to get explained better. 

Secondly, it's too easy to screw with the game if you don't like the outcome of a battle, your rewards, or the options given to you in a chest. If you quit out of a game like Slay the Spire you will resume exactly where you left off, with the same items offered to you. I definitely think Peglin would benefit from that kind of design since it's just too easy to redo any situation you don't like.

Finally, I realize the game is in early access right now, but there's just not a lot of content available yet. I hope that the developer(s) can iron out these issues soon and I'll be returning to the game sporadically to see if things have improved enough to where I feel comfortable recommending the game and changing this review.

Veeery goood, I actually watched RevScarecrow and Northernlion on Youtube play this months back, suddenly got the kick the buy and play this and been having a blast. Figured I'd leave some feedback and suggestions, I'm not too sure what's already confirmed to come and what's not, buuut hey. And yes, I realize this game is still in Early Access.

Overall flow of the game is great - so are all the pegs and powerups so far! Clearly many different ways to play it, but not gonna lie I veeery, very often gravitate towards some sort of "upgrade the board" and/or "refresh to heal" sort of build. I always make sure to have atleast some sort of way to heal, whiiich is probably fine and obvious to have, but it did leave me hoping I could just use more money to heal more. Too often I just find the orbs and relics I know that will work, upgrade em, and then just... fiddle around with the rest of the money. Especially if and when the game decides to not give me a single shop (a single guarantee, please? might already be the case though).

My first run was a cakewalk. Aaarguably I had some information from the mentioned Youtubers/streamers sure, but there were still many new things I hadn't seen before, such as the whole Morbid thing. I had some sort of Electropegnet + Defresh potion setup going combined with pegs or relics that upgrade pegs whenever a hit is made, There were definitely a few moments where Morbid and the peg upgrade working together felt real cheesy, but hey, that's kind of the name of the game with all these Roguelikes, finding fun "broken" interactions. Still, it left me thinking there are deeefinitely some things like that I feel like could be balanced a bit better. Maybe adding a floor or two more between the current ones could do the trick, to make the difficulty curve a tad less steep.

I'm also definitely hoping not every peg type or relic will be available from the start in the final game. I'm assuming this will be the case, but it does feel weird it isn't the case in the Early Access version. Still, I'm looking forward to unlocking new things and playing around with them, maybe be forced to use the weaker orbs instead of just passing on them each time.

Other than that a few small things I'd also like improved. The fadeout between screens sometimes gets stuck when the game starts to load the next screen but the screen isn't 100% black (only like 80-90%), and it would be great to see how many bombs I've hit in a turn instead of trying to guess from the goblin fella throwing tons of them. The minotaur miniboss whatever also has a little glitch, if it gets both a chargeup and attack turn during your reload the damage will happen before it actually does the attack animation, actually happening when it starts charging up. Other than those things I'm hoping there will be relics to influence the enemy attack and movement patterns, stuff like slowing their movement down or making them attack more rarely, stuff like that.

More everything from playable characters/classes to floors to boards to enemies to pegs to relics and this game will be amazing.

I love SO much about this game, but the aiming mechanics are so broken on my macbook trackpad when it should be buttery smooth. Please play Peglin and Peggle side by side and notice the differences. In many ways Peglin is actively getting in my way of making a shot. If the mouse cursor goes off the play window, like when you are making a high angle shot, you instead start highlighting the enemies and are no longer able to shoot your ball, you instead have to move your mouse even closer to the character which makes finding the right angle even more difficult. There is no mousewheel or hold ctrl+right/left to make minute adjustments. Again, I don't know how much of this is osx, and there being support for actual mice and this is a dev oversight, but not all of it can be. Additionally, the peg board is way too small, there are all these side bars with information that, while important, would be better hidden and only show up when you move your cursor to the edges, that way the board could be much better. I have beaten the game twice so far, in spite of the aiming bug; on a trackpad you never have any semblance of accurate aiming of your ball, it will skip entire sections of a peg, skipping either way, but if I move it quickly and try to reset it, then I can get it to rest on a better angle. It's totally busted. That said, there's a lot I love about the game, but for a casual game I really want it to run on my mac and not my pc.

edit: Confirmed, this game is bugged on macos and trackpads, it skips and doesn't allow you to position everywhere. It also loads really slowly on my modern pc but it does allow you to aim correctly.

A must buy for Peggle or Pachinko fans!

Peglin is a great Peggle style game with added RPG elements. You move along a branching over-world map with each branch decided on which route you choose by firing your Peglin Ball down the gutter of preset paths at the bottom of each board. You are awarded with gold each coin peg you shoot and various balls you can unlock/buy through progress. Any relics unlocked in the campaign are unlocked for the custom run mode as well allowing you to master your skills outside of the campaign. Each ball type has different stats and abilities allowing you to focus your Peglin build however you choose to defeat the enemies. With it's timeless pixel art and addictive puzzle/RPG game-play I'd say this game is a fine choice for those who wish to combine turn based RPG's and Peggle.

The concept is interesting, but the gameplay just isn't. I want to like it but by run 3 so much of the fun had already been lost.

Good game with a content drought and serious balance issues. The entire game hinges on RNG, so you either pop or flop based on whatever the Peglin gods decide for you that run.  No good items from chests or bosses? RIP. Having a good run but RNJesus puts a refresh peg in an awful spot? RIP. No good orbs to purchase after combat? RIP. Speaking of purchasing, has anyone used a shop effectively? I think I've bought two (2) things from the store, and that was just to remove stones from my inventory. I never seem to have any cash for shops because they seem to only spawn in the forest stage, where you'll also be dumping most of your cash into getting new orbs/upgrading them. Oh yeah, why do we have to buy our orbs now? With the shop update making it to where we have to buy our orbs, middling runs often boil down to choosing to a)grab a new orb to give yourself the opportunity to grow, or b)band-aid your problems with a heal. These problems are greatly exacerbated as you get deeper in the crucible. Which, duh, the point of the crucible is to make the game harder. Right? However I'd argue that increasing the need for good rng =/= more difficulty, it just means that your wafer-thin agency in the game is spread even thinner.

The shop update has been very fun and the game feels like it's on the right track. However, Cruciball 15 feels virtually impossible unless you get Orboros or some other crazy single-target synergy very early. I only managed to clear Cruciball 12-15 by having Orboros in each run. I also think some of the boards need to be redesigned.

Take the Act 1 slime elite for example. It's hard to average more than 10 pegs per shot, which almost never clears through the ~1000 hp spread across the slimes. Also, the new Act 3 boss is so much harder than the QR code boss. The mine sweeper theme is cool, but the board that is left after you clear the boxes does not have enough pegs, especially when it's spawning time-bomb enemies every turn. 

Cruciball also ruins a lot of relics, mainly anything bomb related. -15 damage on bombs makes bomb synergies useless until you get 4 or 5 of the important pieces, which just isn't worth going for. 

Lastly, there's a way to cheat events and fights. Just quitting to menu and returning to the run will bring you back to the start of the encounter, and the RNG for orb order and events changes. Slay the Spire has a similar issue, but the RNG remains the same when you return.

So Peglin feels like it's in a real, real early state right now.  Not just because it's lacking in content (which it is I feel like I've seen basically everything the game can throw at me after just a few hours), but because it has an absolutely nuts feast or famine level of play.  You either die in the first zone because you can't hit more than a few pegs for damage, or you smoke every boss in seconds.  There's like no middle ground.  It's not necessarily a bad thing, but it does tell me that the game probably hasn't had a balance pass yet.  Anyway, it's fun to pick up and fool around with, but right now it doesn't really have a lot of staying power.  Keep an eye on it in the future.

This is an absolutely delightful little game. Currently there are 3 stages with many individual rooms and paths each. A full run takes about an hour, but each one is almost guaranteed to vary wildly based on the orbs and relics you choose to accumulate throughout each run.

The core mechanics are simple, but the real charm comes from how behaviors of orbs with the levels change based on the relics you have. One of my favorite combos involves a maxxed out Matryoshka Orb, coin modifying relics and the Molten (something, peabrain memory) Relic that prevents you from gaining gold for the rest of your run, but applies your current accumulated damage to the selected enemy for every few coin pegs you hit. Its fun to watch it spiral out of absolute control.

I cannot recommend this game enough. It's a casual game with enough depth to keep runs interesting, but not too much to where you're forced to play with a wiki (does one even exist?) open on a second monitor.
