I think there's a really excellent idea at the core of this and I'm really looking forward to seeing it develop. It's Peggle with some simple Rogue-ish/RPG mechanics baked in. At its best, it's an extremely addictive and satisfying spin on the puzzle game, with potential to break into that super-digestible zeitgeist market (e.g.: Vampire Survivors). The kind of game your friend who doesn't play games plays, but is still deep enough for you (a person reading Steam reviews) to get something out of. While I haven't hit any noticeable bugs, there are a few things that do feel like they need addressing. My two biggest gripes are pacing and content. 
Content will obviously be addressed over time, but at the moment it's feeling pretty light. I look forward to new characters who have different starting perks and orbs that will hopefully feel different, but I'm even more interested in new maps and enemies. I've had a few successful runs at this point, and it's really starting to feel like I've seen all there is to see. The fact that you move through the three maps in the same order every time does make it feel a bit routine. I'm not sure if more randomness there is the solution, but at least more variety would be great to see. 
While content will be filled in over time, and my issues there will be inevitably addressed in some way, the biggest question is how pacing will feel as the game is built. I think it currently feels a little slow. Frequently I find myself just wanting to play the actual combat situations but stuck in a chain of "?" events or stores that I can't afford anything at. Movement on the map is cute, but when I'm feeling especially impatient I find myself frustrated waiting for the next match or event to begin. There is currently a way to fast forward, which I was able to increase to 3x in the options, but that feels odd outside of combat. In menus and on the map I'd rather just tap space bar/A button to skip to the next scene or through dialogue. Stores and the "?" event spaces also feel too common. Maybe a single, unmissable store space right before each boss fight would feel better? "?" events currently feel too common for how few variety there are, there seems to only be a handful and I've seen them all a few times over by nowâ€”obviously this will probably feel different as more content is added.
It's a little hard to recommend at this point because it is, of course, a work in progress. If you're willing to take a bet on something uncertain, I think you could do a lot worse. It may just be a skeleton at this point, but it's a damn fine one. I don't feel too bad about the price of admission, though I did grab it on sale. Whether this game ends up being a fun distraction for a day or two, or, one of the truly great addicting puzzle games, is going to depend on the stuff we haven't seen yet. I think there's going to be a delicate balance to filling Peglin out with more content while not burying the aspects that make it great. Regardless, I'm looking forward to playing along as this one shapes up.

Sad to say but right now it isn't worth the price.  
I have finished the game twice now, and still have time to refund it if I wanted.  $20 for under 2 hours of gameplay is not good value no matter what kind of game it is.  Right now this game is running on hype, which is the only reason I got it.

The graphics are pretty good for pixel art.  Yes the concept is a lot of fun, as getting that amazing shot is the kind of thing that got people addicted to peggle.   For right now though, there is little meat on the bone here. No story, no meta-progression, and a handful of levels.

In time that might change with early access, and if so I will redo my review here.  Like most early access all we have are promises, and I've been burned too many times to trust them.  So for right now I just can't recommend it for this price.

want this game to be good but Act 1 is so poorly designed at higher difficulties its absurd. I would like to see one of the devs play and see how they play act 1. You either need orobouros or a lucky relic combo before the act 1 boss. If you get the spider level to start, especially on cruciball 15+, you literally should just restart as you are losing about half your health at best.
New gold system is fine but needs work. Act 1, of course being 100x harder than the other acts, you are always desperate for gold and instantly spending every penny you get. If you don't happen to get 25 gold floor 1, then screw you you don't get an orb. They should look at successful games like slay the spire where you at least start with some gold. Then of course by act 3 you have so much gold you are desperately looking for ways to spend it, taking whichever path has the most shops. If you don't mind playing games on easy difficulties then this game isn't so bad but if you feel the need to grind out the harder levels then you should wait until they start thinking about balancing the game.

Peglin is a roguelite by way of Peggle and, thanks to Roundguard, is somehow not the first game I've played with this exact mashup of mechanisms. Just like in Peggle, the core idea is that you need to launch a ball each turn so it falls down a pachinko board and ideally hits as many pegs as possible. Peglin, though, uses those hits to decide how much damage you do to enemies that are advancing towards you. You win each level by defeating those levels and will almost always advance without even getting close to clearing the board.Â 

In theory, most of the fun in Peglin comes from skillfully aiming your shots to hit bombs, refresh orbs, and critical hit markers that boost your shot's damage. In practice, the outlandish behaviors of the more advanced orbs combined with the many relics you'll pick up over the game means that you don't really have much control over what happens after the first bounce. Many later maps have partially or fully hidden boards that make it even more impossible to predict what will happen, so success is realistically mostly about having enough buffs that your ball will bounce around for a while no matter what happens.Â 

Similarly, while the various enemies all theoretically have unique behaviors and attacks, in practice they all seem to be handled pretty well with that same strategy of just having your shots bounce around for as long as possible. Some situations are more or less favorable to bombs and crits, sure, but if your ball bounces around the board for a minute, it'll have hit plenty of both along the way.Â

Fun casual game for those who want something like Peggles but with a twist. 

The update that made you able to collect coins and purchase relics/orbs definitely made the game a lot better. The variation on orbs and relics allows quite a few different playstyles that adds replayability which is neat. 

There's not a lot of variations on the maps, so after a while it becomes very repetitive and you especially the early stages since you get to play them the most. There have been patches that adds new bosses and events, but it's still pretty light on content as it is right now. 

The cruciball challenges adds some more difficulty to the game, however it quickly becomes more of a hassle than fun. I noticed that I restarted quite often because the relics I got were not reliable enough to be able to get through the first stage, which made the first stage more of a chore than anything. Since the cruciball challenges stack, early cruciball challenges that felt fine to play through becomes very cumbersome later on. I like the idea of the cruciball challenges, but how it works right now it forces you to play more and more towards a specific playstyle and not try something different. 

I still find this a great game and have spent many hours figuring out good builds to play with.

This game seems to be prove that Peggle doesn't work as a roguelike.

Far too RNG reliant with its physics that even trying to choose a path is left up to chance due to having to throw the ball into the hole associated with the path which half the time, you won't be able to due to bouncing off pegs in the way so you're forced to go the other path. You even get damaged if you go into the ones with fire which I feel is completely unnecessary post-fight.

I also see only two winning builds and that's it. Bomb focus and crit focus. Everything else, you are guaranteed to lose.

Maybe it will get a little better when they add meta-progression but the game needs some serious rebalancing either way.

Wait for a sale or until the game hits 1.0.

The game is pretty fun overall, and has some interesting orbs and relics to pick from. I've noticed that a lot of the orbs are really underwhelming even in the base game, and that the amount of control you have over which orbs you can use makes it really hard to make things useful, since the ordering is random each time you reload your orbs.

At higher levels of difficulty, the game really starts to break down in an unfun way. Because of how random it is to obtain, use, and deal consistent damage with orbs, you really end up in a situation where you basically need to fish for runs in the first zone to even have a chance of clearing the first boss at all. By this point, almost all orbs are pretty bad, and there are only a few viable options to really choose from.

To make things at higher difficulties even more frustrating, enemy encounters are randomized, and not all of them are equivalently difficult. This applies to both elites and regular combat. Some normal combats simply have far more enemies to work through with no additional support from the board to deal with them. There are some elite counters which will simply be unbeatable on higher difficulties if you happen to run into them.

I think its a good game overall, but it needs a lot of polish and a balance pass that really tries to provide more synergy or support for less powerful builds and combos. I'm not convinced its worth the full asking price with how sparse it is on content, given its a fairly short game, but as they add more content the value for the game will go up.

I am a 47 year old father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my son, who is now 15. My son downloaded Peglin and in less than a week, he had already played for over 11 hours. This was terrible for me, as it was already hard enough for me to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching videos on Tiktok. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, did the tutorial but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought my son and I closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories

The core of the game is good, but the experience of playing in hard mode makes me rate the game negatively. For those of you who haven't bought the game yet, I strongly suggest you wait for the full version and see how others react before deciding whether to buy the game. 

The normal mode of the game is not too difficult for most people, and even too monotonous to make it worth the price. However, the hard mode is just a nasty game that challenges patience and tests your luck. I doubt if the game creators have played the game's hard mode himself. 

Regarding the various imbalances in the game, other reviewers have already mentioned them, so I am not going to mention them again. 

Based on my playing hours and experience, I have reason to believe that the game creators made some unannounced "adjustments" in order to increase the difficulty level. Here are some of the possibilities:

- Starting around level 7 difficulty, the chance of the refresh peg being placed at the bottom or corner of the screen has increased significantly. This means that it is more difficult for players to refreshes all the pegs. 

- Starting around level 7, after defeating the final boss of the forest stage, there is a high chance that the relic given by the system will have side effects, and those side effects will cause a great deal of inconvenience to the player. For example, the relic that removes the only Refresh Peg or Critical Peg from the screen. This forces the player to give up a chance to get a relic. 

- Some useful relics have become very unlikely to appear, such as "Gift That Keeps Giving" and "Kinetic Meteorite".



Game creators, congratulations, you got my first negative review.

I have not played the game before the introduction of the gold system. I like the game so far, it takes the fun twist of pachinko and overlays it over slay the spire-like roguelke.

In my experience the gold system is a positive part of the balance - it adds a lot of fun mechanics with regards to gold, and a trade-off decision making with healing / upgrading / drafting vs saving for a shop ahead.

The negatives as of 0.8.13:
- the crucible system does not feel very balanced, the difficulty step up is very noticeable with the bombs strength falling off, as the HP of act 1 mobs goes up. It is not uncommon for me to get stuck and lose a lot of hp on the early act 1 levels.
- surprise elites in ? is very punishing in act 1, the pathing gets so unpredictable when you encounter an elite on floor 2, and you have no tools to get out of this battle alive
- navigation between floors can really screw you over, and careful planning of the route can go out of the window with a single bad bounce. Min-maxing gold in the navigation also feels too risky, as of today.
- maybe it's the fault of my own, but I kinda figured out 2-3 viable orbs, and I stick to them in every run. Some orbs do not feel very viable / not balanced well, and that hurts discoverability of new strategies.

It is darn fun.

The infinitely replayable nature of this turn based Rouge-Like mean you can play it in the background while watching a new show, maybe some youtube, studying, taxes, housework. This is the game I default to when i need to do something but cant because i need my attention split

I've always been a huge fan of Peggle growing up and it was even the game i used to de-stress when coming out to my parents and this game perfectly captures the feeling while giving it its own flavouring, all of the Relics and Orbs you get will meld in some way to create a familiar and adaptable playstyle that's still unique from run-to-run and the game hasn't hit 1.0 yet! just when I think I've milked all I can, I get roped back in, the recently added shops and currency and now new orbs and relics that affect the currency and how you engage with it adds a new element of self imposed difficulty and advantage.

This is the most fair, fun and addictive version of plinko, with so many cool interactions between you and the enemies e.g. when the spiders hit you (not scary spiders) they make your pegs sticky slowing your ball down, some bosses work their way towards you slowly and affect you majorly when reaching you, putting a time limit on the battle and some will sit at the back sending minions at you and some will even walk up to you and start kicking your shit in and none of them feel unfair because the variety in orbs and relics and how they interact with your enemies allow you to utilise a mix between risk vs reward and genuine strategy.

If i could add anything to the game I'd say maybe cosmetics to further incentivise replayability and the only major need is more level variety, as of this version theres only 3 worlds which is a fine length, i feel like with how powerful the relics are but also the fact that some combos are objectively better means it would be hard to balance but maybe shuffling new worlds into the old mix would give more reason to go back, maybe a snow world where you do extra damage against the more fragile enemies but some of the pegs are made of ice and shatter when hit so you have to plan out how you're gonna tackle the problem rather than blindly shooting for the biggest cluster or refresh peg, It'd give the re-orbiniser and the bouldorb and a lot of the orbs i tend to avoid more utility outside of me having the specific relics or orbs to make them good, maybe the boss could be you breaking though some ice into the water below and a fish is coming up to swallow you and throwing pegs down you have to hit the boss with your orb but the damage still works the same so you're factoring in risk and luck whether you should shoot away from the boss to get more damage and hit it or shoot directly at it but at this point I'm just rambling.

The developers have seemed to bulk up the game's content by continuously adding new orbs and relics, but there have been core balance issues present for months that have gone unaddressed.  Certain encounters (First zone) are near run ending.  Most orbs and relics are unplayable in cruciball, and the pool continually gets bogged down by poorly designed ones each patch.  Though the content is regular, many aspects of the game get worse with each patch.  Fairly simple changes could be implemented to improve player experience alot, but instead the game becomes less fun.  Likely giving up on Peglin due to the current direction.

Peglin is an extremely fun game for RPG and Peggle lovers alike. A roguelike aspect freshens the Peggle formula quite nicely, and ensures that even the same peg layout will usually not play exactly the same twice. Unforunately, as an RPG the game currently falls a little flat. Build variety is low and viable build variety is lower. You can play bombs or multiorb, otherwise you will struggle towards the end of the game. 
There is an update that has been simmering in the oven of this game or a long time promising a selection of classes and greater variety of orbs and bosses. The development team continues to deliver on this piece by piece with new orbs being added at a fair pace and new bosses being slowly introduced. Eventually, this game could be the ultimate Peggle-style experience, but at the moment you can experience all of its content in give-or-take 10 hours.
edit: came back to this some years later and the game is good, so I'm changing to thumbs up.

It's a fun game at its core. The music is great, the game play is fun for most part. What makes me not recommending this game is that is too random. When you get the option for new stuff, orbs and relics, it is out of a completely random selection. At higher difficulties, unless you get exactly the right stuff, it is impossible to beat the game. Part of the problem is that a lot of orbs and relics are trash. When, for instance, you beat the forest boss the choice of high tier relics could just be a platter of trash and you rather skip than taking any of them. Part of the problem here is that some relics have negative side effect, for example you get a damage bonus but you can only aim in four directions. I guess the game is still in devlopment and there is a lot more to do before 1.0 release. The introduction of the store is a great idea, but maybe more choices would be a thing? Or at least you could start the game with the orb of your choice? Rather than a bunch of junk stones that you are going to pay to get rid of as soon a possible? Another problem is that there are too few possibilities to heal, you have to go into a fight to pay to heal, which sometimes comes out to you wasting more HP in the fight than you can heal. Right now it feels that you are lucky when you beat it rather than good at the game.

Original positive review:
I've had a fun time with Peglin so far. Having spent 30+ hours on it in the first week of playing I can't give it other than a positive recommendation. The game would be helped with some additional content and it would be nice if the balance was improved to unlock more successful strategies for building your orb-bag. This is to be expected of an early access game of course and overall, I'd say the game is already worth the price as is.

-----------------------------------------
Edit: I wanted to add this edit now that the game has been developed a few months more. I'm disappointed with what they have done, they have added stuff, but after putting the game aside for a couple of months and returning to it I find that my enjoyment of the game has regressed.

I liked playing this game not because it was a difficult game, but because of the occasional crazy combo's you could pull off. They have added content, but that content does not offer new fun ways to win the game. Instead it has made the runs more vanilla, every run seems to be the same.

1. There are too many vanilla orbs and relics that are offered, which has made it impossible to build a good strategy, because there's just too much 'stuff'
2. Of the strategies that are available, several are not valid. Especially the high risk-reward strategy of using orbs that self-damage is hopeless, because there's simply not enough sustain in the game to compensate for the self-damage that you do.

I usually wouldn't be to bothered by balance in a early access review, but in this case I have changed my recommendation since the balance regression has really taken away from the core of what makes the game fun.

Thought I would grab it and give it a whirl. I really tried liking this game but the gameplay is so dull! It's slow, you don't feel the power of your shots, RNG is an absolute run killer there's now way around it at times, and its quite boring with the lack of variety in what the items offer (Get +15 hp.. yay I guess, how about having 3 different types of pebbles that don't do anything but give more crit damage?)

I just found it kind of boring and long-winded. The coin updates are great, I love the sound effect that plays when you get them. And how it reimagines the gameplay into hitting as many coin pegs as you can as opposed to killing all the enemies. 

I would rather spend a bunch of time working hard on a single level, and maybe failing it. Kind of like a puzzle. Instead of clearing out a whole bunch of levels really fast. I also found something to be desired with the level designs.  I like the first level that shows up, with the curvy bits. Or a lot of the levels with curvy bits in general. I tended not to enjoy the levels that are designed after a shape, or a drawing, I prefer levels that are designed around ball physics and navigating the ball. I also find that the resolution of the spheres wasn't high enough, there weren't enough angles. Like I found the ball and the pegs to be jagged in terms of their collision. In Peggle, the pegs feel more spherical and I feel that adds to the replay value because there are so many different ways to bounce a ball.

EDIT: Ball physics have been fixed. The collision feels smoother now. I like it and have been playing a bit more.

It's always difficult to judge a game in beta, but the rule that I have is to judge what is in front of me for what I spent. $20 for this is too much. There's no sense of progression from run to run other than getting custom starts and unlocking difficulty modifiers. The rooms that you go to aren't particularly numerous, I felt I had seen pretty much everything within 8 hours. The fun part of the game comes with discovering new combos from items and orbs you discover on your run, like when I discovered the interaction between the Reorbanizer and the relic that keeps copies of refresh and crit pegs when they move, or the interaction between the cheese and the buckler, followed by removing all your orbs. Discovering those combos is a lot of fun, but not enough to bolster the short repetitive gameplay. Maybe in a year when there's more content I can change this to a thumbs up, but as it stands I feel like my money would have been better spent elsewhere.

I'm honestly blown away by how great this game is - such a simple concept that ends up being such a massive amount of fun, almost 8 hours in and I'm not bored despite the simplicity. Despite the somewhat random nature of the game, I do genuinely find myself becoming more skilled at playing, and it's fun trying out new tactics and play styles. 

Sometimes I'll have a build that focuses on making the most of board refreshers, other times it'll be reloads, or maybe I'll just hoard as many high power orbs as I can? All of these playstyles feel rewarding, and the others more imaginative people might be able to bring together undoubtedly will too.

If you're on the fence give the demo a go - there's a few differences between it and the final product, but I'd argue that the new changes are for the better.

Ok, So my opinion has changed...sorta.  I ditched the entire review, but I'll leave it up as a post on pastebin dot com/p5L9QfxJ for anyone who wants to see exactly where I changed my opinion.

So this game is a rogue-lite peggle-style combat game where your weapons are the "orbs" you throw into the "pachinko" machine, and you go up against a random selection of monsters and bosses (though the stages themselves seem pretty much hard coded) via a "tree diagram" style navigation.  

There's a few recent changes that make a big difference in how the game plays, and some of that is for the better and some for the worse.  Overall, the only real strategy you can take with this game is choosing relics and orbs to use.  There's a bit of strategy with the navigation too but you can easily find your ball bounce off an orb or a bomb and fly all the way to the other side of the playfield to send you down the path you DIDN'T want to go.

Also, this game moves painfully slow, so if you're the kind of person who likes to watch with bated breath while biting your nails hoping the ball won't fly into the fire at the end navigation screen or whatever, this is your game.  Fortunately there's an option to speed things up, even going farther than I would personally go... 1.5x, 2x, and 3x.  I feel like 2x is the speed the game SHOULD move at, but it's still just a teensy bit too fast in some cases (1.75x?)  but that's personal preference.

It's still Early Access so this could all change.  They've promised different classes and they've made significant changes to the game already, so I may have to update this review again later.  Originally when I started trying to play this game, it was so annoying that I barely could get past the first boss without some kind of really lucky run.  In fact it was mostly the slime boss that gave me trouble because of the peg layout.  Then I managed a REALLY lucky run and made it all the way to the last boss on the third stage (yeah only three stages) and got it to within single digit hitpoints before it ended the game on me.

Honestly, there's still a lot of RNG in this game, and that's kinda frustrating, especially when you know where you want to aim your ball and the game decides "nah, it's gonna bounce back the way it came and hit the opposite side instead".  There's also some relics that seem like a good deal if you don't read the fine print and then you find out that you actually screwed yourself over.  

Basically though, if you pick the right relics and decide on a proper strategy (mostly revolving around number of balls in your satchel) you CAN win the game probably 60% of the time...maybe.  After you win they just try to make the game harder by weakening you, but at least being able to buy balls/relics you can take a bit more control over the outcome.

One of the major changes since the game was released was the addition of currency.  Now you have to buy your new orbs, orb improvements, or health between levels, and they also added a shop in case you decided to stockpile your cash and ignore everything along the way.  I am NOT a fan of the shops.  Most of the time I have less than 25Gold (which is the minimum price for orbs) and so I wind up wasting a navigation spot without getting ANYTHING out of it.  

So basically, there's 5 kinds of rooms you can enter: an enemy room (skull and cross bones), a TOUGH enemy room (Red Skull and Cross bones), a random event room (marked by a question mark), a Treasure room (Marked by a chest), and now a Gold shop (Marked by a G in a circle).   You choose where to go by shooting your ball toward the icon at the bottom of the screen, and god help you if there are pegs in your way.

Weak enemy rooms give you a chance to earn more gold by hitting pegs with a yellow dot in it, strong enemy rooms give you the chance to pick an extra relic, question mark rooms give you any of the other rooms or some special event, Treasure rooms give you a choice of relics, and gold shop gives you the chance to buy a large number of balls or relics as long as you have gold to pay for it.   Oh and there's some secret treasure chests if you destroy all the bombs in the between navigation screen.  Hard to do without a combination of other relics but nice when it works.

It also seems like every stage has at least two bosses so there's a bit of replay value left there.  Other than that this is a pretty casual game, and it also works great on the steam deck (most of the time).  In fact Steam Deck is where most of my recent playtime has come from.  I don't really enjoy playing it at the computer as much.  

The part where this goes from a bad review to good is in knowing what to skip.  Pick the wrong relic and the game is ruined.  You might as well quit and start over.  Skip the relic altogether and maybe you'll get something decent later on?  Hopefully skipping the relic won't hurt you.  Likewise, once you know how some relics work, you might want to avoid buying new orbs.  I found there's some relics that increase your stats every reload, but if you have a ton of orbs in your satchel, you may only get to reload once in battle before it's over and that's not much of a benefit.

Really this isn't a full thumbs up.  It would be a meh thumb if it existed, but that's better than the thumbs down it used to be.  Right now the cons are: RNG, only 3 stages vs mild strategy and casual gameplay for the pros.  (Casual gameplay would be a con if you're looking for something more serious, but then the RNG would be a turnoff there too).   So my advice is to buy it on sale or follow the game to see when it gets more updates so that there's more content.  It's a 6/10 game at the moment, but hopefully it'll get better before it leaves early access.

Fun game but one change that the devs should make is making the refresh peg move every turn just like the crit peg. Once you get to the point where you only have one refresh peg, in the higher crucibles levels where it takes more turns to do things, there becomes moments where you literally cannot refresh the board no matter what and lose purely because of the spawn location of the refresh peg behind some object due to bad luck. One example is the "wall" boss board on the second map, where the top pegs are unbreakable and block lines of sights. Don't get me wrong, this game involves mostly a lot of luck as with most rougelikes, but dying because you have no pegs left to hit and an unreachable refresh peg feels unfair and frustrating since it destroys the most bare mechanic of the game. They currently have the refresh peg moving as a relic for some reason, which turns a quality of life feature that would remove rare but unavoidable game-ruining moments into a very underwhelming relic.

This game suffers from some serious lack of consistency. I rarely feel like I died due to my own mistakes, and even when I do it's because I chose an item that seems at first to be useful but ends up completely ruining my build, because a ton of items seem interesting, such as limiting the directions you can aim, but in practice they just make things less interesting and ruin your run.

Enemy mechanics in some cases are fun and interesting, like the shield guys in the castle, but a lot of them, especially bosses, just seem designed to require pure luck to get past. The Minesweeper style boss in the caves looked really cool at first but then I realized that the way the pegs are structured is impossible to get a good set of bounces off on to maximize damage to take out the whopping 6500 frigging health points it has when it is constantly spewing out more enemies and is dealing increasing amounts of damage to me over time. Even if I got 500 damage a turn, (without overflow or piercing), he feels like he'd still kill me from full HP, and 500 damage a turn is something I've only consistently averaged with god-builds from runs that didn't screw me over.

I thought we were over this random luck nonsense with roguelites? I thought we figured out how to make good ball physics like twenty odd years ago when Peggle was a thing? Why does this game somehow fail to be a satisfying bounce ball of pegs game and a frustrating roguelite?

I initially gave this a bad review for the lack of depth thanks to no economy and it's initial lack of a difficulty curve making choices extremely obvious. Now that we have a lot of Cruciball and an economy, I feel the need to update this review.

The game is still chaotic. I struggle to say it's a particularly strategic game. It's not Slay the Spire where you really dig down into how to build a deck and deviate interesting directions based on what you get methodically. That being said, it's got it's own appeal to it as a passive game and what they did add addressed a lot. Boss variety and enemies variety over time has been made to account for throwing a wrench in strategies, as well as Cruciball modifiers changing up what you do. The money aspect especially adds a lot if not strategy than at least decisions. Now you don't just cross your fingers after battle hoping you get an upgrade instead of a new orb, removing orbs is no longer exclusive to "?" events, and now you don't just 90% of the time chuck the ball directly into a direction to end a level. I always found the end navigation by way of peggle cute, but pointless because it was very rare you'd risk ending up in the wrong well. Now you get to go for coins. Now you don't necessarily just finished a battle off in 1 shot, you find time to go for coins. 

It's getting significantly better and I fully recommend it now. I just have my fingers crossed multiple characters turns out just as good, but am also hesitant they might go the easy route and just make minor starting item differences rather than Slay the Spire style where each character has access to vastly different cards.

I first purchased this game for $20 on release back in April 2022 and honestly thought it wasn't very good for that price. Since then the dev has made MANY updates and upgrades and additions to the game, really rounding out the experience. Goblin peggle roguelike

It's so painfully close to being a great game but the devs are merging Peggle, the casualist of casual games, with Roguelikes, the corest of core games, and went too far in the core direction for the chaos of peggle gameplay to feel rewarding. 

The physics make no sense, you can never tell if a bounce will launch a ball across the entire stage or if it will make it lose all momentum and start falling straight down till it is out of the map. What balls do is too over complicated for the random gameplay. Dropping a ball on the side of the stage to choose a map direction is pointless and doesn't add to the fun, it just gives you an opportunity to fuck up your idea of where you want to go. Coins were a pointless over complicated addition from previous versions. 

When you launch a ball you cannot predict what will happen past the first bounce, yet you have to do well or else your run will soon be restarting and everything you built up is lost, destroying the excitement of building up in future runs

The game should have gone with an escalating difficulty levels system of progression like angry birds or.... peggle...., not roguelike. 

I want to be able to recommend it but just can't. Every time I play all I can think is that the dev built what they could, and didn't stop to ask if they should.

You can just save your money for the things you actually want - and if you really want something specific, you can prioritise shops on the map too.

Unfortunately liking the game way less than I thought I would, going from the demo.

Once you get a run going itÂ´s a bit limiting still, but then there are enough synergies and different map and enemy modifiers that the game can be fun.

But everything before that is way too slow, way too rng, and way too tedious and boring. 
You start with 3 stones and no clear way to get rid of them, if at all it will be long after the difficulty starts ramping, there barely starts to be a synergy between the different orbs you pick until way too late in the game. Infact, the different orbs barely have any synergies anyways, yes they change the board a bit...but itÂ´s not like that is much of a strategy. Right? I only barely can choose the orb that I need for the situation and then the next, thatÂ´s not strategy for me. What gets hit is way too rng to stack effects as well. So I just end up with a bunch of random orbs that leave so much stuff that I am bound to hit some random stuff eventually, but that is bruteforcing, not strategic thinking about crosseffects or specific setups against the next encounter. And there is not much game left anyways, itÂ´s 3 maps and you need until the end of the second to get something resembling a "strategy" going (hurrdurr I go multiorb, bombs and healorb). So the unfun parts get drawn out over and over again and the fun part ends in basically oneshots for 1 map. ItÂ´s positive vs negative difficulty and as of now this game chooses wrong: It makes you weak with no way of having much gameplay impact because the options you have are so limiting and later on you are so strong that you basically oneshot half of  the fights. Meanwhile difficulty should mean that the maps/fields/orbs are giving you so many options for meaningful plays WHILE the enemies are a meaningful challenge that YOU get to outplay them. And the challenge should rise with the playerpower.

And the playing fields, I appreciate the modifiers on them (black holes/mirror effects) but those only start ramping in the endgame too. For most of your early fights you have super boring fields where you waste whole turns just to RNG your way to hit a reset. And starting with 3 stones and one crit orb multiplies the boredom of basically having to clear fields, when neither the board nor the orbs you have do anything interesting. So you are either reliant on rng giving you a map where hitting the reset is viable to ramp up damage, or where you are reliant on the crit multiplier to be in a useable spot to hit exactly one enemy. Half of your shots are completely wasted just trying to get to either of them or them spawning at a completely unusable spot on the field. 

ItÂ´s not even about difficulty at this point with the negative dmg modifiers for your stones in the beginning. ItÂ´s about how long it takes to create a playable field, the beginning phase is way too long, too tedious, too boring, to rng heavy to be fun. The game needs to ramp up way quicker, give more customizability from the start, stones should be at best a decision that you wanna play with them (maybe they become stronger the more you have, maybe give better multiplier trinkets whatever) and not a way to limit early game power with boredom because of how little versatility they have in their useage.

Also shops are beyond pointless. I can already buy orbs after fights, I get trinkets from bosses and random chests, I can upgrade only with money or encounters...so shops are only good for getting rid of orbs, ONCE PER SHOP. So the game asks me to save up money, aka do not buy more interesting orbs, so that I can have a chance of getting rid of ONE stone at a shop...it honestly should be the other way around. After a fight you get to lose something boring to make the game more interesting BECAUSE you chose to engage with it and THEN the shops should provide you with ways of stacking synergies, not just another extra orb that might or might not even come to any meaningful use in the next fights.

In summary: Instead of making me weak and plain, make the challenges more interesting and the maps ramping up faster. DonÂ´t create difficulty by simply nerfing me to make me more weak and plain boring, but buff enemies and have more stuff going on. Give me more options to save a throw so there is more strategy aspects at play, never ever should there be a point in the game where something like: Throw orb *dink 3 dmg Throw orb *dink 17 dmg, throw orb *dink 4 dmg throw orb *endless stuff happening that goes way beyond the enemies health-threshold and getting nothing for it. Every throw should be meaningfully contributing and the player should always be challenged to use a strategic value for every throw instead of treading rng hell.

Editing for shop update as of 12-1:

Shop helps the randomocity be a little lesser, and actually allows you to get builds. There's still just a sheer amount of orbs in the game that you can STILL go many entire games without seeing an orb. It's a lot harder to than before, so it's a step in the right direction. It's an improvement. 

Peg bounciness feels like it was cranked to 11 with a complete disregard for any type of physics. Have shot my ball in the exact same spot multiple times, and received different results despite the board having no changes. Not sure what they did behind the scenes, but it's incredible how differently the orbs are acting after this update.  

Still can't recommend in good faith. Cruciball is super hard, but they said it was because they're still working on it, so we'll let that pass. But yeah, still think you should wait on this. 

Editing For Balance Pass on 9-28: 

Lots of changes happened, trying to make some orbs better and some builds more fun. I think this pass was definitely a step in the right direction, but ultimately not enough for specifically the shielded enemies. It's just insane to me that we offer bombs on a map for shielded enemies but the bombs, even if you multi-orb and hit every single one of them, only take the shield down to about 1/3 health, and you still have to crush through it while enemies are slinging arrows and magic and healing. I know what you're probably thinking "What about piercing damage, bouldorb or worbhammer?" I had worbhammer, couldn't get to the singular refresh though to make it do more than about 40 damage. Was never offered a bouldorb or icircle. Hopefully when they start releasing classes or addressing the sheer volume of orbs in the game this improves. For now, still gotta leave it at a thumbs down because we're still in supremely unfun territory in the cruciball. There's no difficulty factor, it's just plain unfair enemies that the board doesn't offer enough variety on to allow you to take them out.

The physics engine for how pegs bounce has always been a pile of hot garbage. Lately it seems worse than ever, but maybe thatâ€™s just the advent of shields in the second area. Certain relics that cause pegs to act differently are the most inconsistent thing. Electro peg net and itâ€™s orb come to mind for how wonky they are. In prior updates it was fun wonk with some frustration, but lately it feels like the peg net is designed to force your ball into the wall or down to the bouncers. The cruciball itself and its added challenge arenâ€™t horrible, giving some good difficulty.  The problem comes from how inconsistent everything is. Builds feel like they get nerfed every single update so that one shots are only possible if you get exact perfect luck. As if battles are trying to be drawn out into long slugfests. 

Orb variety is starting to get a little bit insane in that you might not see a specific orb type the entire game. I just finished one where multiorb didnâ€™t exist until the spot before the act3 boss. I had a build where multiorb wouldâ€™ve been insanely strong. But it just didnâ€™t exist. Sure, thatâ€™s part of the randomness of a rogue like. But when I get offered a swoltorb and every other battle it just feels like something isnâ€™t quite right.

Fun pachinko, STS-style, deckbuilding game. The concept is really solid and I can't wait to play the final version. I was pleasantly surprised with the updates the devs have been releasing.

However, there are a few issues with the game that are causing me to not want to play it in its current state.

1. Balancing - So many of the orbs are straight up bad. They seem to mostly just have a random grab bag of effects and it doesn't feel like you can really make a cohesive "theme". If you do, they are usually pretty bad anyway. One in particular is "self-damage". While there are tons of orbs and artifacts which inflict self-damage, there is very little healing in the game. There's just 3 healing orbs, two of which are usable once per battle, and one of them which deals increasing self-damage every time it is used. And it's possible that they won't even be offered during your run at all. You can heal yourself once after every battle, but it is expensive (costs as much as upgrading or buying an orb) and you only heal for 20%. 

Disregarding the self-damage, healing in general is very weak and feels somewhat frustrating. In most battles, taking damage is completely unavoidable. You often suffer a slow attrition of HP throughout the stage, get to the boss, then get instakilled from a large hit. It feels bad to lose this way. Not even STS is this stingy with healing effects.

2. Currency - I did like the update that introduced coins. It gives us something to farm during the battles and we get to choose whether we want to end the battle quickly, or farm. However, it could still use some tweaking. I'm finding that I NEVER have any coins saved up for the merchant, as I am always using them on upgrading/adding orbs, or healing (which always feels bad to have to do). I would prefer upgrading/adding orbs to be free like they were previously, but being able to use the coins at the merchant. Right now, there's no reason you would really want to save for the merchant, so it feels like a useless stop. Adding/upgrading orbs and healing is just too important.

3. Level design - Maybe this is just me, but I feel like a good amount of stages have very awkward design, which don't allow very much bouncing. As a result, many stages just feel frustrating to play. When you play a pachinko/brick breaker-style game, you really expect to see that satisfying bounce.

4. Path selection - This is the BIGGEST one for me. I absolutely hate the path choosing system. This alone is the reason I give up runs and stop playing more than anything else. For those who don't know, at the end of each fight/event, you have to shoot your ball through the pachinko again and whichever side it lands on is the path you take. It feels SO bad to carefully choose your path, only for you to encounter some unavoidable obstacle or random bounce that changes your path completely. I can't even tell you the amount of times I have rage quit after being denied a path with a treasure chest or 2 to a random bounce making me go in the complete wrong direction. It is the most anti-fun part of the game and is the main reason I only have only 14 hours on this game despite buying it back in August. I know it seems trivial, but I'm sure I'm not the only one who feels this way.

All that being said, the game has entertained me, and I did have fun playing it. I believe that it has the potential to be great, so I will still give a thumbs up in hopes that the devs will take the feedback to heart and release an awesome final product.

TLDR; Peglin boasts a good gameplay loop with a neat base and an active dev that has more coming down the pipeline, pick it up and give it a few runs and see if you are charmed by this game like I was.

I have seen a few reviews saying that this game is too short to justify the price, and although I can understand that; I overall think that this game holds long term value because the gameplay loop is enjoyable. Considering this game is still in active development and I can see that the developer is receptive and ready to tackle any issues, the future of this game seems very bright. I must admit, after a few runs you will feel like you have seen most of the game, but I think this is just because of how this game is still being developed. In my opinion, this game is great for ending a tough or long day and want something to play while you watch a show or video and want to keep your mind on instead of turning it completely off for the day. If you want something to dive super deep into like you can with slay the spire or the like; Peglin is not there yet, but I believe that with the things that are planned to be launched will bring a larger variety to the gameplay and replayability.

Update: Coins and shop update adds some more fun and save-ability to a run, still recommended.

TLDR: I've immensely enjoyed my time with Peglin, and I expect you would too.

EDIT: A lot of other reviews complaining about the currency system probably played it the day the update launched. Prices have been fixed, you now get more items/upgrades than before and I dont aim for currency at all. It's really not nearly as bad as people are saying. Runs have way more control than before and you're picking more orbs/upgrades per game. 

After some updates this game has gotten incredible, and I know a few things that are planned and will greatly improve the game IE peglin classes for more build variety.

The amount of builds in this is crazy. This game is a GREAT mix of puzzle game and roguelike.

Before, most of the builds you could "build" was basically just get a couple of good orbs and some good relics and you'll just stomp.

Now, you have a bit more control over your run, more artifacts add more interactions. I think practically every single tiny artifact has some synergy somewhere. If it's something more than "+1 damage on non crits" you're going to find synergy somewhere, plus +damage is never bad. 

A great example of a synergy I accidentally came across was the bully orb (+1/+2 damage per self inflicted damage), I had a few orbs that did like 2-5 damage to myself when I shoot them so I thought that was the only source I could buff it from.
I didnt really get any insane use out of it but eventually I came across an artifact choice after a mini boss, the only good item for my build was x2 damage but take 3 damage every 15 pegs you hit in combat. Bully orb completely not on my mind because the x2 damage was incredible elsewhere. Then I got to the next mini boss and pulled the bully orb LAST in my first round and it was doing something like 23-36 damage per peg, which is ABSOLUTELY insane, for reference, the rocks you start with do 3-5, aka 3 damage per peg on a normal hit and 5 per peg on a crit. 36 damage per peg is bonkers.

This game is crazy. The music is great. Castle boss fight is literally crash bandicoot theme song x dueling banjos and it gets stuck in my head every time I play this game.

I buy roguelites to experience the different synergies and randomness inside of each run. Winning a run is cool and all, but It's not the end of this games content by any means. Don't judge the amount of content here by the number of levels.

If you only want to play a game to see the ending "You Win" Screen, then the price tag for this game may be too high in it's current state. However, I played over 10 hours of the demo alone and loved it. Try out the demo and see what you think, It will be pretty clear if this game is for you or not.

Peglin is one of the most unique games that I have ever played, the gameplay is simple yet satisfying. While this game is still under development, changes are being made to the core gameplay loop which can be frustrating if you've already learned the mechanics of the game and then they change. However, I believe that the most recent coin-collecting changes that were implemented complement the game really well and I think that it's a solid fit.

Peglin is full of roguelike elements and each run will be different from the last, while giving you as the player plenty of control over how your game plays out. You are given choices for adding new balls to your roster or upgrading ones you already own. The game is challenging and rewarding, also it's quite appealing visually and the sound design is satisfying.

If you've watched the trailer and seem even somewhat interested in what Peglin is trying to accomplish, then you won't regret buying it and trying it because it's a well polished game that will keep you entertained. Roguelike level generation and item distribution keep the experience exciting, I can see myself playing Peglin for years to come and I'm looking forward to seeing the future updates that the developers release.

Peggle and Roguelite combined.

At times everyone needs some simple game for a relatively relaxing experience. Sure, Peglin is still a Roguelite, in the same vein as FTL and Slay the Spire, but the idea of slowly progressing and doing that little bit better (or worse) each time has some calming effect.

Much like many Roguelites it does seem to have some balancing issues, adding content semi-frequently. Quantity over quality seems to be the case.

If you need something new to play within the sub-genre and loved the old-school Peggle this is a don't miss!

This game is really fun!  It looked interesting when I saw it in a let's play video a few months ago and decided to wait for it to go on sale, but after a few play-throughs, I'm kind of annoyed at myself for not just getting it then.  It already has great replayability, and once more playable characters (presumably with slightly different play styles) are added, it will have even more.  The art is simple but cute, the music is easy to hum along to, it plays pretty quickly.

The tutorial is incredibly limited and is only displayed in your first game, so you should be prepared to have a rough time in your first few games as you learn how to play beyond the very most basic level.  Once you get past that initial steep learning curve, though, it's just very fun.

balls pegs monsters

This game saved my life.

I am 36.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and adopted our son together. They are now both 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I found myself lost and miserable. I was self destructive. I got so mad one day from everything spiraling out of my control that I punched some concrete in a moment of overwhelming emotion. That caused me to break my 5th metacarpal in my right hand... my working hand... my games hand.. the hand that I held and carried my children to bed with.. The hand I desperately needed to make sure I could continue to provide.

After learning of the severity of my self-inflicted damage, I was borderline suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man with no history of depression or anxiety. I have never had fits of rage, or been one to break down and cry, but I was in a low spot that just really buried me from being able to see the light on the other side.

Having nothing better to do, I searched for a game I could play, ONE HANDED while I recovered. I somehow stumbled upon this game and read some of the reviews. I decided that it had to be worth a shot... I must admit, I didn't beat the game, or play nearly as long as some of you. In fact, I may have only played this game a day or two.. With that being said, after doing so, I had a new found joy and hope for life. I was able to put behind me the pain and suffering that had been cast over me. I was able to experience other peoples joy and happiness. I was able to see the fruits of my "labor". I relaxed for 5 â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ing minutes to this music long enough to realize that I was going to be okay.

After coming to that realization, I turned the game off, and I went back to work. It hurt my hand like hell but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so damn sorry for myself, and I became the father I needed to be in that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving as.

Today, I am close friend with my kids mother. We don't fight, or argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents, and friends.

I now have 3 kids. My third child is, wait for it, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my own separation, and we just stumbled in to each others life unexpectedly. We have been in a relationship for a year now, and are very happy together.

Moral of the story, you never know what life holds in store for you, and if I would have given up when all the odds were stacked against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you.

**Update** Good first steps to correcting new imbalance. Devs, an idea for you: Make it to where we can do a short rest and long rest. Short rests are free and recover a bit less HP, like 15%, where a long rest would cost the 25 gold and recover something like 33% to 50%. Percentages may vary, of course, but it still feels overly punishing to have to pay gold to recover even a minor amount of health and really pushes making sure you have the healing relics even if they're not normally part of the way you play. A split recovery system would let you have at least some kind of reward if you're saving gold and/or dissatisfied with the orbs presented and would still allow for a higher difficulty level. Changing recommendation due to responsiveness of devs to correct imbalance. Core gameplay remains awesome!

been playing the game for a while and have plenty of failed and succeeded runs. the addition of coins both made it easier to get a snowball effect if you're already powerful, and a bit easier to recover from a tight spot (with enough coins). They're pretty plentiful and all over the board. getting them isn't hard, and it just means you're hitting more pegs honestly. You use the coins to heal, purchase new orbs, and upgrade orbs, which, you can both purchase and upgrade multiple times in one ending screen.

I guess it makes it a bit of a detriment if you're trying a super specific type of build that requires precision...but all my builds I usually end up just trying to hit everything, everywhere, all at once. so to me, it is a great boon. I guess others hate the coin addition. it just made it a bit closer to slay the spire.

Really the change that I would make to the coin system, make the first choice you do at the end of the level a free choice, and everything after that would end up costing the coins you've been gathering. I just feel like that would make it a tad bit more forgiving in the very beginning.

This game is a great idea, executed very well. The gameplay is an enjoyable blend of skill and luck, with everything down to the movement being designed around the core gameplay. I love games that attempt to use their charming aspect as much as they can and Peglins does this wonderfully. I hope to see more updates coming in the future as the game does lack balancing. Before the coins update it was sometimes hard to win unless you went for an optimal strategy every time. However now I played a run to have fun with some of the new relics and it was really easy to win. This is because of the abundance of coins in the mid game meaning i could buy and fully upgrade an orb in 1 encounter. This made it too easy as the lack of random shitty orbs in your inventory is now gone. Plus there are still balancing issues from previos relics and orbs like the cookie makes health a construct that doesnt effect you if you dont want it to. These things can be shifted and worked on over time, with either the encounters getting a difficulty bump, or a nerf of the powerful relics. It will be fun to see where this project goes in the future, and will be following it all the way until release!

A peggle like roguelite game where you hit pegs to do damage to enemies and bosses. The content is kinda bare for the price but it is still pretty mindless fun, and I'm sure they will add more in the future.

Edit: Editing for the steam awards. They've continued to update and they added coins so now instead of pure upgrades you have to have gold to do anything. That change is weird, its like every item room is a shop. I wouldn't mind a dedicated shop somewhere in each floor/run but every pickup having gold attached to it feels weird. Gold is not hard to get by any means but it's just a strange change to me.

First off- yea, pick up the game. Read the bottom though for a quick TLDR

Well, I played it for about an hour, and beat it on the very first run. This game doesn't really offer any challenge to overcome. You become incredibly strong pretty quick. I got a total of 5 or so orbs in my "deck" and was dealing 1-4k damage every hit.

Basically grabbed everything related to bombs.

They did add some "New Game +" mode, but it's very much just "make the game harder." Which it should of been already.

Currently refunding the game as it is really fun, but currently lacks heavily in content and can be nearly explored in one 60m run. Would love to have most relics and balls locked behind achievements and to see stuff locked behind the cruciball modes. At least make it so I feel like there's progression and rewards for completing things.

You already have everything unlocked to begin with, so removing that stuff NOW will just upset people. Classes are coming, which can be a reward after completions, but PERSONALLY, that isn't enough to pull my attention.

To kinda TLDR this thing;
The game is pretty easy and everything seems to be unlocked from the start. It's great for a quick experience as I got, but doesn't seem to give any challenges beyond completing your first run. Give it a play because the concept is amazing and satisfying, but you'll also probably be able to refund after you beat it <3

A long overdue and welcome return to Peggle-style pachinko tomfoolery, but now in rogue-like form, because 2022. I kid of course, the roguish elements have snapped into focus as of the November patch, and really are starting to justify themselves nicely. Balance is still all over the place though, some powerups need buffing, some are too powerful, and some reduce the game to an incoherent mess of randomness (looking at you, magnets), but all of them are optional and will likely be improved in time. Peglin still has some growing up to do, but it's reached a point where I can unreservedly recommend it, the core gameplay loop is already compelling enough to keep my interest for hours at a time, and there's more to come.

A solid Rogelite that will be a staple of the genre given it gets the content. 

If you like Roguelites and peggle/pachinko this will be right up your alley. 

You fight enemies in a turn based style and you use a variety of orbs which you collect and add to your deck on your run to hit pegs on a board which builds your damage. As you progress you receive relics which buff you in some way to aid you in making builds. 

Like other games in the genre, there is an element of rng at play, but dont let other reviews fool you into thinking that the rng dictates your run. If you have played games like Isaac, Gungeon etc we all know that these elements are the core of games like this. Peglin is no different. The way that you play, the items, balls and upgrades you choose all affect your run. There are a tonne of bonkers synergies and the game gives you plenty of choices throughout to give you opportunities to succeed. I would argue that there are only a couple of balls or relics that are somewhat lacklustre, everything else gives you a solid set up. 

The game as it stands currently is somewhat limited in regards to general progression. All of the items are unlocked to begin with so there's not as much sense of achievement as there are in similar games where you unlock more as you progress. I imagine this will change with time. Currently for beating the game, you unlock something called the "Cruciball" these are additional difficulty settings that stack as you win on each level of it. The game gets quite hard with these enabled overall but it's still manageable. Overall the game itself on the default difficulty is light, fun and easy. You can also drop the game at any point and pick up your run any time. 

Overall, the game is really solid and will be a stand out within the genre of roguelikes given it keeps receiving the consistent updates and content that it has been. It's really fun and the devs are constantly working on it as of this moment. I boot up the game every couple of weeks to see what's been added which keeps me coming back (Given I've beaten all of the cruciball levels)

Added note; The game updated adding a shop mechanic that balances a lot of the issues that people have/had with the game wherein there is a lot more player control now!

It's an early access game, so much of what I'm going to say here is probably not going to be relevant, but I don't tend to edit my reviews after I make them, so y'know... It's whatever. 

I like the game, a neat little peggle roguelike, very simplistic in what it does, and is basically exactly what it is trying to be. While I like the game, I feel at a $20+ price tag, I'd expect a *lot* more out of the game. 

As it is you have 3 levels with 3 bosses, only a handful of maps, and maybe a couple dozen artefacts and orbs to use. You can basically beat the game and effectively interact with 90% of the events and boards within your first run. Which now brings me to variety, as there are only maybe 2 or 3 practical builds to use to make any significant progress in a run, everything else you build is ultimately just a meme that won't even beat a few slimes. 

I understand this is an early access game, but with such a short game, no story, limited items, and no unlocks, it's weird that it would be released even as early access, especially at the price it is. Maybe a few months down the line they will have more content, and I'd say then it would be worth it, as is, I feel like unless you are very easily entertained at repeat tasks, the game is maybe only an hour of content for you if even that. 

I like the game for what it is, as it does what it intends to do well, but it is very limited in content, so I recommend it with the caveat I don't actually recommend you get it until it has more content.

It's peggin time

Money system changed the game for the better. There is more player choice and agency than before. It certainly needs to be balanced out a bit better and maybe have differing costs per ball, scaling cost of healing, artifacts and balls that synergize with money in some way- but it's an update in the right direction.

It still suffers from feature bloat and a bit of balance issues (the overwhelming majority of balls and artifacts are shit, and the one that remain break the game), but the devs are changing how the game works while listening to feedback and I trust the game will only improve over time.

I personally like it and would recommend, but for the majority of players, I won't recommend it, being in the current state at the current price point. Wait for sale if the screenshots didn't excite you.

[h1] Great Update! [/h1]

I was on the fence whether or not to recommend this game for a while, but with the most recent update, it is a clear thumbs up! Now with the addition of gold and shops you can better shape your build by purchasing and removing specific orbs from your arsenal. Looking for a specific build after getting a lucky relic early on? Well now you can save up gold, find those perfect orbs, and immediately upgrade it all the way with the saved up money. 

I couldn't tell you how many runs had great potential before the update but were dragged down by having the starting stones in my deck. Now I'm not afraid of having inconsistent DPS at the end of the game because I can route to shops when needed. 

New levels of Cruciball have also been added that give more of a challenge to experienced Peglin players. Very happy I withheld my review until the game was further developed. 

Excellent job on evolving this from a cute little arcade game to something I will sink many more hours into!

Unreasonable stage 1 regular enemy much stronger than elites, unreasonable trash marbles, totally negative events, and many more very frustrating enemies you know you are totally screwed upon seeing... Update after a recent major update: 
After enough hrs of the gameplay, I think it's fair to say the devs definitely don't have a labour to play their game at all. I can give a few suggestions based on their game logic: 
1. The forest slime boss in the cruciball, it's better to give it instead of 900 HP, let it be 9000, and it's even better to delete the refresh peg given that often you can't hit it anyways. Intuitively, since the mucus resembles a shield, give this boss a defence that equals the mucus peg count as well. For the players to win, give it a slime core that deals 100% true dmg. Certainly this core is surrounded by layers of mucus and always drifts to the opposite side, but at least it's winnable so stop being a wuss.
2. The inverted elite, HP=9116 seems fair, and definitely the blackholes are too few while the pegs are too many. It's even better that only one refresh peg is allowed and be tightly surrounded by 4 blackholes so the player always smiles while trying to hit it. Redesign the config so the player can hit max 5 pegs each time with a 3-sigma confidence level. Certainly it's the players fault if they don't find enough bramballs to stop it.
2.5. Shield wizard needs some real magic: to numb/freeze/shock/blind the peglin so he has enough time to shield multiple layers on all the pegs. Can't one hit him? The weak shouldn't fight then.
3. The final crystal goblin boss, what's its name again? I suggest it only gives players 3 pegs to hit: refresh, crit and red bomb. Better yet, upon hit once, the red bomb disappears forever and good luck to find the cheese and round guard with one marble at hand on the way there.
4. This game is not challenging enough, please introduce an inflation system that never cuts short. It's too mild now. Also, who tells this green creature to avoid tax? A 20% VAT looks legit. Heal system is way too friendly as well, since ideally once injured, our cute peglin is weakened instead of strengthened, unless equipped with relics, of course.
5. Boss relic is full of strong ones and is not compulsory as some negative events are. Negative events are not enough either. A genius idea combines the two as sort of a synergy: A compulsory relic after forest/castle guarantees only negative events encounters, and all route choice is a forced RNG, so in the end this despicable peglin ends up with a full hand of terriballs and barely any HP before the next boss fight.

Embrace the actuality, peglin :)

This game is a fantastic little roguelike with a unique combat system and the dopamine hits of a pachinko machine. However, it currently has mixed reviews as of November 18th because a large update just fundamentally changed the secondary gameplay loop. As expected, some people are resistant to change, but I genuinely believe it was a good update that many of those people will come around to once they're used to how things work now.

So what was this divisive update? Goblin capitalism, that's what. Numerous pegs on each combat board now contain a little coin that will gratifyingly *ping* when popped. Previously, after combat, you were randomly given the option to pick one of three random orbs, or the option to upgrade an existing orb (or in either one you could opt to heal instead). Now you're presented all three options after every combat, but you need to pay gold for each service you use. Haglin has also set up his shop finally, offering orbs, relics, and a removal service for some gold as well.

You're no longer at the complete mercy of RNG to upgrade your orbs. You now see more orbs in the post-battle rewards per run since they always appear. You can buy an orb after battle and then instantly upgrade it to max level if you have the gold for it, where previously it would take at least two combats (and RNG to get two upgrades in a row) before maxing your new toy. And possibly the biggest upside of this is that your post-battle rewards never feel wasted. If you're on max HP and don't want any orb you're offered, then you just save your gold so you might be able to grab two orbs in the future, or an upgrade + a heal, or get to Haglin and get him to remove one of your useless basic stones. The game is now far more flexible and makes your between fight decision-making more meaningful, while retaining the gambling-esque nature of the roguelike genre.

Really oversold itself early and has slow and generally has a  neutral or bad update schedule. You don't realize how low the replay value is until you have passed the 2 hour mark and and cannot return it. Really cool concept just not fleshed out enough to justify price tag.

I enjoy Peglin a lot! The different relics and orbs allow for some crazy good synergies. I manage to get a fun build going most of the times, but if a build falls flat, it crashes hard - that's the only downside for me. 

Updates have been a bit slow, but they released the shop and currency update just recently. It took me a bit to get used to the new mechanics (I played about 50 hours without them), but now I enjoy them.

Buying orbs gives a bit more control to the player. Before the update you had to hope for good RNG, which was frustrating if the orbs did not fit your build. That being said, the currency system is not without flaws either. If you are missing 1 gold to get the orb you want, it feels frustrating, too. However, I prefer it to the old system, because of the slightly more control you have. The prices of the orbs are transparent, so you always know how much they will cost in advance.

I am writing this review after the new currency and shop update. I can see where many people may not like it. I think it definitely takes away from the original game play loop but in turn gives you a more consistent experience. I went from not being able to complete cruciball 1 to in two games completing cruciball 1 and 2. 

If you like Peggle/Pachinko style games and also enjoy Roguelites. The game is worth buying.
It is a very addicting game that clearly has tons of potential, and it's not even a fully-fledged game yet and it is immensely fun

EDIT EDIT: The new currency system really solves a lot of the games issues - Now theres a nice balance of wanting to get through an encounter cleanly, and trying to focus on money for upgrading or trying to get a solid inventory. A real step in the right direction. Some more content would be nice, but I'm glad that a major issue has been addressed. Changing to recommended for now.

EDIT: Speed up options are a good start , and some rubbish encounters have been cleaned up a bit. However, there is now a new wave of relics which hint at mechanics that the game just doesn't deliver on (or need). For example, Muscircle and Spinesse, which increase damage by +X to either crit or damage, already exist on other items - These new relics provide nothing unless you manage to fulfil requirements that the game still doesn't really let you meet. Upgrading and getting new orbs is still complete random, and you still get runs where you get nothing but one or the other. A lot of new orbs seem to the same thing existing orbs do. A step in the right direction, but still needs a lot of polish. Cruciball still sucks, stop filling my inventory with crap instead of trying to come up with a real challenge.

A great idea trapped in a web of poor design and frustrating encounters. 

I love that the game lets you go for utterly daft builds. That's great, more rogue-likes need to let you have absolutely ridiculous runs. Nothing beats throwing a multi-orb with the multi-orb item and having 10 orbs flying around. Throwing hundreds of bombs in one turn is hilarious. Relics are nice and varied, with only a few being absolutely pointless. Good variety of orbs, but currently the game seems to be balanced around anything piercing - If you don't have any of them by act 2, or at least a consistent way of hitting bombs, you're probably out. I can see this game being great fun with a LOT of work. 

Onto the bad - Everything takes far too long, enemies have to move one at a time, attack one at a time, projectiles move one at a time. It's not like you can react to any damage coming your way, so why not have it all just happen at once? Certain encounters (anything involving spiders) are so miserably slow that i often just restart if i encounter them in the forest.

The Forest is the weakest part of the game - Almost every encounter is designed in such a way that there's not really any clear or optimal way to deal damage, or simply takes far too long. You just have to throw and hope your orb goes the way you expect. Many of the Forest encounters seem like you're expected to hit bombs to deal any damage, which means you're going to be throwing a lot of turns randomly hoping that you go the right direction.

There are two good bosses in the game - [spoiler]The Mole and The Ballista are fun. The same cannot be said for any other boss. The Slime is just miserable - Better than it was in the demo, but still a complete slog. The Wall is just a DPS check. The Ruins boss can be beaten simply by throwing every orb to the left while the bottom left segment is rising (give it a try, it's basically guaranteed). On a similar note, the invisible mini-boss is quite simply idiotic. You can't possibly plan shots. If you take a certain combination of items, your turns can go for literally tens of minutes.[/spoiler]

Playing the game in its current state is mostly a constant series of asking yourself the same frustrating questions.

Why do the majority of boss reward items simply defeat the purpose of the game? Why line up a shot when the RNG magnet decides your fate? Why aim when Multi-ball will send orbs flying everywhere? Why would i ever take anything that isn't The Gift That Keeps Giving? 

Why is upgrading orbs random? Why does the game seem to love events that just give you stones? Why does the refresh orb sometimes just spawn somewhere where you have to waste turn upon turn reaching it? Why even have sloped surfaces if the pegs disappear before you have any chance to roll down?

In conclusion, currently, No, I wouldn't recommend this game. It needs a lot of polish, and could be great, but as an early access title, it just isn't worth delving into the frustrating mess that the game currently is. Give it a few months, and see how it turns out.
