This newest update actually fixed most of the issues with the game.

People criticizing the coin update saying its more content bloating don't actually understand how it mechanically functions better, IMHO.

1) You would likely get enough coins per level to do what you would normally do before this update, even if you aren't trying to get coins. Simply trying to get more coins lets you stockpile.

2) This actually fixes the RNG issue with the game, allowing you to have way more control over your builds and effects.

3) The coin mechanic is immensely satisfying and a great implementation into this pachinko game. How else would you want to gain coins? Simply post combat coins wouldn't be nearly as thematic. Plus this introduces an element of risk vs reward for each combat, which in turn would reflect on player skill, not RNG as much.

A great update to the game and I am confident for this game's future now. Adding more mechanics and abilities won't inherently break the game as it did in previous updates lmao.

Honestly I wanted to like this game so much, but it's just not got that fun feel that the games it's inspired by managed to pull off.

The orbs don't bounce enough. It sounds stupid but one of the most fun things about games like Peggle is lining up your shot and having it bounce off 20 pegs and getting a crazy chain reaction. In Peglin if you want the orbs to bounce more than 3-4 times, hope you stumble upon a relic that gives you bouncier pegs. I swear the orbs in this game hit a peg, bounce once, and then have no momentum left and just drop in the hole. 

The enemies aren't readable like in a game like Slay the Spire. Most enemies follow a fixed pattern, but you only learn this pattern from playing the game multiple times. In a lot of games this is an okay method of learning, I don't think this applies to turn based games like this. The biggest issue with this system shows up in one of the boss fights, where the boss will attack once every 4-5 attacks, I've beaten this boss a lot but I still have no clue how often it attacks.

The enemies aren't fun to fight. The game gives you a method of attack, but no method of defence. Your initial assumption here might be that because the enemies advance towards you each turn, you have to have enough damage to kill them before they get to you. This assumption is WRONG. Half the enemies have ranged attacks, which means that regardless of how well you're doing, unless you get perfect luck then you aren't going undamaged. While there probably shouldn't be an expectation to be undamaged, it's not fun to take damage like this.

Self damage sucks. Same as the above about forced damage; Half the good orbs in the game have awful downsides: "Take 4 damage when fired" "Take 15 damage when fired, increase self damage by 7" What the fuck were they thinking? This also happens with one time per battle orbs. Yes devs, I'm sure my one time per battle heal of 10 would be gamebreaking if I had it 2 times per battle instead or 3 in a long boss fight.

The game is competently made and designed; the primary character is very cute and I do want him to get complete his journey with mysterious, and as far as I can tell, entirely undisclosed goals.  You are some sort of goblin creature that uses pachinko balls to destroy enemies, get to end of the level, and kill the end boss; which is the standard for a roguelite.

I will say that I thoroughly enjoyed this game, and will probably continue playing it, but the pachinko mechanic is perhaps not the best way to build around a roguelite game.  It has a tendency to miss the mark on consistency, and while standard for the genre, in this game you it can cost you a run on the basis of one bad bounce off a peg.

Overall, I'd give this game a 7/10; while the gameplay itself is quite fun (it reminds me a lot of peggle), the inherent randomness roguelites combined with the randomness of pachinko can be a bit tilting when you inevitably lose a run because you wanted to get the treasure chest and now have to instead deal with a combat you didn't want to do.  

Overall, this game is worth the money, and you should give it a shot if you like roguelites.

Fun pachinko style game.  Launch your orb into the board, watch it bounce around as it powers up with each collision, then deals damage to enemies as you make your way - for some reason - through a forest, a castle and a cave.

There are a lot of different and varied orbs that you'll pick up as you go, and other power-ups to try out.  The physics work well, the levels have varied opponents and challenges and it's fun (and often frustrating) watching your ball dance round the screen, only to just clip a peg and get diverted the wrong way at the last second.

There's an ongoing challenge mode once you've got through the three levels which increase the difficulty of future playthroughs.  I'm enjoying trying to get past the third challenge level - I haven't made much progress lately, but I'm still having fun.

The game seems to have got harder lately, largely due to the increasing numbers of different balls and relics available - it makes it much harder to get a combination that works well together.  When it first launched, you could reasonably rely on getting several bomb-related powers that made it a lot easier.  However, the devs are still working on the game, releasing a balancing patch a couple of months ago that did seem to improve things.

Hopefully they will tweak things some more and we'll get to a point where I can advance some more.  But even at this point, it's a fun pastime and at my usual target of and hour of entertainment for Â£1 spent, I've more than got my money out of it.

I have played Peglin on/off for quite a while, starting with the demo that was available to download before it even hit Steam.
I absolutely adore the concept, and used to absolutely love playing it, but these days, I feel like every time I run I do, whether I win or lose, I come away with a bad taste in my mouth.
The gameplay loop is solid, there are some fantastic choices of orbs and relics, but it's all just far too random, even for a roguelike!
You start a run, get a few orbs, or your first relic, and decide to yourself that you'll aim for a certain build. A handful of levels later, you realise that you have to abandon that idea because you've only been offered items/orbs/events that you don't need, so you start working on something else. This repeats until you end up with some kind of cobbled-together build that doesn't really work, and it's either vaguely good enough to beat the bosses, or not.
As with most roguelikes, more often than not, you'll end up needing to remove orbs from your deck for it to work properly, and in those instances, you probably won't be able to, because there are FAR too few ways to do so.
The only way that you can are via the ? spaces that appear throughout your run, but in my experience, I'd say about 50% of these are just battles, which don't help. A strong recommendation would be to either lower the chance for battles via ? spots, or just remove battles from the ? table entirely, as they really don't feel like they belong there.
A second recommendation, which may resolve the issue in a better way, would be to introduce some kind of 'shop' tile for you to aim for, similar to the way that Slay the Spire does things, where you could choose to purchase specific orbs/relics, or upgrade/remove orbs from your deck, which would allow you to hone your build in a more reliable manner.
I'd absolutely love to change this into a positive review, because as I say, I really do love the concept, I'm just finding it hard to actually enjoy at present. Please keep up the work and support for this game, and I hope to play again soon!

The item imbalance can at time trivialize your choices, as in a challenge run there's no point in intentionally taking items that are bad (unless pain is your pleasure). In my last run, I was creating and sending about 20 bombs and dealing an additional 200-500 damage per orb. I lost.

I agree with some other folks here that have said that with each update, the player seems to have less and less control over the outcome of their run. In some games this is fine, Luck be a Landlord comes to mind. The difference is, in Peglin, the player is tricked into thinking that their decisions matter. 

The reason I love Roguelites is because, if I make good decisions and get a little lucky, I can create ridiculous synergies that effectively break the game. You can do that in Peglin, like I did on my last run. The difference between most other roguelites and Peglin is that once you have the game on the ground with a white flag in its hand, other games wave it, Peglin sticks it up your a$$ and says, "I don't give a $hit about your fun pu$$y". 

TLDR: Fuck Peglin. (I'm probably a bit salty)

I really wish I could recommend this game because it is really interesting and such a neat concept, but at the end of the day, it misses the mark. After playing it for 20 or so hours, I think there's two main reasons why:

1. The physics of the balls on the pegs
In actual Peggle there's an almost pinball-like feel to the how the balls move, and it makes it really easy and intuitive to tell how the ball is going to interact with pegs. In this game, not only do some balls have different gravity effects (not a problem in and of itself) all of them feel really weighed down. It's difficult to anticipate just how the balls are going to ricochet, and also? It just doesn't feel good.

2. The starting relic power imbalance
At the end of the day, you only really need a good start. You can start a run with a relic like the Dumb Bell or Suffer the Sling and be set for the run. Or you could start with three really not very useful options, at which point it's really just better to restart the run and go again. This sucks and I hope the makers at least put in an option where, if you skip picking a starting relic you get some kind of bonus.

There's a bunch of little problems as well- the music is really repetitive and becomes grating, there is way too big a gap between normal and rare relic power, some of the peg boards, although cute, aren't well balanced from a numbers perspective. But all of those can be gotten passed- those two issues, however, really can't be. I'm going to be following the game, but I think I'm done with it for a long time.

It's a fun game with a great idea for a core loop, the devs are actively working on and improving the game, I can't wait to see how it grows.

There's a lot of orbs and relics that are seemingly entirely pointless, I have no idea if this is to have "Bad loot" or the lack of understanding of their own game from the developers, either way it leaves a bitter taste to come across any of these things.

It's cute, but that's about where it draws the line, because the gameplay isn't there.

65% and 77%... At the time of my writing this recommendation, these are Peglin's monthly and total review scores. This is completely unacceptable. Peglin is a phenomenal game. It is a simple and utterly charming title, with the most appropriate art/ sound direction possible, and a soundtrack that never gets old. Make no mistake, there is a lot of strategy to this game, and the developers are adding new content at a great pace. Speaking of pace, the game is the perfect length for controller-passing. All of these elements make it one of the perfect games to share with a friend or loved one. My girlfriend and I play this game almost nightly, and have for a few months now. It's the perfect game for her, because she likes the 'action' element of games (ie: visual stimulus) and there is just enough strategy for her without being too much.

Now for the reason as to why I expect the game is being review-bombed: Peglin is actually a 'rougelite,' and it is very much [i]almost[/i] a hardcore title-- Nothing at all like Super Meat Boy, but definitely not a walk in the park like so many other self-professed 'rougelites.' Ah, I bet you weren't expecting to read that, were you? Yes, this little game can be, at times, barbarically difficult. Winning in this game is a balancing act between action, strategy, and luck. Even if you are an experienced player/ gamer, you are going to throw a lot of attempts at the wall before they start sticking-- and even when you are able to get some wins, they don't come consistently. Furthermore, there was a recent patch which either nerfed, or eliminated, some of the game's more promising orbs/ strategy, making it even more difficult. Some of these changes were reversed imminently in the following patch, which came a couple of days ago, but I digress. 

Here is what I have to say about this alleged point of 'negativity': It simply doesn't matter. Peglin is so much fun to play, even when you lose. Being able to laugh while getting frustrated, and experience a genuine thrill when you finally win it big, is the hallmark of excellent game design. This is such a hard thing to achieve, and is a commonality shared by only the world's greatest games. Among others, Peglin shares this element with Dwarf Fortress, a game which demands days of devotion from its players to learn, as well as games like Blackjack and Poker, which cost both real money and hours of maths study/ heartbreak to play. Do you see that? Those games cost something real and tangible to play. On the other hand, Peglin costs $15.00. There's no wonder as to why Peglin is so successful, considering that is basically an improvement upon Pachinko, another casino game. If you are able to laugh when something unexpected happens, even if it's at your own expense, you will really get a lot of laughs when you play this game. Peglin is an excellent game, and absolute classic in the making. Ignore the naysayers and buy it immediately... [and this is where the polite part of my review ends. Buy the game.]

Now, who should [i]NOT[/i] play this game?

If you are perhaps autistic, extremely impatient to the point of being mentally-defunct, or else a freak who is so obsessed with the destination that he closes his eyes along the journey, then do not play this game. You won't like it, because you will lose too often. If you play games only to get a cheap dopamine rush when you win, and then put your game away forever after "winning" a few too many times, then go jerk off or something and stop writing video game reviews. In fact, stop playing video games altogether. Get your disgusting, cum-stained hands away from this title, and other great hardcore titles which you are seemingly obsessed with trying to ruin; it isn't working. [i]"It's too hard" has never, and will never be a valid complaint in gaming. Read that again: "It's too hard" [b]HAS NEVER, AND WILL NEVER BE[/b] a valid complaint in gaming.[/i] The gaming community at large hates people like this, who are the functional equivalent of compulsive gamblers, or perhaps parlor ladies that can't stand to be slighted in any way. In polite society, we refer to these people as the "inclusive game design" crowd, "games journalists," or more colloquially as "easymoders," and they are are the bane of [i]good[/i] game design. I have never taken people like this seriously, nor should you... However, I fear that a small developer like Red Nexus Games may begin to kow to them out of necessity, if their prized title should be brigaded by these bad actors so quickly after its release. This is part of my purpose of writing this review: Not only am I writing to share how much I love this game with you all, but also to offset the carnage done by these [+/-]80-IQ degenerates who are [i]Hell-bent[i] on ruining it for you before you've even played it.

In conclusion: Go play the game! And Red Nexus... If any of you are reading this, then thank you for making a good game and keeping politics out of it. Please do not listen to the easymoders in the review section, and keep finding ways to make this game more and more challenging and rewarding as you see fit; you have certainly done a good job thusfar.

It might be a little mean to post a negative review of a game that hasn't even been fully released yet, but since it's currently at 0.752 and I have been following how the game has been developed from an early stage I think it is fair to say the finished game isn't going to be worth your money but things could change as it approaches 1.0 who knows.

The main source of problems is that the developers care too much about listening to feedback from players and the result is a silly whimsical game without much well needed direction to make a polished game. It's entertaining but nothing special. The discord server is a spasm of speculation about possible new content and mechanics for the game without enough discussion about refining what is already in the game, each patch they add yet more overpowered orbs and relics which don't add that much to the experience (more on this later). The only thing keeping this game going is new content. One good thing that comes from the feedback from players are the relic and item names, the play on words is charming and meme-y.

The core of what is wrong with the game is that none of your decisions really matter when you are playing. This problem takes on many forms in game: excessive RNG, balance problems and general boring game design.
It should go without saying that a pachinko roguelike is going to have a lot of RNG, but the real problem is that your options are too limited and randomised to leave room for much strategy at all in the game. For a game about item synergy it doesn't give enough freedom in choosing the items, there is no currency system (so therefore no shop system) currently so you can only choose items from a random selection after a fight (if it even gives you that option, it could just offer a choice of healing or upgrading an orb). Although if you just want to kill time this game is great because of this.
Even with less restricted/randomised choices though, the game is still boring from a balance perspective because the different orbs and relics don't interact enough, they just tend to provide a new positive effect which is largely independent of other effects and they're all equally "broken" except when they're not. So choosing between items is either pointless or a no-brainer, neither of which are fun. There needs to be a lot more risk-reward type effects introduced, especially ones that could unexpectedly backfire or work very well depending on how considerate you are about item choices.
But the game is boring on a more fundamental level than just balance issues, some aspects of the general design are uninteresting. There is no lore, very little world building and the event scenarios get repetitive after a while. There isn't enough complexity in how different events influence later events or allows for new events to occur.
Bomb plays are love, bomb plays are life.

Great game! Definitely looking forward to more playable classes to shake up the meta and add more replayability. Definitely had a lot of fun with this game and already got my money's worth, anything additional from this point on will be gravy on top.

I'm tentatively recommending this game because the combination of pachinko + roguelike is a totally awesome, fresh concept and should be picked up by anybody who loves the roguelike genre. 

With that said, I have some caveats--this is a ridiculously unbalanced game. It is very difficult to build a 'successful' deck of orbs and relics that can kill the different varieties of enemies and bosses. You can likely glide by the end of the first map with a pretty mediocre deck, but you will quickly get overwhelmed after 2-3 enemy nodes in map 2 if your deck was only just 'okay.' Compared this to, for example, Slay the Spire Act 2 where there is still some wiggle room to 'fix' your deck before the 2nd boss. 

This game is great if you want something that gives you gambling-heavy dopamine with some light strategy, but I wouldn't consider this a serious deckbuilding roguelike contender. Not yet, at least--here's hoping Early Access gives this game better direction.

This was a fun little rougelite and 5 months ago I would have recommended it. However, with each update I feel like I have less and less control over what happens in the game. With each update it feels more like a slot machine than it did before. I'd like more control over building my "deck", more ways to remove orbs, and more thinking and decision making. There's just not that much strategy involved.  If you prefer more luck based gameplay, you may get some enjoyment out of it.

For an early access game, this is a wonderful little game filled with quite a few nods to the games that inspired it. It didn't take too long to win at this point in the game so far. I hope a lot more content is planned in the future, though. As it stands $20 seems like a little more than I'd be willing to pay for if not for it being still early access. 

That said, I can't wait to see how much more will be added to merit this current amount.

Used to be an extremely fun, engaging, and refreshing take on the rougelite genre. Unfortunately, with each passing update, the game gets less fun and more frustrating to play. Unproblematic orbs and relics continue to receive nerfs (example, bouldorb and jackorblantern) while enemies gets more annoying additions which necessitate specific relics to counter them (example, shields taking half damage and axe me anything negating that), returning you to... what it was like in previous updates. I think the ultimate culmination of this poor design philosophy resides in... (SPOILERS PAST THIS SECTION) 



...the Sapper bossfight. This boss exists not as a test of skill, but a test of "hope-you-didn't-invest-in-the-wrong-build". Bomb builds don't work, refresh builds hardly work, crit builds are weakened because of crits being hidden, hidden pegs don't work for activations, you need some form of AoE or need to smack red bombs... etc. If I were commenting on this game even just 3 months ago, I would be giving rave reviews and voicing my excitement for seeing what it became going forward, but as it stands, the game continues to get worse. I wouldn't buy this anymore if I were you. There's a lot better roguelite options out there.

great game, the only thing that i find annoying is the knights with the shields, you can hit those shields for insane amounts of damage and it will still only damage the shield, i feel like if you hit it hard enough to kill the shield, the guy holding the shield should take either the remaining damage or a percentage of the remaining damage as a result of overkill damage on the now broken shield, like yes there is overflow damage orbs, but the shield specifically being an equipable item shouldnt provide 100% protection if i slap it for over 2k overkill damage lol

I feel my review is a little harsh, this game is only 5 months old. So bear that in mind.

Maybe this is all just me, but I'm going to give my honest view regardless.
I keep wanting to like this game, but I just think they miss the mark.

The first world has so many maps with such poor peg density that you get maybe like 5-10 max bounces per orb launched for the majority of the maps in world one. Which makes a bunch of orbs so much worse than they should be, and is just incredibly boring to experience.

Pegs often lack bounce (Not including the ones that have that programmed, such as slimed or webbed ones) and feel weak all the time. Also for the record, the maps that have the web/slime, have too much web/slime, it makes half your shots the exact same short as the previous one, and that makes the start of the game quite boring when you happen to get the web ones early. 

The slime boss that puts you inside itself, is maybe the least fun boss in any game I've ever played. His pegs are far too spread out, you rarely ever get a good bounce worth a damn no matter how good your orbs are. The idea of the boss I love, the execution I abhor. Just give it more pegs, even if it's more of the gross bounce stopping slime ones. His WHOLE BODY is made of slime, not just a layer externally coating him.

There are far too many ranged enemies half them and increase melee enemy damage. It makes bramble totally useless when more than half of the enemies you encounter do ranged damage for equal damage to the melee guys half of the time. Not enough penetrating weapons or splash damage weapons or luck based weapons. Bomb orbs are easily the strongest and it's not even close how much better they are.

This game is supposed to be about bouncing, maybe have less things that either don't bounce or reduce bounce.

The cruciball is absolutely completely and utterly awful. 1 more stone (a bad thing) but also your stones are weaker (also a bad thing) why would literally anyone with even a single brain cell, want that? Obelisk builds, sure. Let's make a whole new game system just to make 1 build better to start with. That's trash and boring.
Having finished a few more times, my cruciball is now level 4. Just adding difficulty isn't fun, especially when it's in such mundane ways. Oh enemies have more health, your stones are even worse, extra fire hole damage? that's the most boring thing you could possible do to add difficulty. I think I've hit those fire pits (misnavigation) maybe 3 times in 100 runs...

Adding no new complexity is just lazy. These wheel options should be buffs with bad caveats, otherwise there's literally no improved replayability after you complete the game... come on guys, roguelike:101 here, could not be a more basic mechanic for a roguelike.
You literally have items with amazing caveat buffs, they far more fit in the cruciball than the truly so damn boring difficulty increase in there so far.

The more I have played this game, the more angry I have become. Hopefully some of the classes and balance tweaks will improve this game enough, because I'd like to enjoy and recommend this game.

Here are some suggestions.
An orb that every time it's the one you are throwing, ramdomises somewhat. Perhaps some times it's high crit low main stat, some times it's medium both but penetrates, some times it has neither but converts blocks hit into crits or into refreshes, things like that.

A cruciball buff where you pegs start with needing 1 extra bounce to break (forgot the name of that stat, durable maybe?) but your orbs pass through crits, refreshes, bombs, and other non standard pegs, rather than bouncing off of them? (still activates them and breaks their peg)

An orb that is a boomerang. Normal orb in the peg board, but when you fire it, it penetrates through all enemies once and then comes back maybe? Lower stats but deals damage twice could be fun and interactive with mechanics like blind on hit, and any others that apply on hit.

Perhaps an orb or an item, that lets your shots hit only above and behind the target (like a grenade going on kind of thing, small aoe splash damage on the orb, could even be only 50% of the main shot's damage, for balance sake)

Also I think you need to nerf the item that increase crits multiplier for hitting multiple crit pegs. It's just too strong, it truly is so easy to start hitting 5000-10000 damage shots, once you have that. Especially when combined with Durable and the electromagnetic item. You can get to 3x crit in a single crit node and that happens almost the instant it touches the crit. I've gotten to 10x crit before and had I think over 20k damage from shots.

There was a time when I really enjoyed Peglin, mostly when you could combine silly powerful combos, such as the magnet item and bombs, to rack up the damage. With every update since then, the game's feels like it's getting unnecessarily harder or reliant on luck, rather than building up aiming skills with every shot or finding decent item combos. Nothing really gels anymore and it's a real shame.

I'm also not a fan of how recent updates focus on buffing enemies to unwinnable levels. Sure, Roguelites are supposed to be hard, but they also need have that element of progression where you feel you're improving with every run. By buffing enemies in this way, I don't get the sense that I'm improving. Unlocking new characters that change the game a little, or allowing some more freedom to finish runs would bring this game back to a healthier state. It could also do with a bit more variety in locales and enemy spawns, as I've spent far too long playing the same three levels.

Peglin's concept is cheeky and fun, and that alone is a good reason to keep an eye on it and not give up on it. I think that all it needs some TLC to bring back the fun while stripping away some of the emphasis on balancing in favour of the AI. In the beginning, When I first heard about it, I wanted to support it and I'm glad I did. I would have said that this is one of the concepts to watch, but right at this moment, I simply can't recommend people buy it. Hopefully, by the time it comes out of Early Access, it's in a much better place.

Sometimes when I'm just winding down or need something to pass the time I'll boot up Peglin. It's a fun and simple game with tons of replayability. The game is heavily decided by RNG. You're not promised a win nor are you really told you're gonna lose in any specific run. Where RNG isn't the deciding factor, it's where you shoot your orbs that counts.

If you find yourself stuck, and I found myself stuck on the 2nd stage wall boss a lot, try to use some of the other orbs, plan out your paths, and look for more opportunities to get relics in the hopes that what you find works. Trust me, I've been there. But now that I've played the game a bunch, beaten the game a dozen times, and completed every level of the cruciball mode, it really doesn't seem that bad anymore.

Don't go into this game thinking that you're gonna win it with skill. Luck and game knowledge is what works here.

When I first picked up this game I saw some negative reviews which mentioned the RNG. I said to myself-- complaining about RNG in a Roguelite game? Sounds like a skill issue. 12 hours later I have to agree.

By the nature of this type of game you either capitalize on synergies or work to make the best of a bad situation. My fairly off-the-cuff analysis is that there's three issues as it relates to this game: 1) the pachinko element robs you of the same level of tactical control you have in other Roguelites, the ideal action is often still be a 'misplay' on a bad bounce; 2) there is a lot of variation in quality between relics, so you NEED to get good RNG; and this would be forgivable if not for 3) the balance is just not there. If a game is difficult and has well-defined systems or tight controls then they can be overcome with wits and/or skill. This, on the other hand, is a game where you throw a ball and watch it bounce. 

In a better game I'm excited to start another run immediately. With this game I just feel like I wasted my time-- it's not fun to invest so much time into a run and die to a bad bounce or an overpowered enemy. Can't recommend this game as it exists now.

The design of the game is nice to look at but it feels like everything is made to be detrimental to the player. From the get go, you don't really get to feel powerful unless you get lucky with some orbs and relics. It feels surface deep so the game is fun until the novelty of a new Peggle-like wears off.

The level design is less based around bouncing and sliding off stuff like in Peggle that's there to be satisfying and more about trying to make the ball hit the bottom of the screen as fast as it can unless you get a few certain orb types. There's only a handful of levels I like and many I hate. There's many orbs that are bloat or have negatives to using them and the same goes for relics.

Random encounters are best avoided because instead of being a mystery, it's likely just going to contain something you don't want. Enemy encounters range from being fine to just annoying or unfair. Combat feels really detached from the gameplay which doesn't help. You play Peggle and either your continue playing bar or your stay on this level bar depletes and what happens, happens.

The game is overly reliant on luck as a whole which isn't ideal for me. IMO rogue likes need to allow skill to offset luck and allow players to complete a full run. Sadly this isn't it.

All that said, it is in Early Access and things could improve drastically. Great idea, it has some great moments and it has a lot of potential. I just can't recommend it in its current form.

[h1] [b] Review as of patch 0.7.48. [/b] [/h1]

[i] Peglin [/i] is a blend of PopCap's [i] Peggle [/i] and the rougelike genre, a combination that works surprisingly well. Instead of accruing points by hitting the pegs you accrue damage that, once the thrown orb has fallen, will strike your enemies for the number you achieve.

Starting, you'll only have stones - these are your basic attacks - but succeeding each level gives you options to upgrade, remove, or add new orbs to your run. There are three stages that vary thematically and mechanically, but eventually you'll know what to expect as they aren't too random. I don't find the lack of stage variety detrimental as there are a huge amount of orbs and abilities to choose from - creating the perfect synergy is immensely satisfying. 

At this point in early access replay value comes from unlocking modifiers that make future runs more challenging, but this isn't really enough. I'd like more incentive to complete multiple runs in one game session such as cosmetic rewards for our Peglin. Lack of an official endless mode is disappointing but hopefully Red Nexus Games will deliver before launch (I believe there is an endless mode mod).

Peglin has a lot of potential, but it needs more content and a difficulty increase. Perhaps I was lucky beating it on an early run, but I kind of doubt that. The game has a similar gameplay loop to Slay the Spire. As such it needs secret bosses, classes, and ascension options for further replay value. Current recommendation is to buy Peglin if you want to support further development or to wait for a decent sale.

Edit* 9-1-2022
Since my original review Peglin has now added custom game starts and CRUCIBALL! Which is similar to ascension in Slay the Spire. Difficulty is increased in some ways and increases replay value a decent amount! I'm looking forward to the classes that are supposed to be released in the future. Current recommendation is to buy Peglin if you want to support further development or just want to kill some time shooting enemies with orbs. Its far from done and well worth the money with updates on the way

I like this game. I really do. Or mostly did...

The game in demo was fun, relaxing and altogether a great experience. But specific updates has made most runs unbeatable. Some bosses are suited for very specific builds with very specific orbs which are given out at random, so if you do not have that specific build, sorry, you are either going to never win, or have to pray to the gods above for RNG to smile upon you. There are two main culprits.

A) The wizard in the castle. This wizard is completely unbalanced. Don't do enough damage early on? say goodbye to your run. For shields appear on every hit, and unless these shields are destroyed (which take around 3-5 hits, unless you have an orb that destroys shields in one hit) then his shield perk goes up... To the point where if you reload, it goes up twice, meaning you now need to deal over 100 damage in one orb to even start damaging his health. And if thats not bad enough, RIP if your refresh gets locked behind a shield, cause you will be wasting so many orbs trying to get to it as you have run out of orbs to deal any damage.

B) The upside down creature. Although the gimmick is clever, and unique, that is the only positive thing i have to say. MASSIVE health bar, DOUBLE MOVEMENT (so he gets to you in 3 turns) and since some update, the black holes don't have a strong enough pull most of the time to get the orbs hitting where majority of pegs are. Which means you watch as you get one or two pegs and the ball falls down the holes. 

These two bosses are ridiculously overpowered against the player, and I have found myself turning the game off for days after fighting them, just because it saps the fun from the game.

Iâ€™d maybe pick this up on a 50% or more sale, ideally Iâ€™d pay no more then maybe $7, knowing this is at the moment just a frustrating and luck based time waster.

This game is adorable, simple to pick up, and most importantly, it's incredibly fun.

It's still in Early Access at the moment, so there are definitely points where you might notice the balance being off, and the game doesn't yet have quite the amount of variety needed to become a genre-defining paragon like Slay the Spire before it. But the development of the game is still ongoing, and patches are being released pretty frequently, so unless you're thoroughly opposed to early access games just on principle, I would still strongly advise picking it up.

And honestly? It's very rare that I think "I could be playing [game] right now instead" while playing other games, but I would rather play Peglin than some of the games I've already invested countless hours into and gotten to the climax of the story. So if you'll excuse me, while I could go on with the review... I could be playing Peglin right now instead.

Game can be fun but it really only shows how good it could be in the first world.
Health pools become inflated going into the second world forcing you to rely on either relics that make your orbs stay on the board for much longer but usually sacrifice any sort of tactical aiming whatsoever or just running all the orbs and relics that create bombs or refresh bombs.
 On top of that issue is that both of these strategies are basically interchangeable at any time they both synergize very well together since most of the bomb orbs and relics just want you to hit more pegs on the same shot. 
What makes this especially boring is that there is no dependable way to remove orbs from your bag so going for any other fun or crazy build is hampered by carrying around 4 or 5 rocks the whole game or going to random encounters hoping to remove something and just ending up with more filler orbs making your strategy even less dependable.
Personally i think having the most dependable and achievable strategies basically play the game for you just makes it tedious they're fun the first time you roll the entire game without effort, with what you think is a crazy combo, until you do it again and again because its that easy to pull off.
What makes this especially boring is that there is no dependable way to remove orbs from your bag so going for any other fun or crazy build is hampered by carrying around 4 or 5 rocks the whole game or going to random encounters hoping to remove something and just ending up with more filler orbs making your strategy even less dependable.

Overall I think the game shows a lot of potential but lacks any reason to get better at it or try new strategies and that just makes it boring.

Bottom Line Up Front: Peglin scratches that chill Peggle itch; it's probably not worth $20 at this point, but definitely something to watch.

In its current state, Peglin is an incredibly chill game. 

If you're looking for the next deep, deck-building roguelike a la Slay the Spire: Peglin probably ain't for you. It scratches a similar itch, but synergies are much more limited (granted, it is still in Early Access)

If you want something casual to play with a nice, chiptune-inspired soundtrack and solid pixel graphics; or, like me, you played an unhealthy amount of Peggle back in the day and want to scratch that itch, you'll probably enjoy Peglin. 

If you're on the fence, Steam's 2-hour-played refund policy should be plenty to get to grips with what the game is (and isn't). Two hours is enough to get a good sense of what the game has to offer, and you can make an informed decision.

I can't recommend this game. As much as I love when things go right in this game, I moreover just find myself utterly frustrated at it, and I think it's a core design issue.

90% of strategies in the game simply don't work. 

You might go, okay. I have a small deck with a bunch of reload relics, so that'll beef up my relics and make me stronger. Sorry, that doesn't scale fast enough. You're dead before you have a chance to scale to anything, making all those relics useless.

You might have a really powerful orb, that can one shot enemies every time you use it. You've got a ton of damage. Oh, sorry. There's shields that absorb your entire attack while ranged enemies chip away at your health.

I'm not frustrated that the game is hard, or that it's "unwinnable" or I think it's unfeasible to win runs. My complaint is that there's currently two strategies that work, and everything else is kinda useless.

Those two strategies are: Bomb builds, and Orbelisk builds. 

Even with all the updates, these are the two builds that reign supreme. Everything they've added in the update for the most part is next to useless. There's just not enough AOE for how many enemies the game throws at you. You WILL take damage on every single room, and a lot on elites unless you have one of those two builds, leading to you eventually dying.

Not to mention, whether you get orb upgrades or more orbs is entirely RNG. I had one run where I duped all my orbs, and made it all the way to the second boss without getting offered a single orb for my deck. I just wanted an Orbelisk, due to having like 10 stones. But no, every single fight was "upgrade or heal". From a quarter of the way through act 1 all the way to the act 2 boss that I died to. 

Between navigation, rewards, whether you get upgrades or orb offers all being pure RNG, I feel like there's minimal strategy and you just bang your head against the wall until you win. I'm finally calling it quits due to how frustrating this game is.

This is one of the most frustrating games I've ever played.  The game itself has a great concept, but the game is far too luck based right now.  Most of the time when you lose, it's because of bad positions on your critical pegs, an unlucky order of your pegs, or some other chance based issue.  And that's a problem when you lose 2 hours on a single run only to die at the final boss because of it.  This needs to be addressed.  I have now lost 3 times on the final boss and wasted 6 hours of my life because of sheer chance.  Most rougelikes that involve RNG have ways to reduce the RNG as the run goes on (think how in Slay the Spire you can rather easily filter your deck to suit your needs with cheap, accessible card removal.  This is nearly impossible to do in this game, making synergizing incredibly difficult and mostly luck dependent.  If they made it easier to remove orbs (such as offering the option to do them after regular encounters instead of taking a new one, or perhaps instead of upgrading

It is especially bad on the final fight (you know, after you have already sunk far too much time into the run), making losses incredibly infuriating and feel like wasted time.  I think the main reason for this is the incredibly questionable decision to make the boss gain strength as the fight goes on.  It is nearly impossible to kill them before they output so much damage you can't do anything unless you get insanely lucky, even with a strong synergy of orbs and artifacts.  Even if you bring three healing orbs, it isn't enough.  Please either reduce the luck aspect or nerf the final bosses, and the game will improve significantly.  And also make me and probably a lot of other people way less frustrated.

I still put recommended because I think the concept is really strong, and if you don't get as frustrated as I do with losses nearly entirely because of bad luck instead of an actual lack of skill or strategy, you will probably enjoy this game a lot more.  But if you hate unfair losses like that, I'd stay away from this until they (hopefully) address this in a patch.  Just play the original Peggle.  Even if you lose there, it doesn't take 2 hours to retry the stage you lost on.

Idea and presentation of this game are great! But aside from you needing to be able to make your shots, there is a lot of luck involved. You need to find good orbs, good relics, good encounters and your orbs need to spawn in the right order. Critical pegs and pegs to refresh the board also spawn randomly. It is absolutely possible to lose an encounter and consequently the game thanks to any of these factors. 

It's still quite fun to play, but when you go up in difficulty, the rather excessive randomness is hard to overlook. If you are okay with just casually playing and seeing how far you get, this game is quite excellent, even in this early stage of development. If you are trying to win, it will laugh in your face, spin the Wheel of Misfortune and make you lose from a thing out of your control.

Extremely addictive. Immense replayability thanks to a significant amount of randomness on each run.

I understand that this is supposed to be Rogue-like but traits, orbs AND levels need to be re-balanced. You literally cannot win a Mini-boss fight (both the 3 plants and minotaur) with 4 lvl 1 orbs. Add to that the crucible with only 1 refresh and crit peg and this entire game becomes stressful rather than fun. [h1]Positives[/h1]
[list]
[*] You can get some disgusting combos
[*] Feels really good when you get those combos
[*] Good game for multi-tasking because it's slow-paced and requires minimal input
[*] Could improve by the time of release
[/list]


[h1]Negatives[/h1]
[list]
[*] Cruciball 6 onwards difficulty spike feels drastic
[*] Game seems to be balanced around getting the combos
[*] Ball feels so heavy when you don't have these combos and sinks into the gutter quickly
[*] Feels really bad in the early-mid game if you get the wrong items/balls based on these issues
[*] The special rooms where you get an additional item if you explode all the bombs seems to need either Short Fuse or Enhanced Gunpowder
[/list]

TLDR: Peglin is an example of what an Early Access game should be. The game has a solid foundation but could use some more development, and getting data and feedback from players is helping the dev(s) a lot as they actively work on the game and release updates. Absolutely worth the money if you have nostalgia for games like Peggle and you enjoy things like deckbuilder roguelites. 

The game is still early access as I'm writing this so I can't speak to the finished product, and if it wasn't still actively being developed and updated my opinion would probably be different, but so far my current 30 hours in the game have been very enjoyable. It could use a bit more fluff with the progression system to make it more interesting to get further in, currently you have access to all items on your first run and when the first build of the game was released, there were maybe half as many items as there are now. Starting out with some of the simpler orbs and relics available and getting access to more as the game was updated felt very natural, and some kind of progression system that unlocks more items as you progress through the Cruciball would make new runs feel more interesting and give more incentive to actually continue to play the game to unlock harder difficulty options. The luck aspects of the game can sometimes be frustrating when they don't go your way, but can also be immensely satisfying when they do favor you.

In my original review for this little roguelite I had been unhappy with the balancing and felt it needed a change before I would recommend this. It's been a few updates, and I can honestly say that the game doesn't feel as bad as it had beforehand. In fact a good portion of runs I have are great! Bomb builds are still insane, but I have had a good amount of runs that feel strong without the need for bomb synergistic relics and that's great! the new orbs that they've added are fun and can be very strong. The most recent orb added can also help with bad refresh orb spots which is something I originally did not like about the game balance.

I think the most recent update really helped the most, it helps alleviate the jump in power from stage one to stage two, and introduces a new boss and mini boss which adds a bit more variation which I love. The past two updates really just solved the majority of issues I had with the game, and I can wholeheartedly say that I'd recommend this game now. It's a fun roguelite concept that I believe will become even better the further the dev fleshes it out. Pick it up if it interests you!




(orginal review)
It's a fun concept for a roguelike, and I'm sure in time it will improve a lot considering it's still in early access. But it has some glaring problems that make it a less fun experience at the moment.

 The core issue is that the balancing is absolutely dire. The only realistic way you will win is through getting a build around bombs, otherwise you will almost always get overwhelmed and lose by the second stage. It isn't that the bomb build is overpowered (though it probably is) it's that every other "strategy" is severely underwhelming. I do not think a nerf of the bomb build is what is needed, more so other strategies need a serious tune up or alternatively the enemies need to be toned down in hp. 

Another problem I've faced which is not as big is some of the rng, mainly with how certain peggle boards are organized and the refresh orbs. I think the boards made are nice for the most part, and it's neat that they are thematic to enemies at times. The problem is that on some of these designs, bad luck with where the refresh orb is can cause you to waste multiple turns trying to refresh the board. This can cause you to essentially lose a fight because you got unlucky which feels really bad. Not quite sure how the devs would fix this because having it work like the crits could be frustrating at times as well, but it isn't the biggest problem if nothing is changed.

You should keep an eye on this game to see how it develops because I think it has GREAT potential. But for now it needs some big changes in balance before I'd recommend you buy it.

Cute little game with a great concept, and keeps getting new content. Occasionally infuriating but that's just roguelites for ya. A run takes no more than an hour, which is great because it's the sort of thing I can sneak in without making time for a Gaming Session. Super lightweight to install and run, performance is great on both my laptop with only integrated graphics, and in Proton on my Linux desktop.

There is a relic that deals damage equal to 20x the amount of times you have reloaded each time you reload, a relic that heals you a bit every time you reload, an encounter that removes all your orbs and replaces them with a single orb, and lastly a couple encounters that allow you to remove an orb of your choice.

I was lucky enough to get all of those in my second run and literally won the game by doing absolutely nothing from then on, it was awesome.

On an unrelated note this game is also fun when you play it without breaking it completely lol

10/10. It's in early access, of course it will be a little buggy, and unbalanced, but this game deserves overwhelmingly positive. I've only finished one run and I'm sure of it. If you want a fully polished game, this isn't what you're looking for. Regardless of that, my first run was awesome. I built up an okay team of balls and was feeling confident, then i got the option to give up all my balls. What do you think I did? I knew there was a secret ball you got from this, so it was an immediate yes. I was really happy having an orborus and RIGHT after i got the option to double it. RIGHT after that i got the option to double all my balls. I went on to get an electropegnent and the rest is history. I highly recommenced this if you want a non-multiplayer game all your friends can play, so you can share stories of your wildest moments.

UPDATE: After playing ~13 more hours additionally and seeing some of the patches they've implemented, my review does not change.  The RNG is even worse now with all the new relics and orbs.  I do not really find it enjoyable to sit there restarting the game 5-7 times in order to get a decent starting relic only to get lamed out with bad fights in world 1.  The Ooze elite is too hard unless you have the bramball.  They did make the minotaur easier, which is a plus, but there are still some real woofers for encounters in the first world.  They need to make all the orbs viable as a standalone or give us a way to limit what orbs we see.  I do like how some orbs combo and synergize very well with others, but the fact that you have to get these said combo pieces with the new influx of random orbs just adds too much frustration.  I only recommend this game if you absolutely love losing to RNG and/or you are a peggle master.

The boards in the first world are either ridiculously easy to clear pegs from or ridiculously hard to get more than like 5 pegs.  I really don't know what I'm doing, which is kind of bad game design considering I've played around 36 hours at this point.  I hate the randomness of your starting relic, and I find myself just resetting until I get a good starting relic AND a good map layout.  That's not all that fun for me.  If you want to be frustrated, then I guess I recommend this game to you, but if you're just a casual peggle player, then this game is way too hard to progress all that deep into the game.

[i]- Peggle: Dungeons[/i]
My only complaint is that the game lacks diversity, but then again - it is in early access. Buy it. I only came up with this one con after 60 hours of playtime.

Peglin is a fun and different take on the gameplay of Peggle, combining some traditional elements of Roguelike games to make a very enjoyable experience. You progress down a branching tree of encounters and depending on what you land on that dictates the encounter you do, or what rewards you'll receive. As you progress the levels get a fair bit more difficult, but with the right traits and additional Orbs you can add to your list, you'll cut right through. 

In its current state Peglin is a fun and enjoyable different take on Peggle, which I played for hours back in my WoW days when it was available as an Addon to play in between bosses. However it isn't without problems, though I believe almost all of my current problems will be irrelevant as more updates come out for the game, and post full release. 

My first main complaint is that there is a lack of variety in the game overall, or at least it feels that way. It took me 7 hours from start to end to beat a full run, and during that time you see the exact same stage layouts over and over and over. The lack of variance in levels became really obvious after just a couple hours, it feels more like a set campaign than a roguelikes changing nature from run to run. The only things that change from run to run are what Orbs you add to your loadout, and what Perks/Relics you get, everything else feels the same.

That leads into my second problem, a lack of variety in the Orbs/Relics overall leads to situations where you have a useless Loadout, and when you have a bad loadout its basically just a slow loss every single time, it feels like there's no way to recover the run. There's a couple Orbs that have synergies with others, but they don't feel like the synergies matter. With Relics you often see the same ones over and over as well, and there's a few that are significantly better than the rest that you would never not take. Matroyshka and the Short Fuse are both amazing relics that were always obviously better than the alternatives. This is also a minor issue in the grand scheme of things because I'm sure as time goes on and the game grows the options will grow with it.

And one of my last main complaints is a lack of Characters, but as you can probably guess this ends up being the same situation as the others which will get better with time. I would have liked more options at the outset, but as the game as a whole is relatively short as of right now, it wouldn't really change much from run to run. 

All of my problems with the game right now stem from it being Early access and I imagine as this game goes on there will be more added that fleshes it out fully and gives a bit more variety. The game definitely has its charm and is fun as shown by how I played for like 7 hours straight to get a win, its just that the fun was cut short when I realized I had basically seen everything the game had to offer within those 7 hours, and that there wasn't much of a reason to play it again. Can't wait for updates though, its a cute game with fun concepts being mixed with older classics, and at $20 I guess I can't complain too much, maybe wait for a sale if you're not sure.

I really wish I could recommend this game but in it's current state I just can't.

At its core this is a cool concept and I enjoyed my time with the game. The fact that this is Early Access is very evident in the balance issues the game currently has. The first area is doable but anything beyond that will be a struggle if not simply impossible unless you have a build that focuses around bombs with one or two orbs that are big heavy hitters for most bosses. Enemies will have too much health or be too numerous to deal with without the bombs and without the heavy hitters good luck defeating anything beyond the first area boss. Area 2 and on everything has way too much HP while being way too numerous. 

Most of the orbs are pretty useless. The bramble orb seems useful until you realize there are about 5 other enemies with hundreds of HP behind the one that's stuck for a turn or two that aren't stuck and the damage done to them by the bramble is insignificant. There's an orb that passes through everything except special pegs which could be useful if essentially wasting a turn on it wasn't a death sentence. The only reliable healing orb I've found was a one and done for the whole game unless I wasted three upgrades on it which means I wouldn't have any upgrades on the orbs I needed to upgrade to actually deal damage. The list goes on and on.

In addition the relics make or break a run. Some are just plain overpowered such as one where your remaining damage after killing an enemy will pass through on to the next (if you get this early and build around it is the only viable strategy that isn't bomb centered that I've found). Other relics will make only the first reload of the fight a free reload which is essentially nothing.

On top of all of this during the fight the order of your orbs is is random every fight and is pretty make or break sometimes. You'd think "okay well Slay the Spire you get a random hand of cards every turn, so what's the difference?" but the difference is in that game you still have a choice on which cards to play. In Peglin you can skip one orb and then you're just stuck with whatever order the game decided to give you. You also don't get to see that ball until the next reload where it will again be shuffled in a random order. For example one orb does damage based on all the pegs you have hit during the combat. If you get that the first shot it's almost useless so you bin it. Then you don't even see it the rest of the battle because it was shuffled to the end or you finish before you even reload. This could be solved by doing a sort of hand mechanic like a deck builder or even just letting you hold on to an orb instead of binning it completely, swapping it out whenever you want similar to holding a piece in Tetris.

If balanced correctly and if the content gets expanded on this would be an easy recommendation but as is I would save your money and wait to see what happens.

Peglin is an almost great Peggle/Roguelike combo that is hindered by a lack of content and variety. 

The visuals and soundtrack are cute and colourful. The gameplay is simple but satisfying. 

On the downside Peglin is quickly beaten and offers little more after finishing the cruciball mode (think Slay the Spire's ascension mode). The game has balancing issues - at higher levels there is little build variety and there are only a few viable ways to win.

A few updates and additions have been made at the time of writing, all of which I feel have improved the game. If Peglin can continue with great updates and address the issues with content and variety then I would fully recommend.

I very much enjoyed Peggle years ago and this looks like it has a fun twist on that concept. Unfortunately there is too much "random" in this game.
Specifically in one particular instance which makes the feature not worth having if it's going to be so random anyway; path selection for traversing the map. There is a world/dungeon map with branching paths, when you finish a level you select left or right on the path you wish to travel.  Unfortunately due to how random the bounce of the ball is I frequently end up going down the path I did NOT want.  Which is just hyper aggravating and not pleasure inducing in the least.  What is the point in offering a choice if there is such a large chance of the player not getting what they want. Might as well just be 100% random the whole time and save the user from thinking they can effect that part of the game.

It's not too late to fix this problem (simple solution, just remove every peg on the level when the player is picking left or right so their choice in that instance is respected).

This game needs a lot more love before it's ready for full release. The levels are too reliant on consistently hitting refresh orbs that often get parked in the corers of maps with several turns worth of barricades to work through, and too many levels have a single row of objects to hit and an empty floor beneath them, or massive empty space parked between two vertical objects where they hit 1-2 pegs then fall straight down with no map floor for even a single bounce. The base speed of the game is so slow you can see the pixels ticking along, and even at the 3x speed (which you need to go back to main menu to turn on????) several of the moving maps crawl along at a snail's pace, forcing you to sit and line up shots for agonizing amounts of time. The Cruciball challenges are uninspired and feel like a total drag, not offering a challenge so much as a relic slot machine (more than your typical rogue-like). Too many relics and orbs have power levels so far above others that there is no room for build variety. The more unique options require synergy to be any good and you have no time to pivot into them when the stars do finally arrive due to how short runs are. Even then, the more powerful meta options are just better at 99% of the game. The game is satisfying for about 10-30% of any given run, but it's a fast burn-out if you're looking for a good time sink, even between games.

Complicated feelings with this game. It's cute, it's innovative, it's fairly well executed. But at the end of the day... It's peggle. It's insanely RNG based.

Sure, you can sort of aim where you want your ball to fall in the first two or three bounces, but after that all you can do is pray that your ball doesn't do something stupid like falling straight down. It sounds like a little grievance, but because of how often that occurs, there's a decent chance that in any given run you will have one disastrous fight where your ball falls 5 times in a pit doing like 10 damage each time, and you end up dying. That's all it takes to lose.

Just a clarification for people who have't played the game. In the first world, some of the basic enemies have up to 200 health. You basic balls do 2 (or 4 with crits) damage each hit. Meaning you need to hit between 50 to 100 pegs to kill one enemy! With no control whatsoever over how many pegs you will hit. And of course those are not the only enemies in the fights. And that's [i]just[/i] the first world.

The core issue is that there's little to mitigate that RNG. There's a really solid base to do that that's currently in the game â€“ the different balls you can buy, and the relics you can get â€“ but it does not go far enough. There should be more options to buy and sell balls. There should be more control over what relics you get. Most of the relics are useless. Most of the balls have questionable use as well. The navigation system is cute but adds another layer of grievance when for some reason the path you want to take is full of pegs but the other side is completely open. The fight rewards are frustrating as hell too â€“ too often do I get the option to upgrade a ball when I need health, and no upgrade option when I'm at full health. The game needs [i]less[/i] RNG but instead adds more of it. And I know that's a big ask, but just one ACTIVE mechanic during the peggle shots would make the entire game feel less like a gambling simulator. Like the nudge you could do in Space Cadet for example.

Don't get me wrong, I beat the game like, 10 times? And it was fun! Because every time I won I used a bomb build and became insanely overpowered. Here's the deal: Bombs have a ton of relics that synergise with them  (recombobulator [i]especially[/] is a win runner, in combination with any other bomb relics); bombs do full piercing damage (as opposed to other balls with piercing that can't actually target all enemies, like flying ones); bombs do an instant 30 damage in 2 peg hits, more than any other balls can provide.

But that's it, really. The one and only way to mitigate the RNG is focusing on getting as many bomb orbs you can get and bomb relics â€“ but of course that's still RNG whether you get those or not. Bombs runs are the highest highs. Everything else can turn into the lowest lows in one fight.

If things change by the time 1.0 is released, I'll change my rating but I have little hope there's going to be drastic changes.

This game is easy to learn, hard to master. I play games of all difficulty levels, from point and click adventures to Hotline Miami. This game is approachable and pretty easy to learn, although there are nuances that the game does not do a great job of teaching, which will hopefully be fixed with a better tutorial system in the future.

Peglin is basically the Slay the Spire of Pachinko. If you didn't like Slay the Spire, you won't like this game. If you don't like Peggle and pachinko, you won't like this game. Procedurally based games and physics games and pachinko games all have heavy RNG elements.

The same way I would not give a negative review to a time management game for requiring meticulous micromanaging, I would similarly not downvote a procedural game for RNG or downvote a pachinko game for RNG.

Slay the Spire lets you choose your own path through a forked path system. So does Peglin -- and, just like Slay the Spire, you can pick from combat, mystery, boss, and treasure rooms.

Slay the Spire lets you create a custom build by collecting artifacts that offer permanent benefits. So does Peglin -- e.g. items that permanently increase bomb damage.

Slay the Spire lets you build a deck of cards that are randomly shuffled at the start of a round. So does Peglin -- except instead of cards, you have pachinko balls that have various effects.

My husband has never played Slay the Spire or a similar game. He tried this game on my account and got all the way to the third area on his first try, by taking the time to learn the game, read the text about artifacts and cards, and building accordingly.

The RNG on this game isn't shitty. It's just like Slay the Spire, if not easier, because all content in Peglin is unlocked from the start, unlike Slay the Spire. If you don't like RNG and procedurally generated games, you will not like Peglin. If you get mad about RNG, you will not like this game.

This is a game where build matters. Some items and balls you can pick are really incompatible with each other! Others make "overpowered" builds. I have never had a run where I couldn't make a fun build that kicked ass. 

Just because someone thinks a build is overpowered, broken, and makes the game broken, that doesn't mean their opinion has anything to do with whether or not someone else will like it. There's nothing stopping a player from making an underpowered build as a challenge. 

There is also the issue of confirmation biases regarding whether a build is overpowered or not. For instance, my husband likes multiball and refresh builds. I like Nosferatsorb builds. He is plays more multiball than me so therefore he is better at multiball because he put in practice. 

You see this same argument with any game where a character can specialize, because of confirmation bias fueled by the fact people pick the same builds over and over and then complain the game doesn't have replay value.

If you want to get the most out of this game, learn to play it, try different builds, and go in with good faith and have fun. You will die. A lot. But you know what you'll also be doing? Playing pachinko the entire time, with no cutscenes or any filler. You're going to be doing what's advertised, which is bopping pegs and smooshing enemies. How far you get is up to you, your skill level, how much practice you put in, and yes -- a little RNG.

But, not knowing how a game works and being surprised by an enemy's scripted behavior isn't the fault of "RNG." Yes, the game takes skill. So what.

Cool on paper, cute if you don't think about it too much or care about your experience being more than a roll of the dice that you have no power to influence. The developers are still adding content and while one of the things making me have less fun with the game may well be fixed, the other is more doubtful.

The first, and most fixable, issue is balance. bomb builds are by far the strongest, and no other build can even hold a candle to the damage they can deal. They only have one drawback depending on the items you pick up, and even that can be mitigated if you get lucky and find the right healing items, which brings me to my main concern.

Yes, nearly all roguelites have some reliance on luck. However, the best roguelites are the ones where you feel you have at least some agency, some way to influence that luck, whether it's being able to spend currency in a shop on a selection of specific items you might want, or some way of directly nudging the RNG to favor certain item drops. Other than an initial item selection, this game has none of that. You get what the game gives you and it either works and you win, or it doesn't and you lose. In addition, your entire run can just be obliterated by the pegs that refresh the board spawning in a location that's impossible to get to without wasting multiple turns to brute force it. The RNG of items mixed with the RNG of the peg boards themselves ultimately spoiled my experience after my first few wins. I'll keep trying it when the game updates and update this review if these challenges get resolved, and I hope they will. In concept, this game is delightful.

Despite recommending the game, I'm going to put down a few issues as to why I refunded it.

1) No run variance. The variety in your runs stems from the relics you gain, the orbs you pick up, and a few other factors. Normally this would sound fine, but two things are missing: Class and enemy variance. From what I can tell the amount of bosses in the game is pretty low at the moment. Especially considering how little each boss has in terms of animations or complex interactions. On top of this whenever you go through an area you always face the same 3-5 enemies. You might argue "Other roguelikes are like that" to which I would agree, but then argue that STS, Dead Cells, and Risk of Rain have multiple "paths" at every given level. Stage 1 is not the same everytime, however here it is.

2) The price. This game is comparing itself to the likes of roguelike giants. Risk of Rain, Dead Cells, Hades, etc. If the game was 5-10 dollars, I would say pick it up, but when you're charging sometimes MORE than these games, you need to compare yourself to them. 

Now despite these downsides, there are upsides. Otherwise I wouldn't recommend the game.

1) The developer actually cares. The team is showcasing off the next few updates, and they are promising to fix the issues I have above. There is a lot of potential.

2) The content which the game does have is superb. Even someone like myself, who hasn't played games similar to this one (peggle) in over 10 years, can see the depth in the game and the polish it has. 

Give this some time and It'll be great. 20 dollars great? I'm not sure.

I've played Peglin since the demo was out. I used to play it quite a bit and while there was a really fun core to the game, I always felt that the experience as a whole was way too swingey and inconsistent. More often than not, you were only really just waiting to get all the big, broken stuff that auto-won any run you were on and every run that you couldn't secure that, you just kinda had to cross your fingers and pray that you can somehow scrape by. Since it's official early access release, it seems that direction the game has taken at this early point is to completely double-down on the inconsistency. Whereas before you were able to just weather the storm and just barely make it by, if your run isn't already good before you reach the first boss, you might as well just hit reset, because the rest of your run is just going to be a slow, methodical march towards inevitable failure.

Before going on to list alot of my gripes, I need to emphasize that I do think that the core game itself is very fun. It is just basically just using Peggle to supplement an RPG battle system and it works well enough. When the game is actually firing at all cylinders, it has alot of the elements that I enjoy from roguelikes. It has a great breadth of variety of options to change the way you play and there is a thrill to finding a combination of items and balls that works to melt enemy formations before they get a chance to even move. It's just that alot of the systems that are built around this core are currently incredibly discouraging and brutally unforgiving, to the point, where your runs feels more like a luck of the draw than anything else.

I place much of the blame of this on alot of the new items that have been introduced since launch. The game has had a bit of a time experimenting with alot of "Risk vs Reward" items, things that have benefits counter-weighed by drawbacks. In most roguelike games, I would see this generally as a positive, as it encourages playstyle and defines how you play. In Peglin though, it doesn't quite work. Mostly because your control over the game is already very limited by the fact that you are still playing Peggle and while aim is a part of it, aim can't help you if you have just bad placements for refresh and critical hit pegs. With the way alot of these items work, getting a certain item can actually just completely brick your run, unable to deal almost any damage without a very specific lineup of balls and other items to support that playstyle.

However, there is still alot from just the initial demo that is still causing issues. The rate at which you heal at base, while good enough to get you through the forest, will most often mean you are basically losing the run, because you are losing out on potential upgrades. Not only that, but upgrades being random between upgrading balls or getting new ones can very easily leave you in a bad situation, where you either lack the tools needed to deal with future levels or lack efficient firepower to deal with enemies fast enough, which means you take damage that needs to be healed, which means sacrificing upgrades, etc. These kinds of slipping game-states can occur far too easily with just a single bad luck of the draw.

While there is alot of potential for this game and while I do have confidence in the team to address these issues, the game is currently in an unfortunate position, where their first few steps forward have felt a little iffy to me. The way the game is right now, I can't say I can fully recommend people pick the game up just yet, especially for the price it's asking.

This game is very fun, but I will say that it has a lot of elements that just make it feel empty.
Frankly getting to the cave and beating the game there just ends with you looking down a tunnel, when I beat the game on my first run ever and was presented with that ending, my thoughts were just "that's it?". I understand that this is not a full release, so the lack of content may very well be made up in the future, but that is the key phrase here, "in the future". Buy this game if you are intrigued by both the concept *and* the game play that you see, but be prepared for pretty consistent repetitiveness in enemy encounters and map design which is so cookie cutter, you feel like you're not only replaying the game, but living in the same moment.

However: There are many thing that could make this game amazing, and I will list my ideas here:
1. Changing the map to feel less like a Slay the Spire direct copy.
- The map makes the adventure seem bland and without much excitement. By making the map less basic and maybe adding an actual 2-D forest to trek through via your normal navigation patterns, that would make it much more immersive. Additionally, add more variants of spaces or locations, seeing exclusively the Boss, Floor boss, Enemy, and question mark spaces make me exclusively pick the question mark since a lot of the games charm and interesting features are only contained in those random encounters. Branching it off into different types of mystery encounters or sub-genres with colourful markers would allow for more skill expression whilst awarding player knowledge and strategy.

2. The Orbs are amazing, but it would be cool to see us actually charge up the attack whilst the ball is knocking down pegs.
- By making the Peglin charge up an attack depending on how many pegs and how high the attack value will be (with variations depending on if it's like, a projectile or magic attack etc.), I imagine it will look a lot more appealing and interesting. Giving enemies some sort of idle animation akin to a 2-D fighter would also add a charm and make them seem less cookie cutter.

3. Finally, add another area(s)
- I've seen that they are planning to add an optional boss at the end of the cave with a shorter room of encounters and a *very* difficult fight, but that addition could even be made AFTER the third place with another buffer area in between and maybe a bit of balance tweaking to allow the user to continue playing through all 5 locations now, with 5 being the optional challenge area. My runs at the moment tend to either be extraordinarily overpowered or spectacularly awful, so by editing the balance and adding another full area between the cave and challenge, you can slow the pacing whilst making runs more consistent in power rather than a firm high and low roll.

Thank you for reading my review, note that it is only not recommended in its current state, if there's one thing this game has in spades, it's potential. I look forward to seeing if they implement these options or expand the game to mod developers to potentially do these things themselves.
