Peglin, for me, solved the reluctance I had for Peggle type games. Instead of the challenge being based around individual levels, with limited shots, needing to hot specific pegs, Peglin acts more like a roungelike. Hitting pegs simply represents damage done to enemies, with that damage doubling if hitting a critical orb, or the pegs resetting of hitting a reset orb. As you succeed at clearing levels you are given new orbs that act differently to eachother when used, and different artifacts, each one fundamentally changing the way you play the game. Peglin is the marriage between the fundamentally fun game play of Peggle, and the run based advancement systems of games like Spelunky or FTL. And as such, it is one of my favorite games.

At the time of writing, I cannot recommend this game.

I would say that at it's core, the game is fine and I would nominally recommend it based on how well it works. Unfortunately, there are a few major balance aspects and one gameplay mechanic I feel would be better off being removed.

Balance:

Bomb builds are simply the way to go. In my time in playing, the only wins I got were with bomb builds. With any other build, I wasn't even able to get past the second level. This is not a call to arms for the developers to nerf bomb builds, and I'll explain in a moment.

As a roguelite, the game, unfortunately, relies heavily on RNG, that is to say, the ball itself. I don't feel that it controls consistently, and the basic aiming arrow is not nearly useful enough to lead an accurate shot. I would extend it by 25-50%. But that aside, even a strong build can get a very quick game over because the ball nudged a single peg, flew across the board and straight into the gutter. I suppose that's just part of the game, but it makes the game absolutely brutal when you consider the following.

I feel that all the enemies have far, far too much health bar the starting enemies. And usually, the entire track is full of them so playing anything less than a bomb build, or a ice or ghost build is straight up asking to lose. If you get the two logmen (who have 300hp each) as your first encounter, just reset. You can very easily find yourself stuck in a loop where you are forced to take the HP restore after each encounter because you had the audacity to play something other than an AOE heavy build, and now you have no opportunities because you constantly have to top up your health.

Taking this into account, a quick reset button would be much appreciated.

The one mechanic I would honestly like to see removed is having to slot the ball into the path you want to take. In some instances, the ball making a sudden 45 degree turn and dunk straight into a mini-boss instead of the chest you were aiming for is usually an instant-reset moment. Just let us choose a path instead.

As it stands, I can't recommend this game to anyone except extreme peggle/pachinko lovers, because the roguelite elements clearly need some work.

EDIT:

I would like to stress that this is not a bad game. If it's on sale and you want to kill a few hours, go for it. But while the peggle/pachinko half of the game works almost flawlessly, the roguelite element does not. There is no meta progression, no unlocks, nothing to try and tip the scales in your favour aside from simple luck in a run. Some items and builds are so clearly superior to others that you are simply making things harder for yourself for not pursuing them. 

Critically thinking, progression is what I'd like to see most in the game. Perhaps by unlocking the orbs first, then being able to start with a different loadout, would go a long way. I'm just spit balling here (pun intended).

I do have hopes for the game as it is still in early access and still receiving updates. Maybe check back once the game fully releases.

Okay so Peglin! For a game that's $18 early access? It's really worth it. Something about it's appeal is so addicting. You can't help yourself. 

However there is a huge problem with this game and thank god it's not any higher than $18. And the big problem with this game is the imbalance between the bosses, sure it's a roguelike; but something about the imbalance as many others have said and I'm throwing my opinion into the mix is that the game just really loves you not putting it down till you beat that specific boss or act. Now I'm not saying it's a bad thing -- far from it; but when it's basically dick-waving with a "git gud" sign and that's far from okay. Yes, we love the challenge, yes we love seeking revenge against a boss. But it's about taste and execution her and my god is it poorly done with it hence why the imbalance is such a huge focus.

If the runs are fairer in terms of dishing out fair boards (the images you see of balls floating in mid air? That's the board), and if the bosses aren't absurdly imbalanced then this might be a great indie game to enjoy.

But for now? I would say try the demo first, and see if you an really get into it.

Iâ€™ve changed between "recommended" and "not recommended" a couple of times, which sadly resets the helpful ratings. (6 ratings lost by my count.)

================================00

Tl;dr: 

Itâ€™s a fun game. Casual on basic difficulty, requires some strategy/luck/skill at higher difficulty levels. Bad luck can be hard to mitigate.

The game was very much overpriced when it came out. Compared to other games in the genres (peggle-likes, rogue-likes, and peglin-roguelikes), it is still very pricey and I recommend waiting for a sale unless you are very sure about the game.

================================00

When it came out, the game was very shallow for a rogue-like, and very imbalanced as well. There are still quite a few two-item combos and three-item combos that can pretty much break the game, but at this point there is an increasing amount of depth. Likewise, these game-breaking combos are much less likely to occur, now that there are many more orbs and relics.

Random chance can still very much make or break a game. Unless you get at least one solid orb/relic or combo going early, you may become trapped in a loop where you can barely improve your Deck because you have to heal after most fights.

I highly recommend adding something like a shop (similar to Slay the Spire, for example). Give the player a choice of, for example, 10 orbs and 5 relicsâ€¦ but at a price. Even adding only a single shop-like event during the whole game would really help players work towards builds, and reduce scenarios wherein you are basically waiting for specific orbs/relics to pop off, knowing that your current build will not be able to survive the late-game fights.


================================00

Once you get going, skill often loses more and more importance. Unlike, for example, Slay the Spire, where you are often still fundamentally changing your Deck and strategy on floor three, here the same combo from the first floor will often remain barely altered until the final boss.

Likewise, the "Peggle skill", which is to say strategizing where to aim and actually managing the right bounces often becomes nigh obsolete. As a consequences of the layout of many late-game boards, as well as many relics and upgraded orbs, aiming is often practically useless beyond the most basic concept of "aim in the general direction of where you want to hit stuff". 

If your orb is literally attracted by every one of up-to hundreds of targets, if the targets are constantly moving, and if you throw up to 16 orbs at once, then itâ€™s mostly random chance what will happen. However, this depends on your specific Decks, and some orbs can reward strategy/skill throughout the game

=================================00

This is a fun idea crippled by some very serious issues.

First and foremost, the developers seem to be very focused on making a challenging game. While I normally enjoy difficult roguelikes, this is peggle were talking about. The hugely chaotic and effectively random nature of most shots past the first one or two bounces means that skill will only take you so far, and adding permadeath to the mix just leads to a really bad feeling every time you get bad luck.

The pixel art hurts the game here as well, since it's harder to tell how your shot will bounce off pegs which function as circles but have chunky, blocky edges.

Refreshing the board is absolutely essential to clear fights effectively, but the only guaranteed way to do that is to hit one of two randomly located refresh pegs. If you get bad luck with the spawn locations, it's easy to end up in a situation where you just have to waste multiple shots carving a path to the refresh, which is frustrating.

Lastly, there just isn't that much content, certainly not enough to justify the price tag. Runs get repetitive quickly.

I really hope the developers take this game in a different direction and focus more on having wacky, fun synergies, but that doesn't seem super likely. In the meantime, don't bother buying this unless it goes on a big sale or gets some very significant content updates.

Peglin is a game with promise, but no polish - or at least, the polish has been applied in the wrong places, leaving huge expanses of dull gameplay. While I understand that it is an early access game, as of June 2022, [b]I cannot recommend buying this game for the hefty price tag that it comes with[/b].

Visually, it is an engaging game. The cute pixel graphics are lovingly-crafted, and they're definitely the main thing that will keep your attention for at least 2 hours of gameplay. It also has appealing audio design, which is great, because every good Peggle-style game needs to have satisfying "plinks". The graphical design of the different orbs you can obtain in your run is also interesting, even if they don't have as much of an effect on gameplay as you might expect.

I found the best parts of this game to be the parts inspired by Slay the Spire. The relics system - although not quite as robust and varied as StS - did keep me engaged, at least until I realised that not only were there relatively few relics, they also had little to no synergy with each other. Even the ones that you might think pair well together don't seem to make a tangible difference in how the game plays from round to round, fight to fight, or act to act. Similarly, the random events with extreme parallels from "that other roguelike" (probably one of if not the best roguelikes of all time) were also enjoyable for the first few rounds, until you start to see repeats. And believe me, you will start to notice the repeats very quickly, likely long before you finish the game. 

Enemy design is interesting, until you realise that there is little to no variety in what they actually do. Normal enemies are minor annoyances that die quickly, elite enemies are annoyances with a dash of bullet-sponge. They overstay their welcome. There is little difference between the types of enemy you face. Occasionally, you'll find gimmick enemies with a special mechanic that actually impacts your strategy, like the mirrors. These were cool the first time I encountered them in Act 2. Finding out that they repeat into Act 3 was a bit of a bummer, and make me feel like [b]the ideas ran dry before they got to that point[/b].

The finest example of the ideas running dry is the Act 2 Wall Boss. Literally a wall with a high health pool and no interesting mechanics. It does not attack for however many painstakingly slow turns it takes to reach you, at which point you are dead. You are playing Peggle with/against a brick wall that does nothing to you, and your only goal is to complete the damage-check. That's it. No strategizing whatsoever.

There isn't much strategy behind the random events and what choice you pick. Often, either way, your build gets shafted, and you end up with a hodgepodge of special-effect pegs which don't feel very special or synergize with each other. 

Peglin is missing that element of control over your destiny. You have very little control over your build, very little control over the path you navigate down (if you're blocked by pegs after finishing a level), and ultimately, very little control over the outcome of the game. You will immediately begin to feel the drain as soon as you finish a run for the first time, if not before then. I cannot imagine this fundamental failure of the game becoming any better without significant changes throughout future development, which is a real shame, because I want to like it very badly.

Good if you want a game you can dip in and out of for short sessions (the game saves before every fight or event), or for longer playtimes where you do a whole run in one go. Synergy between upgrades gives very fun results. The music makes a fun and quirky background which fits the game's aesthetic and there are a variety of enemies and bosses to face. Foes often have unique tricks built into the levels which make them more difficult and interesting to face, such as sticky pegs that slow your orbs down. 

If you like putting together a build which becomes greater than the sum of its parts, this is a great game for you. You will acquire many artefacts ("relics") along your journey which synergise to massively power up your character. 

The semi-random relics and huge variety of orbs mean that it doesn't become repetitive: one run could be all about gathering as many stones as possible to power up a certain orb that is strengthened by them, while the next run might focus entirely on upgrades that boost the number of bombs you can throw until you're vomiting out a stream of explosive maimery that wipes the map clean in a single glorious cacophony, or stacking critical hits until you're somehow hitting for two billion damage against enemies with a few thousand health.

I've had a lot of enjoyment out of this game (I put a lot of time into the demo that steam doesn't take into account) and would absolutely recommend it.

It's fun until it just decides you're not allowed to have fun.  The RNG is too severe.  I might forgive the random "easy" battles that, due to bad balance can just end a run if you have the wrong artifacts (especially those that magnetize or otherwise change your ball path)... but even the navigation is an RNG minigame.  Instead of going on a route that picks up 2 chests, it might decide that you're going to fight multiple "easy" enemies... who then decide to take 2/3 of your HP because your build need another relic or two... It turns all the fun you were having sour.  I really wish it was good, because when RNG navigates where you want to be, it can be a great experience, but when you lose, it never feels like you could have done anything to win.

[h1] It's every Arcade game you happily lost countless quarters to[/h1]

[b] The Good [/b]

 There's something about these Rube Goldberg machine type games where "it's away!" is both addictive and fun.  While there is RNG, nothing about the pachinko room feels unfair. But the game is pretty challenging.  I'm about 3/15 runs, hence the "it will eat your quarters" style arcade game.  Still fun though.

There's clearly a concept of "Builds" - bomb based (which goes poorly for the final boss IMO), crits, multiball madness, etc.  The ball variety is pretty good and that is what makes the game the most fun.  The fact that enemy positioning matters is pretty cool too.  

[b] The Bad [/b]

It's true, at current state in Early Access I can see myself playing this game exactly another 20-25 hours and it will just get too monotonous.  At present it gets about a 5/10 replayability.  But for $18 US, I think it was worth the price.  My rule of thumb is I should get at least 2 hours of entertainment for every dollar and when it's done I could see somebody spending 100+ hours on it.  

I'll say more below, but when the RNG is unkind (like... no decent ball offers the entire first act) it is brutally punishing.

[b] The Ugly [/b] [i] (Psst - Hey Devs, here's the feedback to improve the game!)[/i]

I'll start with the obvious - you need more rooms, more bosses, more mini bosses, more enemies.  Sounds like there's other characters planned too?  Cool.  Right now this plays like a $5 mobile game, but it could be almost slay the spire level good, with a bit more content and balance.  

Add a merchant (? event) with 7-10 different orbs, artifacts and BALL REMOVE!  Since health is the game's currency, just use that.  This could be very easily implemented as is.  Make this event more frequent, like 20% chance.  Maybe make a "buy nothing" to heal 20%.  This will do a tremendous amount of RNG removal to the game, because of shitty maps and bad reward RNG.  

Make rewards consistent / predictable about the enemy rooms, whether it's acquiring a new ball or getting an upgrade.  That doesn't seem like it should be random.  The current design removes skill in both map pathing, and can just fist you royally when you're rolling into the end of act 1 with three shitty lvl 3 stones.  

There are some artifacts that are absolutely OP.  Let me know if you want me to share which ones.  

There are some orbs that are simply "uncompetitive" because they will leave you in a really bad spot for the final battle.  Maybe that's what skipping is for, but it would be cool if there were an artifact that let you choose a ball from your inventory.  

One idea is a ball that deals little damage but "pushes back" the enemy, a la brambles holds them down.  Perhaps a "Blue bomb" or something.

The one bug I've found is sometimes a ball will stop on a moving level and just... despawn.  Seems like if teh ball is detected as stuck it should auto bounce in a direction at random slightly... not just despawn.  Fucking brutal on the last boss when this happens because riding the platforms is the entire strategy.  

Anyway keep it up, it's a fun game.

Peglin has the honor of being my 100th Steam review. And it's even a positive one!

I think we've all seen roguelite elements applied to many game genres by now, but roguelite Peggle is a new one for me. Peglin is refreshingly unique. Each run starts out a little slow, but they get fun once you get deeper into it and start collecting orbs and relics. The effects of these items interact with each other in interesting ways, and THAT'S what makes every run feel different; not the enemies or the boards, but your build. It's fun, and it almost has an addictive mobile game quality to it. You'll die only one or two turns away from defeating a big boss, you'll get frustrated, and then you'll hover your mouse over the quit button for a few seconds before thinking "...nah, I can do one more run." Peglin's a good time waster. And it's really solid for an early access title. There's not really any game-breaking bugs or anything like that. Peglin just needs a little more variation when it comes to its boards and levels, the ability to choose classes, and a drop of polish. Considering it's status as an early access game, I'd expect all of those things to come with time.

I don't really have anything glaringly bad to say about Peglin. It's good for what it is, and it'll probably only get better with time. If you like Peggle or other pachinko-esque games, and if you like roguelite elements, give Peglin a try!

First off, I really like the game; the style, the mechanics and the premise, but I can't recommend it.

Here's why:
-The balance feels off...
-The projectiles feels sluggish or lose inertia way too quick and not fun while some items makes the projectiles move in what I feel should be "normal"
-Some levels are almost impossible to do well because of the lack of "pins" while some other you absolutely can't fail at as it is impossible for your ball to reach the bottom without mid tripple digits minimum.
-The game had benefitted by not making all the "pins" the same shape and doing something with the side walls too, but they didn't (as of my review).

All in all, the core gameplay loop feels unsatisfying and like you can't really Skill your way through anything as the trajectory feels random at some times and rigged at other times. So even at a heavy discount, I don't feel I can recommend it currently and as well when there are some saying the Dev apparently banned negative comments/reviews.

Played the peglin demo for 6hr, now the full version for 3hr. 

TL;DR - buying the full game isn't worth it.

I played the first world (in the demo) for maybe a dozen times. I think it is the most balanced and enjoyable part of the game. Buying the full version gives you two more worlds, but as the relics begin to stack on top of one another and the enemies get exponentially harder, the element of skill and strategy begins to recede, and you end up blind firing shots with increasingly more chaos. 

Given how quickly chaotic the game becomes with the collection of so many relics, I don't see how the developers are going to add more content - the final world is already out of control. The game needs to be paced down to allow for more of a slow, fulfilling build-up of power-ups and more powerful enemies. 

The peg boards in the more advanced levels are also much less thoughtful. Most of them consist of several hundred pegs scattered in some semi-coherent pattern in which you fire and watch the mayhem unfold. It's somewhat satisfying, but loses a lot of replay value and charm.

Whatever algorithm controls the receiving of relics should have more control over which relics are offered to the player at which stage in the game, and ensure that the player begins by receiving small improvements, and the enemies get incrementally harder. This would prolong the campaign and allow for more of a focus on how the user actually plays the levels.

Despite the inherent simplicity that comes with a peg-breaking game, like Peggle before it, Peglin is charming, compelling and fun. Having already made the comparison, I will say; at surface level, it's easy to say "it's like Peggle" but when you make it a rogue-like and add a ton of items that modify your 'orbs' (balls) or the pegs themselves, it becomes a lot more 3 dimensional. There is a certain element of luck, particularly on the levels where the pegs start moving around quickly but I haven't yet felt cheated by the game. Plenty of replayability, as with any rogue-like and, at the time of writing, apparently more characters on the way. Highly recommended as something to whittle away a couple of hours with.

The levels are fun and different each time you play them.  It is a fun take on pinball with defeating bosses with your damage and healing.  Even if you are skeptical you should play.  It is not scary and it is not timed so you have as long as you want to think about your next moves.

However, with that being said, I think the balance is way off, the enemies deal far too much damage and theres a bad lack of healing or rng in general to even get a way to heal. I win maybe, at best, 1 out of 50 loses, which lowers the replay value. I have hope that the devs add more to this game because has huge potential in becoming one of my top games. I definitely recommend people play this, but beware right now its very unbalanced.

Its like Spell Tower meets Peggle in the most addictive way possible. Levels vary in difficulty and the replay-ability is pretty good with the variety of orbs and items that change how each game is played. Mission is a set 3 maps long and can be replayed in Cruciball mode for added difficulty. The Cruciball settings go from mildly challenging to frustrating real fast with the missions becoming nearly unbeatable if you don't get certain items or orbs by certain points. Power up can become wildly dangerous in late game and you can bring yourself down to zero health with splash damage from your own bombs from full health. Mixing the power ups is a bit like alchemy and becomes almost addictive in itself. Overall 9/10, fun to play but needs some refinement. The further future updates are sure to bring more to the game

First things first, this is a very fun game. Peggle was my very first video game addiction, and Slay the Spire was my most recent, so seeing the two games combined is nothing short of a dream come true, and it is everything I've ever wanted.

That being said, this game is clearly still in early beta, as it is riddled with bugs, albeit very minor bugs. The most annoying bugs I have encountered mainly center around playing with a controller, where the controller will not be available for input during certain moments, namely the end of a successful run and during the pachinko relic obtaining segments.

Item balancing is pretty impressive for a game as early in development as this one, save for the sapper sack, which I still believe could use a drop from 150 damage to 100.

Overall, I would easily recommend this game to anyone looking for a new roguelike to play or a fun way to pass the time, and I can easily see myself putting 100+ hours into this game in the future.

I have really been loving this game and I enjoy the challenge and different options.  
I did want to say that I found a bug though that was mildly frustrating.  I was fighting the final boss in the caves, the cubes. I had gotten through all but the last one and it only had a  about 50 health left. I had several level 3 Orboros, since the bonus damage for my shot was going to be 300+ I decided to have fun and not hit a single peg for the final shot. 
I threw Orboros straight down, and killed the cube. However, the game did not end, the cube animation was still spinning but was an empty box, and I could not shoot any more orbs, or do anything. I recorded a video of it after that and will post that when I figure out how to do that. 
I had to go to the main menu to leave the game, and had to completely redo the fight. Luckily I still won, which was nice.  It was my first win on lvl 1 Cruciball. 

Great game otherwise, and just thought this was a neat bug. I will continue to enjoy this really rad plinko adventure game!

Fun addictive game that I can't stop playing. Not perfect by any means as RNG can be ruthless, but updates are scheduled. Biggest crime that this game commits is that there is no downloadable soundtrack option as it's a bop, and would be totally listening to it whilst doing other things.

Note: This game is in Early Access. There's a pretty good chance that the current issues will be at least mitigated before the full release, and I know that. This review is specifically covering the current build.

I wanted to like this game so badly. I heard about its announcement ages ago, and grayfruit's playthrough of the closed demo back in late 2020 had me decently excited for the release of the game. However, at least in my opinion, the game fails to provide a fun experience on nearly all aspects.

The music is okay. I wouldn't go so far as to call it "bad", since it takes a genuinely talented musician to make bad music, but the tracks are more average than anything.

The general style and direction of the game is quite endearing, and it's probably my favorite part of the game. The ball puns are cute, I like the creativity with the item designs, and the different boards for each enemy group are really cool.

The gameplay is... Well... Pachinko. I wouldn't necessarily call it worse than pachinko, but it's definitely worse than Peggle. Part of the joy of Peggle was how easily controllable the ball is, and being able to do trickshots, slick shots, and bucket bounces feels REALLY good when you manage to pull it off. I can't quite place why, but the ball feels unruly and hard to manage in Peglin, especially when you're trying to refresh the board. Combine that with the necessity of hitting specific pegs in order to actually deal serviceable damage, and it quickly becomes VERY frustrating.

The roguelike elements feel very forced, and as much I want to like the interesting ideas put forth by the game, I can't shake the feeling that the twists and interesting mechanics of the game are derivative and downright lazy in places. The Slay the Spire formula just doesn't work if you can only draw up to two cards per turn (three with a very specific relic), and you can only play one, and enemies have ludicrous amounts of Health, and you can (usually) only attack one enemy at a time.

On the subject of enemy health and AoE damage, the balance is easily the worst part of the game. You either make a bomb build, or you're playing the game wrong. I know that sounds very pejorative and closed-minded, but I'm being serious. Sapper Sack increases your odds of winning by 500%, and every Bob-Orb increases your chances by 100%. Bombs are the only thing in this entire game that can deal enough damage to push through the stupid amount of health and numbers of the enemies. And oftentimes, even that's not enough. There is a specific miniboss in Area 3 that is a darkened room completely filled with enemies, each of which have something like 777 Health EACH. Even with a bomb build, the room is completely ridiculous. As well as that, the Wall Head has over 7000 health, and if he makes it all the way to the player, you instantly die. I don't think I've ever beaten the boss without either Sapper Sack or Electromagnet (which was nerfed to hell in a recent patch). Animated Ruins is also a ridiculous boss, but I've only ever seen that boss three times, and beaten it once. In 11 hours of gameplay, I've only ever seen that boss THREE TIMES, and the one time I killed it was before the balance patch that made it harder.

I sincerely hope some major changes are made to the game, since I really want to like it. But as it stands, I just don't have fun when I play this game.

A fun little indie game for the first 3 hours during which I got my first clear. I started on the harder version and stopped playing after another 2 hours of not getting anywhere and feel that mode needs more balancing. The game is more of a true rougelike since you don't unlock powers or become stronger after a playing for a while. Replayability isn't there yet as the three levels don't give you time to build out a strategy and your more of just going along for the ride.

Technically the games controller support and full screen windowed mode worked flawlessly for me. I'd say the game should be priced at $5 right now for 3-5 hours of play. Hopefully they will add a lot more content and bring its value up. Some sort of money gathering system that allowed you to buy power-ups would add more depth to this game. It could really borrow a lot from Slay the Spire and it would be more fun.

I got to Cruciball Lv.6 (essentially ascension 6 for Slay the Spire fans) and at a point the game just gets way too punishing for it to be enjoyable anymore. Several levels are fun and you can kinda get this rhythm about how you're meant to throw the balls for solid damage, but there are multiple encounters that will just completely end your run if you're unlucky enough to get them through almost no fault of your own or your build. 

First terrible encounter is the Minotaur miniboss on stage 1. The peg arena is shaped like the Minotaur's horns along with some sparse pegs underneath it, and you can tell you're meant to slide your orbs down the horns for good damage; however, the Minotaur's health is way too high and most of the time you won't have any orbs strong enough to take him down before he makes his way towards you and start chunking you for 22 health every two turns. The pegs underneath the horn pegs are way too spread out to get good damage on him, and in the worst cases the refresh board peg will get stuck underneath the horn structure which means you can't do any damage until you clear all of the multiple pegs blocking it, which allows the Minotaur to end your run. Three-fourths of my runs end when I have the misfortune of rolling this miniboss, I've just learned to restart my game when I see him.

Second potential wiper is the massive ballista boss of stage 2. Most encounters in stage 2 are very fun and relatively fair even if your orbs aren't very strong, but the ballista is able to deal 30 damage within a few turns of the fight starting, and will repeat the attack every 5 or so turns afterwards, of which 2 of those will leave you with the confused status, which causes your aiming to go crazy. Between its large health pool, ability to outright execute anyone who has low health from earlier in the stage, and requiring AoE to deal with its constantly summoned minions that will block individual shots for it. It has ended quite a few runs that were for all intents and purposes going well beforehand, and there is no clever way of avoiding the massive damage it can put out unless you get specific relics, which is entirely RNG-based.

Last terrible encounter is in stage 3, where you will encounter two worms who attack from range and a conga line of suicidal peglins that will blow themselves up for 35 damage when they get in melee range. The peglins have way too much HP (450 each) and the the real kick in the teeth is the pegboard, which are multiple moving diamonds with red bombs you're meant to hit to deal with them, but if you pick up certain relics such as 'The Gift That Keeps On Giving' which causes all pegs to take three shots to break or unless you have a very specific orb (lightning), then your orbs will immediately slide off the diamonds and fall into the abyss. The moving diamonds mean that if you can't hit these bombs, then your orbs can't gain any kind of purchase and will just fall to the bottom of the board without dealing any real damage. Runs that should have been winners have all failed at this one particular encounter, and between resetting my runs to not get stomped by the previous encounters only for this one to always appear and ruin my run, I no longer have any desire to play this game anymore.

Resetting after a failed run is long and tedious because you need to grind through the same few encounters again and again, hoping for the types of orbs and relics that will actually give you a fighting chance against the encounters that ordinarily would end your run (bomb builds are effective in every encounter, give you a chance to kill the Minotaur and ballista, and are extremely effective against the last boss) only to get completely stomped in the very last stage because the you didn't get the one orb capable of saving you from a single endgame encounter.

I would strongly advise against getting this game as it is currently, encounters need more polish and general counterplay so that you don't eat shit because the game decided to pitch you encounters you're utterly incapable of dealing with.

There is no reason that I should enjoy this game as much as I currently do, I've beaten the game twice and have seen probably every part of the game but I can't stop playing because the amount of content that I know I can make with this game is limitless.

It has promise.  It wants to be peggle, but misses out on a huge amount of what makes peggle fun.  A number of unfair fights and events.  Lack of power slides.  ball bounces seem bleh, with the ball often just falling through pegs.  Maps often funnel into a corner.  Refreshes/Crits often spawning in impossible places.

The aim of the game is to survive long enough to build a combination of Ammo and Artefacts that have insane synergies and damage.

The game begs to be broken and if you play well you WILL end up breaking its spine over your knee.

I think for the most part, after going through most of this game's content that it's really fun and I agree with a lot of people saying it needs a bit more content before justifying the price tag, which looking at the roadmap, looks like it is coming.
The main gripe I have with the game is how RNG dependent it can be. At least to my knowledge, it is completely random if you get an upgrade or a new orb at the end of a battle and due to the massive scaling enemies get between acts, this can literally lead to a dead run if you are unable to upgrade your orbs. This is also extremely frustrating in crucible mode where if an R peg gets in a bad spot and you don't have very specific relics, say goodbye to your entire 30+ minute run. I feel like the reduction of R pegs in the challenge mode just feels awful as it just takes the game out of your hands.
Apart from this, I would say the game is pretty good and I have put a lot of time into it, I would recommend as a casual game but not for someone expecting an experience akin to a game like STS due to the RNG dependence.

This game gained traction though the "Going Rouge" Event on Steam, as well as a mention from "Roundguard" Dev's around the "Roundguard" 2.0 update. "Peglin" was cute enough and seemed to have a lot of potential, especially for people that were fans of not only "Roundguard" but "Peggle" as well. After seeing the way the Dev's of "Peglin" dealt with critical posts on Steam Discussions about a week into the release, and also after a very nerfy update around the same time, I began to have doubts. 

Aside from pulling posts that were mildly questioning of the price point, they seemed to not really care to listen to customers input if they offered constructive criticism. Combine that with no real road map as far as development is concerned, and lackadaisical attitude in general towards suggestions from people that clearly want to see the game succeed, more alarm bells began to ring. 

Now that posts are being pulled from Steam Discussions by the Dev's of "Peglin", I had to review it. I don't recommend supporting this title as it is, especially at a $20 price point. If they really want to make this title succeed, they need to listen to ALL the players, not just the ones that support every single thing the dev's state they are going to do or "maybe implement at some point *add dismissive tone*". 

Follow the game, sure. Read the discussion's and give feedback on the Demo, sure! I would simply ask that people observe before purchasing. Play the Demo, ask questions, and engage the Dev's, that, I think, is the only way to squeeze value out of the game for folks that already paid full price. To all those people that played "Peggle" and had the satisfaction of "I made that shot happen", don't expect that here. It all seems so directionless... much to my disappointment.

::Edit:: The day after I poster this, they released what they call a "RoadMap". It is lackluster at best, and not very much direction is given, hardly a "RoadMap".

For those who love Peggle, this game *almost* scratches that itch. I loved the rogue-like elements and creative balls in-game, but it became clear early that each ball doesn't make enough of a splash. You end up going for the specifically stronger balls and builds.

Truthfully, the content at its core is there. They definitely need to fix the physics in the game (probably the most frustrating element) and they will have a real gem on their hands.

I absolutely love Peglin. It's genuinely my new favorite game right now.
The way you create builds with orbs and relics reminds me a lot of The Binding of Isaac, in the best possible way. 

For being in early access, this game has an impressive amount of variety throughout the three worlds that are currently available. The recent balance changes are very welcome, and the upcoming class system is a good idea.

The rest of this review is directed toward the developers of the game about a few little tweaks I would make:

Please, PLEASE give us a fast forward button like in Peggle! I like the enemy movement animations on the top, but after many many games, it ceases to be useful information, and just wastes a lot of time.

I understand if you don't want to make it right click, since that currently works as discard (which is very useful to have as right click) but maybe fast forward could be done by holding middle click or something?

Another thing: at the beginning of each game, the player is greeted by a random selection of three relics to choose from. It doesn't make much sense to have it be a random selection, since they can just immediately back out of the game and reset until they happen to roll the relic they want.

Making it into a picker menu would be a very satisfying answer to this problem, where the player can select exactly which relic they want to start with, but a passable compromise would be to just simply add a 'reroll' option to the existing selector instead.

One other thing that might be more on the personal side of things: the slime boss is too damn hard, and unfun to fight. I do like the concept of the orb launcher's location changing when the goblin is consumed by the slime, but that gimmick doesn't really add to the fight. Please make that boss more interesting and less of a grind!

Thanks for all the love and energy you've clearly poured into this project. Gamedev absolutely kills people mentally, and I hope you're doing okay through it all. Much love!!

It's an OK Pachinko-roguelike game, with a lot to be improved.

1. Some orbs are practically unusable. It might be fine for a game like Slay the Spire to have useless cards since there are more than a hundred of them, but for a game that only has a dozen of orbs, this significantly limits the variance of playstyle and hence the replay value. The relics are very unbalanced either.

2. Some maps are very hard to play. If the refresh ball (R) gets spawned in an awkward position it's very difficult to play.

Minor issues:

I. When an orb gets stuck for a few second, it disappears and is considered a lose orb. That doesn't really make sense as the orb is still in contact with the beads. 

II. The pricetag is too high for a pre-release given the current game content.

This is a great game at its core, but it still needs a lot of polish before its truly worth its price tag. There just needs to be a lot more if it IMO, as once you get a hang of the game it feels pretty samey from run to run. 

I have one specific gripe for the gameplay, and general ideas on how to fix it:
- Speed up button. Sometimes you throw a bad orb, and you just sit there watching it bounce around hitting nothing of importance.... mocking you and your failures... So instead, you hold the space bar or something, and the game speeds up to 2x speed. I would in general make the gameplay faster (especially when enemies are attacking which feels like it lags behind the general gameplay). 

Other than that, as long as the devs keep supporting/updating the game for the foreseeable future and fine tuning, it should eventually be a great game. In the meantime, you can't deny that it's fun and creative roguelite!

Very fun game overall. The core concept is fantastic and addicting and it is a great game to play while watching something on another monitor.

However, while the game play is great, it's clearly an alpha title in the content department. After 4 hours of game play, I seem to have experienced everything the game has to offer. 

Some content I'd like to see added:

2-3 more characters that change the way the core game is played. Would be a simple thing to add some archetypes like archer, wizard, etc. that change how pegs work or anything. Anything to mix it up.

Some type of curses or otherwise negative perks. Right now the only really bad relic is the self-damaging bombs. In later stages its common to full clear a board multiple times, so it's possible to clear every red bomb at once, killing yourself. 

Shops, or some form of player choice mechanic. Right now adding cards to your deck is simple, but there's very few options to remove cards. It was common for me to have 10+ cards in my deck even when being hyper selective.

Major balancing. Even 3 hours in I was finding the content trivial; no boss or encounter lasted past my third card, including the final boss. In my third run I did over a million damage in a single shot. A hard mode or ramping up mode would be obvious (and seems to be in productive) but it goes beyond that. I was clearing each fight in the first 1-2 cards, and the only time I was in danger was killing myself with red bombs in the stages where they spawn naturally.

More bosses and enemy variety. 

The music is good but the game needs more tracks. 

An option to speed up the peg bouncing would be nice. There were times where I had to wait a full minute to finish bouncing around. Maybe a button you can hold to speed it up 2x speed at least. 

I think 3 levels is about the right size, but maybe alternate zones to mix up each run. Ascending instead of descending, etc. 

Overall, game play 8/10, music 4/10, and content 2/10. Looking forward to checking in to see if there's anything new in a few months.

The core gameplay mechanic is a blast, and if the devs accomplish everything on their roadmap, the game's major flaw (its over-reliance on RNG) will be fixed. There is clear passion being put into this project, and I think it was well worth the purchase.

I'm going to echo what others are saying: The concept and execution is great, but the content is lacking. If you're contemplating on buying this, I'd recommend holding off until there's at least one additional content patch, just for the reassurance that the Devs aren't going to slack off or bail on us. It's not unheard of for a developer to lose interest after having a very successful (and profitable) early access launch. As soon as the Devs prove they're not going to take the money and run, I'd say this game will be an easy buy.
Not enough content

Interesting concept but the balancing is way off. The game started out very difficult (always dying very early), but as soon as I found out what builds work, it turned around and got too easy (as in dealing 4 digit damage every attack with AOE on top). It has potential but needs some work.
Cute little game, oddly addicting.

I love the fact I can just do a 30 minutes run, lose terribly, be angry at the game and not want to play it ever again, knowing that I suck badly at aiming, and then come back the next day for yet another 30 minutes run... Core gameplay loop checks out :+1:
fun

Too concerned with balance, it forgets to be fun. The idea is great but any good power-up has huge downsides, and you don't have enough control to build a run, The core idea is solid, but the devs need to let some runs be overpowered

Needs more to it to justify the price considering it only has 3 "levels", and I finished the game in a few attempts . That being said, it's a fun concept and it plays very well. Considering it's still early access, I definitely see the potential in the game. Hopefully the devs take pride in their product and continue to release fun, cute and addictive content for this game. Once it's a full game it may well be worth the price!

I know the game is still in early access, but I really wish it wasn't! Took me around two hours to finish the game for the first time, then I played nine hours more, and still keep coming back. I have now played it with so many different tactics and builds and love how crazy it gets so fast.

I congratulate the devs for this fantastic weird and cute idea of a game, and a flawless execution of it. I'm looking forward to having more and more maps. My cute peglin needs more enemies to chase.

10/10 as far as I'm concerned, and I'm really picky about my games. It has become my evening routine to relax with, clicking soothes my overactive brain and lets me concentrate on listening to an audio book, podcast or a youtube interview while drinking juice and letting out steam going through those goofy levels and bossfights. No pressure, yet the challenge is there. I love it.

Well worth the money on early access, and even moreso after the full release. Definitely recommend this, specially to anyone with adhd-tendencies and a thing for a roguelike "might have to try again couple times, and then go again a few more for fun" stuff.

Just let me know if you release any peglin merch, I'll go to my office proud wearing that goofy goblin on my shirt and hat.

Cheers!
So much fun! Hope for more levels soon.
fun game
Man I love pegging
beans son

PEGLIN IS GREAT. PLS GIV MORE. BUY THIS GAME, NOW. You shall not regret your decision. It is truly a wonderful game that has adorable graphics and great music. It is relatively short, but the game is currently in early access! I am definitely looking forward to more from this majestic game. It's relaxing, and quirky. I like it.
please expand this game so I don't have to go back to playing old Peggle games I am begging you
The game is fun and the concept is great. My only real complaint is that the game as it is now is far more luck based than skill/build based.

Peggle and a Roguelike! There's lots of fun combinations of orbs and abilities in this game to produce some absolutely absurd numbers. Lets just say a basic rock does 2 damage for every peg it hits. I just did 24k damage to the final boss in one it. WOW!
A fun, relaxing game that requires strategy and a bit of luck! Cute art and animations too. Wish there was more!
Its very cute, I love it
If you love randomness in games, you'll LOVE this game. It allows for customization but can still be taken out of your hands any second. HIGHLY recommend.

I got this game because I watched Northernlion play it on Twitch.  It is a lot of fun, even in its current state.  Some of the encounters feel less fair than others, but for the most part the balance between RNG and player control is nicely done.  The game feels a lot like Slay the Spire to me, if you replaced the combat part with Peggle mechanics.  The branching map, the random encounters, the relics all remind me of StS and the orb selection feels a lot like simple deck building.  Really solid twist on a couple of beloved game concepts.  It's a bit addicting and even when I was mad that I lost a boss fight, I still felt compelled to click the restart button and go again.

A very fun and original take on Peggle that makes it way more interesting for people like me who don't like or are bad at peggle.

I can recommend it currently if it was a bit cheaper,  but for an early access game there's a ton of promise.   Because the core systems are all here and work beautifully, and really the only thing that is lacking, are the tried and true ways of making rogue likes better, such as in the following wishlist:

- New Characters with different starting line ups or orbs, board special peg counts, or starting items.
- Some long term benefits that turn it more into a rogue LITE  (IE, items that once unlocked, are permanent baseline upgrades)
- A harder challenge mode (already in beta)
- Some way to make the first 3 ish rounds of every playthrough not feel the exact same.

9/10
fun

This is a good game. However, at the time of making this review it doesn't have enough content to justify a $20 price tag.

It will eventually be a great game, and well worth the money at $20. I have no doubt about that, but it might be years until that time comes.

Buy it if it goes on sale, or if you _really_ love both Peggle and Slay the Spire.
haha orb go brrrr
more like poglin
Addictive (waiting for more content)

I've only played for a couple of hours, but I'm already loving this game, because it's the perfect mix of strategy and chaos. One run, I gathered as many stones as possible to increase the damage of one orb in particular, then the next run I created a bomb build so ridiculous that I ended up dying from full health to my own bomb explosions. The game is perhaps a little overpriced right now, but hopefully additional content will be added over time to make the game better value.
Bomb builds are fun A.F.

Obviously still needs some work and expansion, but a fun casual game. If you like Slay the Spire and Peggle, you'll probably enjoy it. 

Only caveat is It's priced higher than it's worth for most players - it's 80% of StS's price, and it's a loooong ways from being 80% as polished or as deep as StS, but if you're not really worried about the cost, go ahead and give it a try, it actually is fun.

This game is a lot of fun, but there is nowhere near enough content currently for its price tag, theres also a couple frustrations that hold it back, for example, trying to path a route is borderline pointless as it can be blocked by pegs by the time you get there and go the complete opposite direction, theres also too few items, encounters and bosses, only one character.

But the game is fun, i enjoyed playing it. But I'd recommend waiting until its farther in development, Especially for its current price tag

Core concept of the game is great, a lot of fun and potential for lots of different strategies and builds. 75% chance you're gonna just end up doing a bomb build anyways but yaknow, its the thought that counts.

Obviously the game is still very clearly in early access and it's incredibly bare bones. Not much content and once you've beat 3 or 4 runs on cruciball mode, you've basically seen all there is to see. While I wouldn't recommend buying it in it's current form as it's still lacking a lot of content, if you're somebody like me who's just been searching for a fresh new thing to maybe sink some time into, maybe give it a shot. 

Excited to see future developments for now.

Very fun and satisfying to play. As you may have guessed, it's a bit like Peggle and a roguelike had a baby. The runs get absolutely nutty by the end of the game. After finishing a few runs though it might feel a little same-y depending on what combos and decks you go for.  So hopefully in the full version there'll be a lot more orbs and events to give the game more variety. 

Also: a personal gripe but the Minotaur fight should get way more pegs.

For a game in early access it's absolutely worth getting, assuming you can get it on sale because the base price is a little high.

What can I say that hasn't been said already? It's good casual fun, but in it's current state it lacks the content to justify the asking price.
That being said, there's a lot of pontential and I can see myself waste hundreds of hours on this game if they keep updating it.

Ps.: WHY DOES THE MUSIC GO SO HARD
Are you supposed to beat the game on the first run through?

Really good game can't wait for the full release!!
Just wanted to say it is an adorable game to chill and play casually.

If your not a fan of Peggle, this may not be for you. The item combos, can get rather comical. To have 5-6 beefy enemies on the screen at once, and to wipe them all with a long chain is just fun. The game is kind of short however, Once you beat the 3rd campaign region, that's it. The game is the hardest early in my opinion when you don't have many item/ammo synergies, late game it gets easy and if you have a good synergy set up, the final region boss is little threat.
peen
PEGLIN!!!
Needs some more content but it's a good game for early access.
fun little game, even on early access.

I played through the demo a few times and the improvements between the demo and early release were vast and for the better. The creators really listen to input and put a lot of care into balancing.

At the moment, the game is very RNG base so there isn't really a sense of being able to customize your build at all. Certain builds are only available if you hit certain events and I hate the coin/luck relic with a passion. Not all bosses are built equally either, as the bull mid level boss is probably the worst peg layout while the plant boss is so much easier by comparison. At the same time, in the second stage, the demon wall boss is basically one massive DPS check and is so much more difficult than the ballista boss. I've only beat the wall once, and that's because I had so many bomb relics going. Other times, I had rather strong heal builds, but demon wall don't care about heal builds at all. Only eating little peglins.

There isn't a lot of control over adding things to my deck vs upgrading them, so the current gameplay just feels like "spam for as many relics as possible because you'll never get a deck you like." The RNG is what dominates the game at the moment. That's my only complaint.

Currently, if I get a really good relic layout, I'm winning battles in four turns, so it takes me about an hour through all three areas. This isn't a compliment or complaint, just a general statement of gameplay as it is. Confusion relic go brrr.

Otherwise, I do like it a lot. The level designs are nice and always interesting. Each area feels vastly different from the last. Sprites are gorgeous.

I really look forward to what the final game will be.

I also agree with everyone else that $20 is to much for the game as it stands now.
Please more level :)
Its fun, wish it had more content.

This is a must try for fans of Pachinko style games like Peggle or SushiCat. The extra Roguelike elements are very reminiscent of Slay the Spire and add an interesting level of complexity on top of the addictive core gameplay. At the time of writing this, the game just released on Early Access less than a month ago, so understandably there is not a ton of content to play through. The negative reviews on the steep price tag are correct, you are paying a hefty amount for a short experience. Regardless, I would still recommend this game. What's there currently is a lot of fun, and I'm very excited to see how it evolves.
Peggle + Roguelike = Great Idea
Simple premise, well executed and a reminder of a great game from the past
If you liked Peggle, and you liked Slay the Spire, then your gonna love Peglin!
Great fun, when I won my first run I was worried, but it turns out I had a bit of beginners luck, its a hell of a lot of fun.
Price is too high - please poke me when it will be around 5$ will buy again.
very fun game. love it. Thanks to Duffrid3r

Even in early access stage, the game feels quite polished already. The difficulty level is good, it's not *too* hard and it's fun to play. The orb puns are great, the difficulty increase throughout the levels is also good.

Had a good time, and will definitly continue playing.
addicting
Tiny amount of content, annoying animations that take too long.

I loved both Peggle and Slay the Spire. It's an interesting mashup idea, and on paper, Peglin should be a great game for me, but it's not ready yet.

There's just not enough here to warrant the price. There's no progression system, which actually makes sense as the difficulty is so low that unlocking anything extra would be unnecessary. The low difficulty also means that the orbs are essentially meaningless. They give some interesting effects (and some less interesting ones), but unlike StS where I was agonising over every card choice, Penglin gives little reason to do anything other than pick the orb you think is coolest.

I really really hope this game lives up to its huge potential one day. This is a good start, but it needs a lot of work.

Best game of 2022 10/10

Very good, but you can't deny the current lack of content,. But come on, it is Early Access so no surprise there. 
I'd love to see this game in it's finished state

Still needs quite a lot of the work. The basics are kinda fun, but the game is very unbalanced. It also offers very little options for a roguelike game, making each run feel the same. At the same time, there is no real progress in the game. Achievements don't unlock new orbs, new interactions, enemies, relics or anything, which makes the game a bit boring rather quickly. I do think there's a lot of potential to this game, but definitely not worth the rather steep price tag it has.
pretty fun would like to see more content in the future tho.

Peggle meets Slay the Spire. They blend remarkably well. The variety of balls and relics means no two runs are the same. Issue is its WAY too easy and too short. I beat it on my second try and then again on my third try. There needs to be a final floor (hopefully there will be in the full release) because just as things start to pick up steam, it ends. Also certain ball types are just so overtly broken that it may benefit from some rebalancing. Super enjoyable and addicting though for all its flaws. Unique too! Worth the money imo

Very cute and a clever blend of roguelike and Pachinko, which isn't a combination I've seen before. Not a lot of content right now and it's pretty easy to beat, but it's still very fun. Can't wait to see what else they add.

Great game I definitely hope they add more bosses orbs and relics soon but as long as this game is consistently updated and the ascension system is implemented well  I can see myslef playing it for quite a long time to come
great time passing game, feels so good to just play and one shot enemys
yes

I am really enjoying this game, but late-game is a joke as the relics seem to be too strong for the late-game levels. Additionally, some of the late-game levels should be early game levels (pegs moving upward) as combos easily exceed 1k while having no clue what your balls are hitting due to 'darkness' (should be a mid-game gimmick to matter, by late-game it does not matter).  I have never come close to losing once I get to the late-game, either I am a rogue-like peggle god or this game needs a much greater difficulty curve. It is still super fun to play and I think it has a bright future once a balance overhaul/audit is complete. I am excited to see future patches. The lightning is in the bottle, you just have to contain it!

P.S.: After some thought, the upward moving pegs should simply be downward moving pegs - that may be enough to make those levels difficult, especially if the bottom third of the board is sparsely populated.
Yes but currently the game is very short. 2-4 hours of current actual game-play. after that it just restarts so
Super fun and very replayable

Needs more to it for the price. Whats there is pretty good, but there's less than $10 of stuff at the moment. Four or five music tracks, 3 stages with 2 variables on the boss per stage. You spend the majority of your time in the beginning stage. Whether because of skill or luck, you lose a lot in this game. the forest is first and only stage you can start on and the music is always the same. It's a nice song, but it and the peg-boards get old after just a few re-plays. Fighting bats? The pegboard is shaped like a bat, how creative. Fighting a slime? The pegboard is shaped like a slime. Fighting a spider? It's a web, and the most un-fun board in the game where "sticky" pegs slow your ball down.

The stat building aspect of the game is what makes it interesting from other peg games. The sad thing is you're limited to a few types of weapons/relics or else you can straight up kill yourself from your own strength. And if you do in fact get lucky and land on a god-build, there is no "fast-forward" option. You have to wait and wait and wait for your ball to finally leave the screen and kill the one mob with 5 health on the screen with your Stone lv. 1. And that's indeed if you don't land on a level absurdly overloaded with enemies compared to other boards in the same stage. Your run can end in no time when you arrive at a board you simply didn't get lucky enough to deal with.

What starts as a cute, endearing, and very entertaining game, end as a frustrating gamba simulator. Which is appropriate.
a very fun game that offers challenge as well as a large potential to grow as  more updates come out.
Its actually just so fun
Good
Great Game especially when modded.

I found this game from a random youtube video that called it a cross between peggle and slay the spire, and that is what this game delivers. The synergy between the different power-ups is cohesive, and the is enough variety in the level designs to remain interesting across multiple runs. I am very excited to see what additional enemy types and random encounters they add as they develop further. The only aspects that felt missing at this point is the ability to speed up the movement of the level pegs when aiming, and the ability to aim more precisely like Peggle has.

While it's fun on the first go, the lack of difficulty and the miniscule amount of content for the high asking price means i had to refund this and not recommend it. I completed it on my first try without the slightest hint of difficulty.

Difficulty is always a difficult thing (ironically enough) to get correct, but a roguelite game like this lives or dies off of its challenge.

Also items (relics) you get vary WILDLY in power. Health recovery should be a rare thing, not "recover 1 health for each 5 pegs hit" or something inane like that, which guarantees infinite health in later levels.
Great Rougelike. Remember, early access. Only three peg boards as of now // But there is massive replay potential while getting lucky randomly with the artifacts and different ball options.

I'll just say what most are saying as I have to agree... Not worth the price, but...!!

it's well worth the replayability. Granted, too soon to tell. Being early access at this point. The game's gotten this down rahter well, just keep adding to it. I'm actually enjoying going back to this every update to see the difference. Haven't actually lost a fight yet. Most peeps just don't realize the power of the cookie relic with the refresh orb alone, and that bombs do 50 to everything but not to you... getting a bomb orb to make more is a discount way to handle the small fry that poke, or those spiders that you can't quite snipe, but without the bomb refresher relic you'll start to lose peg slots so it becomes a slight risk. as for the red bombs and this strategy... that's the point behind them. They deal damage to you too. if you have the cookie and a refresher orb, you won't need to worry about dying any time soon if you know how to peggle. especially if you manage to make the pegs durable. I have yet to get a run without the cookie and even went without a refresher. The chances of bouncing into a refresh tile or having a relic that makes crits refresh... oof. The game isn't hard. Even Cruciball. It's about knowing how to work around the board. I can see where it could be hard, but in the words of an archer who changed over the years: "It's simple Geometry." or rather once you figure out every orb's weight and can see into a jump or two... eh... it'll come in time.

Anywho... I'll be saying 7/10 at this time. Needs more to it. As it stands there's less to it's generations outside the unique mechanics of being a peggle game than practically every other deck builder game. However, it's very good as it is. A more realistic price for this game would be about $9 or $10. Don't quote me there. I'm no price expert. It's just what I'd be willing to pay. My friend went out of their way for this, so I'll give a review. It's entertaining enough that I even did this in the first place.

PS: I actually enjoy the music. Enough so, that I wish there was a DLC for the soundtrack. I'd give more info, but I'm no writer for details beyond my knowledge as a gamer, sry. No programmer knowledge or anything of the sort to nitpick the finer details and give input on the mechanics of the game outside what I experienced like I put above.

Though I feel a bit dirty paying 20 bucks for a pachinko game, everything else about it makes it somewhat justifiable. If the price tag seems a bit steep, perhaps follow and wishlist Peglin and see what comes of it.

The gameplay itself feels fine, having played the demo I was pretty interested in what else the game had to offer. The blend between pachinko and rougelite mesh well. I do look forward to what other areas will be left to discover, what new potential relics and events might be added, and most importantly- what new boards might show up. Getting stuck with the minotaur as often and as early as I do in runs can really sour the potential of a run. I don't mind the minotaur as a unit since he's pretty scary and all, but the board the minotaur uses doesn't feel like it has too many good shots. Hopefully more variety in units or boards will alleviate that issue for me when more content becomes available.

Peglins themselves are super charming and adorable and I kinda want a peglin plush. Deffo going to include peglins in my next DnD session. If it weren't for their cute factor, I probably wouldn't have bought this game if I'm going to be honest with myself.

Also really enjoyed seeing the mole instead of the giant slime this second time winning, the slime pegs really bring me down !

It is rare that an update to a game makes me actively enjoy said game less, but boy did this game manage to do that. When I first purchased this game, the boards were a bit odd but there was never a situation where I felt like "man, this doesn't really tickle my fancy the same way Peggle did". Every board, like Peggle, was fun. Every powerup, however oddly worded, felt enjoyable and like you could make a build around it using others. Rarely was there a situation where me losing was something I couldn't chalk up to being bad. I even recommended it to a bunch of my friends who liked Peggle or Slay The Spire, giving it ludicrous amounts of praise.

And then the game got updated.

Now, the boards feel unspeakably bland, and all the fun powerups have been neutered so much that having them feels more like a crutch than not having them. New powerups feel like they hardly do anything even when they trigger. Honestly, everything feels like it was intentionally made less fun. Runs that used to be tough but definitely completable have now been reduced to two-board wipes that force me to restart due to lack of pegs to deal damage with. Where there was an interesting idea that felt wacky but well-executed is now a game I'm almost considering taking back my shining recommendations to friends.

THAT BEING SAID, I get it. It's early access, they're still working on it, stuff has to be ironed out. It could very well be that the next update of this fixes all of these problems and more, and the game becomes as good, if not better than, it's former self. It happens. And when this game gets another update, I will gladly take another look at it, see how it feels and adjust this review accordingly. But until then, the phrase "It's an Early Access game, take it with a grain of salt" is best felt with this game in particular. It might be your cup of tea now, and I hope you enjoy it if so, but don't bank too hard on it staying the same.
not worth :( tiny game

I recommend this game with a HEAVY asterisk. Right now in it's early access this game is very narrow minded in what builds it will let you play with. And I don't mean a limit to the orbs though I would like to see more variety in that. To explain, there is a boss on the second tier that auto kills you once it reaches you. It is a damage check boss. But if you're running a slower build like what I did the first time I reached him, one with lots of healing, you can't do anything to him. It's very annoying that there is a boss in this game the completely invalidates a playstyle this game lets you play, one that was absolutely destroying everything up until that point by the way.

I will also say that the power curve in the game is extreme and as of yet I don't see a lot of builds the game gives you the chance to play being viable in them. I think the game needs to do a lot to broaden the curve with more levels or longer levels, and more varied bosses. 

And get rid of one hit kill bosses.

No. No it's not.

Will this game help my wife realize I still love her and just made a mistake?
No. I had too many shots at that hot tub party in Denver. This is a game about hitting pegs with balls. 

Thanks Devs! Great game!
